All creatures within the cloud become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}, and all creatures outside the cloud become concealed to creatures in it.

Each creature that begins its turn inside the cloud takes @Damage[5d6[poison]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:28|basic|options:area-effect,inflicts:sickened] save). A creature that fails the save is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure).

action->Toxic Breath.name: Toxic Breath
action->Toxic Breath.description: The blight drake spews a fetid ball of polluted putrescence up to a range of 60 feet that explodes in a @Template[type:burst|distance:15]. Creatures within the burst take @Damage[4d8[acid]|options:area-damage] damage and @Damage[4d8[poison]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:28|basic] save). The blight drake can't use Toxic Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Toxic Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Infrared Vision.name: Infrared Vision
action->Infrared Vision.description: A bloodbrother can detect infrared radiation (such as that given off by warm-blooded creatures) as a precise sense at the listed range.

action->Frigid Cold.name: Frigid Cold
action->Frigid Cold.description: 10 feet. A bloodbrother's flesh radiates intense cold. A creature that starts its turn in the area must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:22|options:area-effect,inflicts:fatigued] save or become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.HL2l2VRSaQHu9lUw]{Fatigued} while it remains in the area. Creatures immune to environmental cold effects or with any cold resistance are immune.

action->Drain Vital Fluids.name: Drain Vital Fluids
action->Drain Vital Fluids.description:
Frequency once per round

Requirements A creature is imprisoned in the bloodbrother's ribcage prison

Effect The bloodbrother drains the vital fluids from the imprisoned creature. The victim is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} (or increases its drained value by 1), and the bloodbrother regains @Damage[10[healing]] Hit Points, gaining any excess Hit Points as temporary Hit Points that last for 1 minute.

action->Frigid Touch.name: Frigid Touch
action->Frigid Touch.description: A creature that begins its turn @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained} by the bloodbrother takes @Damage[1d8[cold]] damage.

action->Grisly Ambush.name: Grisly Ambush
action->Grisly Ambush.description:
Trigger The bloodbrother hits a creature in the first round of combat, and the bloodbrother was hidden from that creature at the start of combat

Effect Each enemy within 30 feet that witnesses the attack (including the target of the attack) must attempt a @Check[will|dc:25|options:area-effect,inflicts:frightened] save. On a failure, the creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} (or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 4} on a critical failure).

action->Ice Passage.name: Ice Passage
action->Ice Passage.description: A bloodbrother ignores difficult terrain from ice and snow and doesn't risk falling when crossing ice.

action->Imprison.name: Imprison
action->Imprison.description:
Requirements The bloodbrother has a Large or smaller creature @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained} with their bone spur

Effect The bloodbrother tries to imprison the required creature in their ribcage prison. The bloodbrother attempts an @Check[athletics|against:reflex] check against the creature's Reflex DC, imprisoning it on a success. The bloodbrother's bone spur is no longer grabbing or restraining the creature they've imprisoned, so the bloodbrother is free to use their bone spur Strike once again. The bloodbrother can't attack a creature they've imprisoned and can have only one creature imprisoned in their ribcage prison at a time. An imprisoned creature is restrained ([[/act escape dc=25]]) and temporarily immune to the bloodbrother's frigid touch while restrained.

Botnib.name: Botnib
Botnib.publicNotes:
The lowly botnib, also called a computer glitch gremlin, is intuitively tied with the computerized devices and networks of the modern age. These cavorting fey make it their mission to create as much havoc as they can by influencing computer systems and creating chaos in their wake. Known for their innate ability to communicate with digital devices, computer glitch gremlins routinely become infatuated with such systems, which they subvert like one might put together a fun puzzle.

Gremlins have plagued the Universe with cruel tricks since long before the Gap, and they've fully adapted to a galaxy filled with technology. Whether meddling with a comm unit, a starship, or an entire space station, gremlins delight in ruination and chaos.

action->Digital Telepathy.name: Digital Telepathy
action->Digital Telepathy.description: A botnib can communicate telepathically with digital devices and with other creatures that can do so (such as other botnibs). This allows the botnib to attempt Computers checks to access any computer within the telepathy's range.

action->Techsense.name: Techsense
action->Techsense.description: The botnib can sense items and creatures with the tech trait within 100 feet.

action->Glitch Aura.name: Glitch Aura
action->Glitch Aura.description:
20 feet. Creatures and items with the tech trait struggle to function reliably when near a botnib. Creatures with the tech trait, unattended items with the tech trait, or creatures holding equipment with the tech trait that start their turn in the aura must attempt a @Check[will|dc:16|options:area-effect,inflicts:glitching] save.

Critical Success No effect, and the creature or item is temporarily immune to the botnib's glitch aura for 1 minute.

Success The creature or items are unaffected.

Failure The creature, item, or all the creature's held items become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6A2QDy8wRGCVQsSd]{Glitching 1}.

Critical Failure As failure, but @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6A2QDy8wRGCVQsSd]{Glitching 2}.

Caypin.name: Caypin
Caypin.publicNotes: Caypins are brawny predators with the agility of wolves and the scaly skin of crocodiles. Their most striking feature is a mass of wriggling, semi-sentient appendages that cover their heads. Each of these tentacle-like protuberances contains a bloodshot eyeball and a gaping mouth full of teeth, and the caypin—which has no eyes or mouth of its own—relies on these orifices to see and feed. Nutrients absorbed by the appendages are passed to the caypin via tiny receptive sockets in the beast's jaw, and caypins can detach these appendages into writhing clusters that independently move up to 100 feet from their bodies. In the wild, caypins use these clusters to ambush prey, and the creatures are known across the galaxy for their rapacious ability to consume half of their body weight in raw meat.

action->Appendage Cluster.name: Appendage Cluster
action->Appendage Cluster.description:
A caypin's detached appendage cluster is a Small, mindless, semi-independent creature controlled by the caypin. It has the minion trait, darkvision, @Damage[30[healing]] Hit Points, a land Speed of 20 feet, and a swim Speed of 15 feet. It shares the caypin's AC, saving throw bonuses, and skill modifiers. The caypin can see what its appendage cluster sees and otherwise shares its senses with the cluster. Each round, the caypin can Command a Minion to grant an appendage cluster 2 actions. An appendage cluster can make jaws Strikes (Melee 1 jaws +14, Damage 2d4+3 piercing) and has the Cluster Onslaught ability.

If the caypin is killed, any detached appendage clusters are also killed. Any appendage cluster that moves more than 100 feet from the caypin dies instantly.

If both the caypin's detached appendage clusters are destroyed but the caypin still lives, the caypin is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} until it regrows at least one of its appendage clusters. A dead appendage cluster regrows in 3 days.

action->Aquatic Ambush.name: Aquatic Ambush
action->Aquatic Ambush.description:
40 feet

Requirements The monster is hiding in water and a creature that hasn't detected it is within the listed number of feet

Effect The monster moves up to its swim Speed + 10 feet toward the triggering creature, traveling on water and on land. Once the creature is in reach, the monster makes a Strike against it. The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} against this Strike.

action->Cluster Onslaught.name: Cluster Onslaught
action->Cluster Onslaught.description: An appendage cluster attempts an Acrobatics check to [[/act tumble-through]] a creature's space. On a success, the mouths of the cluster gnash and gnaw at the creature, dealing @Damage[3d8[piercing]] damage. If the Acrobatics check was a critical success, the target also takes @Damage[4[bleed]] damage.

action->Detach Cluster.name: Detach Cluster
action->Detach Cluster.description: The caypin detaches half of its facial appendages into an appendage cluster that occupies a single adjacent square of its choice. A caypin can have up to two appendage clusters detached at a time, and if both clusters are detached, the caypin can't make jaws Strikes or Detach Cluster again until at least one cluster reattaches. An adjacent appendage cluster can reattach to the caypin with an Interact action.

Cerebinite.name: Cerebinite
Cerebinite.publicNotes:
The mineral cerebinium, also known as memory crystal, naturally appears in the broken region of space known as Kazmurg's Absurdity. Typically, these minerals develop in remote subterranean locations, where they grow based on the presence of thinking minds within a planetary range. The more active minds in a region, the faster these mineral formations grow. A major world of millions can easily create vast underground stores, and in these majestic caverns, cerebinites spontaneously emerge.

Cerebinites are essentially mindless creatures—save for the memories that power them—who have developed as an offshoot of cerebinium growth. Though possessing no intellect of their own, they act off the impulses provided by the memories stored within the crystals that constitute their forms. In many ways, a cerebinite is like the many oozes that lie in wait throughout the cosmos.

Encountering these active mineral deposits often requires a delicate approach, as cerebinites can engage up close or at a short range by hurling cerebinium spikes and blasts of cerebinium shards charged with memories drawn from their surroundings. Even in death, these masses of cerebinium explode in a destructive burst of psychic energy, affecting the minds of those nearby with jumbled visions of countless different lives. When multiple injured cerebinites gather near one another, this proximity can cause an especially destructive chain reaction due to cerebinites' own susceptibility to mental attacks.

strike-melee->Blast of Cerebinium Shards.name: Blast of Cerebinium Shards
strike-melee->Blast of Cerebinium Shards.description: Creatures that take mental damage are also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round on a critical failure

action->Crystalline Ambush.name: Crystalline Ambush
action->Crystalline Ambush.description:
Trigger A non-mindless creature enters a space adjacent to a cerebinite

Requirements Initiative hasn't yet been rolled

Effect The cerebinite automatically notices the creature, makes a crystalline growth Strike against one creature adjacent to itself, then rolls initiative.

action->Mind-Shattering Demise.name: Mind-Shattering Demise
action->Mind-Shattering Demise.description: When the cerebinite dies, it explodes in a blast fueled by the memories stored in its crystalline body, affecting all creatures in a @Template[emanation|distance:30]. Each creature in the area (including other cerebinites) must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:22|options:area-effect,inflicts:stunned] save or take @Damage[2d8[mental]|options:area-damage] damage and become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} (or double damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2} on a critical failure).

Civusdaemon.name: Civusdaemon
Civusdaemon.publicNotes:
Born from infospheres and digital networks, the civusdaemon is a force of malign intent who bends online spaces to torment mortals. Representing death through oppression and hate from social media, these daemons act in the shadows, tormenting their foes to such a ruinous extent that they often take their own life.

Hailing from the plane of Abaddon, daemons are utterly devoted to the destruction of all life. Their existence is based around specific means of death, and they seek the death of all things in service to their lords: the Apocalypse Riders. Each daemon represents a different way to die, and they use their specific powers to further that means of death.

Advents in technology have only created new means of death and torment, so new types of daemons enter existence with regularity, each created once a sufficient mass of new deaths occurs to spawn them. These new advent daemons often prefer to spend their time in the galaxy rather than Abaddon, as they can better spread their torments to the mortals of creation.
Civusdaemon.allSavesBonus: +1 status to all saves vs. mental

action->Eyes on the Infosphere.name: Eyes on the Infosphere
action->Eyes on the Infosphere.description: A civusdaemon knows the presence of any creatures connected to any local infospheres it has access to. A creature who is connected to an infosphere is visible to the civusdaemon as a precise sense. Disconnected creatures who've been active on an infosphere within the past day leave enough residual trace that a civusdaemon can sense them as an imprecise sense.

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Menta.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Mental

action->Profile Picture.name: Profile Picture
action->Profile Picture.description: A civusdaemon appears as a strangely two-dimensional version of a creature of their choice. Creatures targeting the civusdaemon must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:5] to do so, as if the civusdaemon were @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}. A creature who succeeds at this check automatically succeeds at further such flat checks for 1 round.

action->Well, Actually.name: Well, Actually
action->Well, Actually.description:
Frequency once per day

Trigger An enemy critically hits the civusdaemon or the civusdaemon critically fails a save against an enemy's effect

Effect The attack becomes a hit instead of a critical hit, or the critical failure on the save becomes a failure instead.

action->Character Assassination.name: Character Assassination
action->Character Assassination.description:
The civusdaemon targets the online reputation of a creature it's aware of on a shared infosphere. After 1 day of downtime, the civusdaemon attempts a @Check[computers] check against the target's Computers DC.

If successful, the target takes a –2 circumstance penalty to all checks made on that infosphere because of damage to their reputation. The civusdaemon can maintain this effect each day by spending another day of downtime without needing to attempt an additional check.

If the civusdaemon maintains this for a week or more, the penalty increases to –4. The creature or an ally of the creature can spend a day of downtime to attempt a @Check[computers|dc:26], Deception or Diplomacy check to counter the character attack.

On a success, the civusdaemon's efforts end, and the target becomes immune to this ability for 1 month.

On a critical success, the target or ally also identifies a specific location that the civusdaemon operates out of, such as one where it frequently connects to the infosphere.

Clangit.name: Clangit
Clangit.publicNotes:
Clangits, or space station gremlins, know everything about the inner workings of their home stations and enjoy punishing or pranking the station's larger inhabitants who know less than they do. "Haunted" space stations and ships with mysterious power flickers, doors that randomly open and shut, equipment that malfunctions at just the wrong time, and frequent unexplainable accidents are probably the home of one or more clangits.

When they aren't playing pranks, some clangits monitor and repair the sensitive machinery keeping many older space stations afloat—a fact that has probably saved them from eradication on larger settlements like Absalom Station. Most clangits stand about 2 feet tall and weigh around 7 pounds—the perfect size for slipping through vents and squeezing down maintenance tunnels.

Gremlins have plagued the Universe with cruel tricks since long before the Gap, and they've fully adapted to a galaxy filled with technology. Whether meddling with a comm unit, a starship, or an entire space station, gremlins delight in ruination and chaos.

action->Mechanical Trickery.name: Mechanical Trickery
action->Mechanical Trickery.description: When a clangit has spent at least 1 hour exploring a ship or space station, the gremlin gains an innate sense of its inner workings and can remotely control mechanical infrastructure within 60 feet, performing simple actions such as opening and shutting airlocks and doors, opening heat vents, activating alarms, turning lights on and off, or tampering with gravity controls.

action->Tech Travel.name: Tech Travel
action->Tech Travel.description: The clangit enters adjacent mechanical infrastructure, such as a control panel or pipe network, and instantly emerges from another within 100 feet.

Cloud Ray.name: Cloud Ray
Cloud Ray.publicNotes: Enormous cloud rays are apex predators on gas giants such as Bretheda and Liavara. Cloud rays are incredibly maneuverable and can fly through the atmosphere at speeds few can match, rendering them nearly inescapable when on the hunt.

action->Explosive Death.name: Explosive Death
action->Explosive Death.description: If a cloud ray dies due to fire or electricity damage, its internal reservoirs of explosive gases and combustible fluids detonate in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] that deals @Damage[11d8[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:30|basic|options:area-effect] save).

action->Lash Out.name: Lash Out
action->Lash Out.description: The cloud ray makes two consecutive tail lash Strikes at a –2 penalty against any targets within reach. These attacks count toward the cloud ray's multiple attack penalty, but the multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after it makes all its attacks.

action->Natural Thruster.name: Natural Thruster
action->Natural Thruster.description:
Frequency once per hour

Effect Until the beginning of its next turn, the cloud ray gains a +80-foot status bonus to its fly Speed and deals an additional 1d10 slashing damage with its tail Strikes.

action->Stunning Lash.name: Stunning Lash
action->Stunning Lash.description: A creature that takes electricity damage from a cloud ray's tail Strike is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} (@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2} on a critical hit), then becomes temporarily immune to stunning lash for 1 minute. Creatures with a weakness to electricity don't become temporarily immune.

Cloud Skate.name: Cloud Skate
Cloud Skate.publicNotes: Cloud skates are skittish creatures that avoid settlements whenever possible. They travel in large packs when in their docile periods and remain in small groups even during their aggressive hunting cycles, making them dangerous to travelers. They navigate through the clouds using three powerful tails, trapping prey with huge, baleen-filled mouths that span the full width of their single-segmented bodies.

effect->Effect: Natural Thruster.name: Effect: Natural Thruster
effect->Effect: Natural Thruster.description: You gain a +75-foot status bonus to your fly Speed and deal an additional 1d10 slashing damage with your tail Strikes.

action->Explosive Death.name: Explosive Death
action->Explosive Death.description: If a cloud skate dies due to fire or electricity damage, its internal reservoirs of explosive gases and combustible fluids detonate in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] that deals @Damage[6d8[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic|options:area-effect] save).

action->Natural Thruster.name: Natural Thruster
action->Natural Thruster.description:
Frequency once per hour

Effect Until the beginning of its next turn, the cloud skate gains a +75-foot status bonus to its fly Speed and deals an additional 1d10 slashing damage with its tail Strikes.

Collapsing Structure.name: Collapsing Structure
Collapsing Structure.descriptionHazard:
The kyokor (or other kaiju) grazes a structure, severely compromising the building's stability and possibly causing it to collapse.

When a kyokor passes by or through a settlement—or even attacks!—it leaves a trail of destruction that can be represented by the following hazards.

Terrifying, skyscraper-sized beasts roam the wastelands of Daimalko. Called colossi by the population, these monsters erupted from deep within the earth to stomp cities into dust, decimating the population and destroying every surface civilization on the planet in a terrifying Awakening. Kyokors are among the most dreaded colossi. There's no hope of defeating one without a valko—a war machine created by Daimalko's stubborn survivors to fight the colossi.
Collapsing Structure.disable: @Check[athletics|dc:43] (master), @Check[civil-engineering-lore|dc:43] (master), or @Check[crafting|dc:43] (master) check to brace the structure to reduce the risk of collapse until the end of the creature's next turn. The DC of the flat check for this round (see Routine) is increased by 4 on a success, or by 8 on a critical success. Increasing the flat check DC to 21 or higher stabilizes the structure, ending this hazard.
Collapsing Structure.reset: The building becomes susceptible to Demolish again [[/gmr 1d6 #rounds]]{1d6 rounds} after it's stabilized.
Collapsing Structure.routine: (1 action) The GM rolls a @Check[flat|dc:9] to determine if the building collapses, increasing the DC as listed in Disable. On a success, dust and debris fall within the building and 30 feet around it, providing concealment and dealing @Damage[6d6[bludgeoning]] damage to [[/gmr 1d4 #Targets]] randomly chosen targets (@Check[reflex|dc:35|basic] save); on a critical failure, a creature is also knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}. On a critical success on the flat check, the effect is the same, but the debris deals @Damage[12d6[bludgeoning]] damage to [[/gmr 2d4 #Targets]] randomly chosen targets instead (@Check[reflex|dc:35|basic] save); on a critical failure, a creature is knocked prone and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained} by rubble until freed ([[/act force-open dc=38]]; [[/act escape dc=35]]).
Collapsing Structure.stealth: (master) to notice cracks forming in the walls of the structure as the kyokor (or another kaiju) approaches.

action->Demolish.name: Demolish
action->Demolish.description:
Trigger The kyokor (or other kaiju) applies any amount of force to the structure

Effect The building trembles. The floors of the building and the streets within 30 feet of the building become difficult terrain; creatures on this difficult terrain take a –2 circumstance penalty to attack rolls, AC, and skill checks. The hazard rolls initiative.

Coposirix.name: Coposirix
Coposirix.publicNotes: The rapid and careless industrialization of Tabrid Minor ruined the planet, particularly ravaging the population of copi—the coral that's the ancestor of the native copaxi people. In areas where the copi's magical connection to gravity was strongest, however, the rampant pollution instead mutated it into grotesque new forms. In a twisted mockery of copaxi evolution, clusters of copi fused together to form coposirixes, shambling mounds of mutated copi fused with a partial shell of crystallized waste that crackles and creaks as it moves. The form of a coposirix constantly changes, sometimes even taking on hauntingly humanoid features that melt away just as quickly.

action->Seep In.name: Seep In
action->Seep In.description:
Trigger The coposirix takes damage

Effect The coposirix's body absorbs some of what damaged it until the end of its next turn, the material seeping into its constituent copi and changing its composition. The effects of this change depends on the nature of the damage.

  • Energy Damage The coposirix's attacks deal an additional 2d6 damage of the same type as the energy damage dealt to it.

  • Physical Damage The coposirix gains resistance 6 to physical damage. If the damage was dealt by a weapon made of a special material, such as silver, the coposirix's battering sludge Strike counts as that same material for the duration of the effect.

action->Falling Rush.name: Falling Rush
action->Falling Rush.description:
The coposirix bends gravity around itself, causing it to fall toward its target. The coposirix Strides up to twice its Speed in a straight line in any direction. If it ends this movement within melee reach of at least one enemy, it can make a battering sludge Strike against that target. After this attack, the coposirix falls if it isn't on a solid surface, taking half the normal amount of damage for the distance fallen and not falling @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}. If the coposirix passes within 10 feet of another creature at any point during this movement, that creature is affected by the fluctuating gravity and must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:25] save.

Critical Success The creature can use the fluctuating gravity to its advantage to reposition itself. It can Step as a free action.

Success No effect.

Failure The creature is pulled 5 feet in the direction of the coposirix's travel. This follows the rules for forced movement. If at the end of this movement the creature is unsupported, it falls and lands prone, taking fall damage as normal.

Critical Failure As failure, but the creature is pulled 10 feet and falls prone even if supported.

Corchaaz.name: Corchaaz
Corchaaz.publicNotes:
The crab-like corchaazes of Tabrid Minor build their shells from copi, a coral-like polyp that also constitutes the bodies of humanoid copaxis. Copi contain hollows that collapse matter into dense stores, creating pressurized chambers that emulate black holes. Corchaazes break down copi with their claws and add the material to their shells, creating gravity wells on their bodies. Corchaazes are effectively immortal unless they die of injury or illness. Legend has it their shells continue to grow as they age—copaxi folk tales describe corchaazes as big as islands.

A coastal shelf collapse on Tabrid Minor in 322 ag destroyed the planet's major corchaaz spawning ground, but this wasn't the end for this hardy species. In 324 ag, a team of scientists in a nearby star system noticed wildly fluctuating gravimetric readings. Following the weird readings, the scientists discovered and tracked a group of corchaazes traveling along a local Drift lane. Corchaaz migrations were new, and many scientists were eager to study rafts, as the migratory groups were called. More corchaaz rafts showed up the following year in other systems, including the Ghavaniska and Pact Systems.

action->Gravity Well.name: Gravity Well
action->Gravity Well.description: 20 feet. The corchaaz's body pulls nearby creatures toward it with dense gravitational forces. A creature that ends it turn within the aura must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:20|options:area-effect,forced-movement,inflicts:prone] save or be pulled 10 feet toward the corchaaz (also landing @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} on a critical failure).

action->Interstellar Raft.name: Interstellar Raft
action->Interstellar Raft.description:
A corchaaz can combine its gravitational forces with other willing corchaazes into an interstellar raft as an exploration activity that takes 10 minutes. While part of an interstellar raft, the corchaazes must remain within 100 feet of each other. Additionally, the raft members gain a 40-foot fly Speed and the cosmic trait (both of which they keep for 1 hour after this ability ends). An individual corchaaz can Dismiss the raft, which detaches all combined corchaazes. If half or more of the raft members die, the interstellar raft ends.

@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.2UI9dt0QM2VEvpJV]{Effect: Interstellar Raft}

action->Copi Concealment.name: Copi Concealment
action->Copi Concealment.description: The corchaaz raises a gravitational barrier around its copi shell and gains @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealment} against all creatures for 1 round.

action->Graviton Grip.name: Graviton Grip
action->Graviton Grip.description:
The corchaaz attempts to lock a creature within 40 feet into place with gravitational forces. The target must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:20] save.

Critical Success The target is unaffected.

Success The target takes a –5-foot status penalty to its Speeds until the end of its next turn.

Failure The target becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}.

Critical Failure The target is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} for 1 round.

Corpse Fleet Infantry.name: Corpse Fleet Infantry
Corpse Fleet Infantry.publicNotes:
The Corpse Fleet's rank and file infantry are trained to work as a unit.

The Corpse Fleet is an army made up of undead supremacists who refuse to bow to the will of the living. Founded by defectors from the Eoxian navy, the Corpse Fleet aims to shatter Pact Worlds unity and liberate Eox from the influence of the living and those bone sages who sided with them. Unyielding and utterly ruthless, the Corpse Fleet deals in death and destruction, feeding on the living and exploiting the dead.

weapon->Arc Pistol.name: Arc Pistol
weapon->Arc Pistol.description:
Upgrades: 1

Instead of traditional ammunition, this bulky pistol contains a capacitor that generates arcs of electricity. Its stock is crafted from polycarbon or other synthetic insulators, often tinted bright yellow and inscribed with the universal bolt symbol for high voltage.

weapon->Autotarget Rifle.name: Autotarget Rifle
weapon->Autotarget Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

This short, bulky assault rifle incorporates a piston system that allows the user to switch to auto-fire and unload a magazine with one trigger squeeze.

weapon->Battleglove.name: Battleglove
weapon->Battleglove.description:
Upgrades: 1

These durable gloves fit over a wielder's hands (or other appendages) and feature weighted plates or spikes over the knuckles.

armor->Shotalashu Armor.name: Shotalashu Armor
armor->Shotalashu Armor.description:
Upgrades: 1

Flexible but sturdy plates layered together form this traditional armor worn by lashunta cavalry on Castrovel. In times past, a shotalashu cavalry member forged their armor from their mount's shed skin, or more rarely, the skin of a fallen mount, to honor them in future battles. Synthetic imitations are fashionable on some parts of Castrovel.

action->Coordinated Shuffle.name: Coordinated Shuffle
action->Coordinated Shuffle.description:
Trigger An adjacent ally moves away from the Corpse Fleet infantry

Effect The Corpse Fleet infantry Strides up to half their Speed. They must move in the same direction as the triggering ally.

action->Fusillade.name: Fusillade
action->Fusillade.description: The Corpse Fleet infantry's ranged Strikes deal an additional 1d4 precision damage when the Corpse Fleet infantry is within the first range increment of at least one other member of the Corpse Fleet wielding a ranged weapon.

Corpse Fleet Officer.name: Corpse Fleet Officer
Corpse Fleet Officer.publicNotes:
A Corpse Fleet officer is a bold combat leader who bolsters their undead allies and has trained to destroy the living.

The Corpse Fleet is an army made up of undead supremacists who refuse to bow to the will of the living. Founded by defectors from the Eoxian navy, the Corpse Fleet aims to shatter Pact Worlds unity and liberate Eox from the influence of the living and those bone sages who sided with them. Unyielding and utterly ruthless, the Corpse Fleet deals in death and destruction, feeding on the living and exploiting the dead.

weapon->Laser Pistol.name: Laser Pistol
weapon->Laser Pistol.description:
Upgrades: 1

This compact pistol is the most popular sidearm in the Pact Worlds thanks to its reliability, durability, and affordability. Most common laser pistols have a lightweight polycarbon body ending in a long, slim barrel.

weapon->Phase Cutlass.name: Phase Cutlass
weapon->Phase Cutlass.description:
Upgrades: 1

A phase cutlass resembles a traditional curved sword until it's powered. Then its blade morphs into a shimmering void, with a tiny star for each life it ended.

armor->Defiance Series.name: Defiance Series
armor->Defiance Series.description:
Upgrades: 1

This squad armor is a molded shell of reinforced polycarbon with a helmet and retractable visor.

action->Bolstering Aura.name: Bolstering Aura
action->Bolstering Aura.description:
20 feet. Undead that begin their turn in the aura (including the Corpse Fleet officer) gain 8 temporary Hit Points for 1 hour, then become temporarily immune to bolstering aura for 1 hour.

@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.ZWOPndNX0EIhYCG9]{Effect: Bolstering Aura}

action->Decimate the Living.name: Decimate the Living
action->Decimate the Living.description: The Corpse Fleet officer has trained to decimate the living. Their Strikes deal an additional 1d6 void damage.

action->Lead Salvo.name: Lead Salvo
action->Lead Salvo.description: The Corpse Fleet officer makes a ranged or melee Strike against a creature. Each undead within 100 feet of the officer can immediately use a reaction and expend ammunition from a ranged weapon they're wielding equal to its expend value to increase the damage of Lead Salvo by @Damage[1d4[void]] damage for each undead ally, to a maximum of an additional @Damage[4d4[void]] damage.

action->Tireless Flurry.name: Tireless Flurry
action->Tireless Flurry.description: The Corpse Fleet officer makes one ranged Strike and one melee Strike in any order. These attacks count toward their multiple attack penalty, but the penalty doesn't increase until after both attacks are made.

Corpse Fleet Recruiter.name: Corpse Fleet Recruiter
Corpse Fleet Recruiter.publicNotes:
Corpse Fleet recruiters are powerful necromancers capable of maintaining control of mindless undead, creating new undead, and turning their magic against the living.

The Corpse Fleet is an army made up of undead supremacists who refuse to bow to the will of the living. Founded by defectors from the Eoxian navy, the Corpse Fleet aims to shatter Pact Worlds unity and liberate Eox from the influence of the living and those bone sages who sided with them. Unyielding and utterly ruthless, the Corpse Fleet deals in death and destruction, feeding on the living and exploiting the dead.

weapon->Integrated Shock Pad.name: Integrated Shock Pad
weapon->Integrated Shock Pad.description:
Upgrades: 1

This flexible nanocarbon circuit can be installed as an upgrade into gloves, kneepads, or similar appendage protectors to emit a powerful electric shock when forcefully applied to a target.

weapon->Integrated Zero Pistol.name: Integrated Zero Pistol
weapon->Integrated Zero Pistol.description:
Upgrades: 1

Zero pistols use transparent canisters of supercooled liquid as ammunition.

action->Seize Control.name: Seize Control
action->Seize Control.description: 20 feet. Mindless undead that begin their turn in the area must attempt a @Check[will|dc:22|options:area-effect] save; on a failure, the Corpse Fleet recruiter seizes control of that undead. It gains the minion trait.

action->Corpse Bomb.name: Corpse Bomb
action->Corpse Bomb.description: The Corpse Fleet recruiter detonates one mindless undead minion under their control, causing it to explode in a @Template[burst|distance:15]{15-foot-radius burst}, dealing @Damage[4d6[slashing],4d6[void]|options:area-damage]{4d6 slashing damage and 4d6 void damage} to creatures in the area (@Check[reflex|dc:25|basic|options:area-effect] save).

action->Efficient Commands.name: Efficient Commands
action->Efficient Commands.description: The Corpse Fleet recruiter Sustains each spell they cast to create minions and Commands any number of their minions.

action->Rapid Recruitment.name: Rapid Recruitment
action->Rapid Recruitment.description:
Frequency once per day

Requirements A formerly living creature that died within the last round is within 10 feet

Effect The Corpse Fleet recruiter immediately performs the @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.spells.Item.c3b6LdLlQDPngNIb]{Create Undead} ritual, as if it were a spell with a casting time of 2 actions and the Corpse Fleet recruiter rolled a critical success on the ritual.

Corzad.name: Corzad
Corzad.publicNotes:
Packs of wolflike corzads act as the eyes and mouths of the corzadai fungal colony.

Corzadais spawned from the broken remains of Aucturn. Explosively launched into space, these fungal colonies are held together by mysterious forces. Their strange fruiting bodies have taken on numerous shapes, of which two have been more commonly seen in the Pact Worlds than others: corzads and corzadors.

action->Fungal Symbiosis.name: Fungal Symbiosis
action->Fungal Symbiosis.description: A corzad's Strikes deal an extra 1d4 damage to targets within 20 feet of at least two of the corzad's allies.

action->Spore Tide.name: Spore Tide
action->Spore Tide.description: The corzad dissolves into a mass of slimy spores and Strides twice, ignoring difficult terrain and other creatures. This movement doesn't trigger reactions. Any creature in the corzad's path must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:15|options:area-effect,inflicts:sickened] save or become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}. The corzad re-forms at the end of this movement.

Corzador.name: Corzador
Corzador.publicNotes:
Vaguely humanoid corzadors herd corzad packs as they carry out their grim tasks.

Corzadais spawned from the broken remains of Aucturn. Explosively launched into space, these fungal colonies are held together by mysterious forces. Their strange fruiting bodies have taken on numerous shapes, of which two have been more commonly seen in the Pact Worlds than others: corzads and corzadors.

action->Follicle Germination.name: Follicle Germination
action->Follicle Germination.description:
Hundreds of wirelike nerve endings erupt from the corzador's head in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30]. Each non-corzadai in the area must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:18|options:area-effect] save or be instantly observed by all corzadais within 100 feet. Corzadais in the area gain a +1 circumstance bonus to attack and damage rolls against the detected creatures as long as the targets remain in the emanation. The corzador's emanation remains in effect until it takes a move action to leave its current space.

@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.Bw1u0YIbG0ZV1CIR]{Effect: Follicle Germination}

action->Shrieking Utricle.name: Shrieking Utricle
action->Shrieking Utricle.description:
Trigger A non-corzadai creature moves within the corzador's active Follicle Germination

Effect The corzador emits a high-pitched shriek. All non-corzadai creatures within the corzador's Follicle Emanation take @Damage[2d8[sonic]|options:area-damage] damage with a @Check[fortitude|dc:18|basic|options:area-effect] save.

Cosmic Dragon (Adult).name: Cosmic Dragon (Adult)
Cosmic Dragon (Adult).publicNotes: These majestic dragons embody the stellar forces that underly and balance all that exists in the universe. Cosmic dragons are wise, social, and patient beings, accepting of all whom they come across; they see all creatures as equal components of the universe and are just as likely to be found discussing astrophysics in the company of scholars as they are to be found lamenting the twists and turns of fate in the company of the downtrodden. Most cosmic dragons can change their shape, though they usually only do so to make other creatures comfortable. They detest deception and always introduce themselves as dragons even while in another form.

action->+2 status to all saves vs. divin.name: +2 status to all saves vs. divine

action->Attunement Aura.name: Attunement Aura
action->Attunement Aura.description: 60 feet. All allied creatures in the aura gain a +5-foot status bonus to Speeds (if the dragon is photon-attuned), or all enemies take a –5-foot status penalty to Speeds (if the dragon is graviton-attuned).

action->Cosmic Attunement.name: Cosmic Attunement
action->Cosmic Attunement.description:
The cosmic dragon is always attuned to an underlying stellar force: either photons or gravitons. They can swap attunement as a free action once at the start of their turn in combat and is otherwise attuned to whichever force they choose at any time outside of combat. The dragon's melee Strikes deal an additional @Damage[2d6[fire]] damage while they're photon-attuned and an additional @Damage[1d6[bludgeoning]] damage plus Knockdown while they're graviton-attuned. The damage of their cosmic blast Strike is likewise determined by their current attunement, as are the effects of some of their other abilities. The dragon can choose to exclude any creatures from any effect of the aura or action that uses the aura.

The dragon can always sense the distance and direction to the nearest Drift beacon and to the Starstone on Absalom Station.

action->Draconic Frenzy.name: Draconic Frenzy
action->Draconic Frenzy.description: The dragon makes two claw Strikes and one tail Strike in any order.

action->Draconic Momentum.name: Draconic Momentum
action->Draconic Momentum.description: The dragon recharges their Stellar Breath whenever they score a critical hit with a Strike.

action->Stellar Breath.name: Stellar Breath
action->Stellar Breath.description: The dragon unleashes divine power like that from the core of a star or black hole, dealing @Damage[10d10[spirit]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:cone|distance:40] (@Check[will|dc:34|basic] save). The dragon can't use Stellar Breath for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Stellar Mote.name: Stellar Mote
action->Stellar Mote.description: The dragon conjures a mote of stellar energy that shares their current attunement. They direct the mote to a square within 90 feet. While the mote is deployed, the dragon's attunement aura also emanates from that square, with the same emanation radius. The dragon can Sustain to move the mote up to 90 feet or to recall the mote from any distance. The mote is made of cosmic energy, doesn't occupy a space, and can't be targeted or destroyed by any effect.

action->Stellar Pulse.name: Stellar Pulse
action->Stellar Pulse.description:
The dragon imposes an effect on creatures within their attunement aura. The effect is based on the dragon's current attunement. The dragon can't use Stellar Pulse again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Stellar Pulse]]{1d4 rounds}.

  • Graviton Each creature must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:34] save or be @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} for 1 round.

  • Photon Each creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened} and can use the extra action only to Stride or Strike.

Crest-Eater.name: Crest-Eater
Crest-Eater.publicNotes:
Crest-eaters are large four-legged beasts with traits of both reptiles and mammals. Originating from the distant world of Kasath, they've spread throughout the cosmos, accompanying numerous kasathas and even having a small enclave aboard the Idari worldship in the Pact Worlds. A crest-eater is a predator known for consuming the bones of their prey. They use a highly corrosive acidic venom that eats through minerals with ease. Their name comes from their history of tracking down kasathas and cracking open their prey's elongated skulls to feed on the "bony crests" within. As crest-eaters consume bones and other substances, they produce large mineral protrusions across their bodies. Crest-eaters are social creatures and often form prides to hunt together or join with other nearby species if they're accepted—it's not uncommon to find a starship crew or local raider gang with one or more crest-eaters they've adopted. Tamers who have hunted with crest-eaters for generations craft a ceremonial cestus from their comrade's body after a crest-eater passes, a tradition still practiced to this day despite the high value and demand for crest-eater bones.

Most crest-eaters can grow as long as 14 feet and about 6 feet tall (not including their noticeable mineral protrusions). Thanks to their mineral-laden composition, they often weigh in excess of 1,000 pounds, somewhat hampering their mobility in environments that can't support their girth. Young and mature crest-eaters tend to stay together in small prides, though some act as solitary hunters in environments where food sources are scarce. Especially large males frequently become increasingly aggressive as they age, and they're often driven away by the rest of the pride for both their hostility and gluttonous appetites. If these solitary beasts survive long enough, they can become unpredictable and dangerous threats that attempt to establish territory and find food by attacking desert settlements. Many kasathan epics feature one or more brave warriors defending their village against an ancient male crest-eater. Whether dispatched by local legends or eventually dying off in secret, these oversized crest-eaters can leave behind a valuable cache of minerals for enterprising adventurers.

action->Bone Tracker.name: Bone Tracker
action->Bone Tracker.description: A crest-eater can use its scent as a precise sense at the listed range against creatures that have taken damage from crest-eater venom in the past hour.

action->Crest-Eater Venom.name: Crest-Eater Venom
action->Crest-Eater Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:21]

Max Duration 4 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d6[acid]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[1d8[acid]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[1d10[acid]] damage, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}, and enfeebled 2 (1 round)

action->Scree Strider.name: Scree Strider
action->Scree Strider.description: Crest-eaters ignore difficult terrain caused by rubble, sand, and uneven ground made of earth and stone.

survival.label: to Track creatures afflicted by crest-eater venom

Crest-Eater Necrograft Zombie.name: Crest-Eater Necrograft Zombie
Crest-Eater Necrograft Zombie.publicNotes:
Necrograft zombies are animated by necrografts created from the body parts and internal organs of undead creatures. On Eox, it's common to augment animals and beasts with necrografts to ensure their survival on the dead planet. After death, many of these creatures return as true undead to continue serving their creators.

Technological zombies are created when a dead creature is reanimated (or otherwise kept moving) by an internal or integrated technological item—usually an augmentation. Despite the vast differences in form and hardware between different tech zombies, they do have similarities—they're mindless undead driven to harm the living, with technological components and weaknesses that can be leveraged.

action->Necrograft.name: Necrograft
action->Necrograft.description: A necrograft zombie's necrografts can be disabled for 1 hour by a creature that succeeds at a @Check[religion|dc:22] check. Attempting to do so can typically be done only while within reach of the zombie, and is a 2-action activity that has the manipulate trait. A necrograft zombie with disabled necrografts is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use any reactions.

action->Rapid Decomposition.name: Rapid Decomposition
action->Rapid Decomposition.description:
A necrograft zombie must use this reaction unless its necrograft is disabled

Trigger The zombie is reduced to 0 Hit Points

Effect The zombie rapidly decomposes into a heap of rotting biomass, dealing @Damage[2d8[poison],2d8[void]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:15] (@Check[reflex|dc:22|basic|options:area-effect] save) and making that area hazardous terrain for 1 minute (@Damage[1d4[void]|options:area-damage] damage). This ability destroys any organic items on the zombie (including necrografts).

action->Scree Strider.name: Scree Strider
action->Scree Strider.description: The crest-eater necrograft zombie ignores difficult terrain caused by rubble, sand, and uneven ground made of earth and stone.

Cyanoscum.name: Cyanoscum
Cyanoscum.publicNotes:
While these wood elementals bear the adorable appearance of a rodent, their main bodies are unfortunately composed of toxin-producing algae. Cyanoscums thrive in any warm, wet environment. Cyanoscum blooms are easy to spot; from a distance, they look like blue-green meadows floating atop still waters or clusters of fuzzy, teal moss clinging to plants and rocks. An explorer moved by this majestic sight might venture too close to the water's edge or reach out to touch the soft, resplendent moss—inviting contact with these beautiful but poisonous creatures.

Elementals are energetic intrusions from the primal planes of existence. They take many forms, from mindless eddies in the wind or water to complex entities capable of wielding primal magic. The advent of space travel and the progress of technology have allowed even more living embodiments of the elements to manifest in the Universe.

Natural events like wildfires, solar storms, and floods can unleash hordes of unruly elementals on a planet or into a region of space. Sometimes, a gathering of powerful elementals causes a natural disaster on an epic scale, like an off-the-charts solar flare that fries a planet's power grid or a ceaseless storm swirling in a gas giant's atmosphere.

action->Water Sense.name: Water Sense
action->Water Sense.description: A cyanoscum can sense the presence of water within 60 feet as an imprecise sense.

action->Squish.name: Squish
action->Squish.description: A cyanoscum can Squeeze through spaces that aren't airtight at its Speed per round.

action->Toxic Touch.name: Toxic Touch
action->Toxic Touch.description: Any creature whose skin comes in direct contact with the cyanoscum, such as during an unarmed Strike, must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:13] save or take @Damage[1d4[poison]] damage.

Cyanoscum blooms are easy to spot; from a distance, they look like blue-green meadows floating atop still waters or clusters of fuzzy, teal moss clinging to plants and rocks. An explorer moved by this majestic sight might venture too close to the water's edge or reach out to touch the soft, resplendent moss—inviting contact with these beautiful but poisonous creatures.

Elementals are energetic intrusions from the primal planes of existence. They take many forms, from mindless eddies in the wind or water to complex entities capable of wielding primal magic. The advent of space travel and the progress of technology have allowed even more living embodiments of the elements to manifest in the Universe.

Natural events like wildfires, solar storms, and floods can unleash hordes of unruly elementals on a planet or into a region of space. Sometimes, a gathering of powerful elementals causes a natural disaster on an epic scale, like an off-the-charts solar flare that fries a planet's power grid or a ceaseless storm swirling in a gas giant's atmosphere.

action->Water Sense.name: Water Sense
action->Water Sense.description: A cyanoscum can sense the presence of water within 60 feet as an imprecise sense.

action->Toxic Exposure.name: Toxic Exposure
action->Toxic Exposure.description: Creatures inside the cyanoscum bloom's space are exposed to cyanoscum toxin. A creature can't reduce the poison below stage 1 while it shares a space with the cyanoscum bloom.

action->Cyanoscum Toxin.name: Cyanoscum Toxin
action->Cyanoscum Toxin.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:18]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d4[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[1d8[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} (1 round)

action->Frenzied Scratching.name: Frenzied Scratching
action->Frenzied Scratching.description: Each enemy in the cyanoscum bloom's space takes @Damage[3d6[piercing]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save).

action->Squish.name: Squish
action->Squish.description: A cyanoscum bloom can Squeeze through spaces that aren't airtight at half its Speed per round.

Cybernetic Zombie.name: Cybernetic Zombie
Cybernetic Zombie.publicNotes:
The most common form of tech zombie is the cybernetic zombie, but tech zombies can also arise through other types of technologies, including nanites.

Technological zombies are created when a dead creature is reanimated (or otherwise kept moving) by an internal or integrated technological item—usually an augmentation. Despite the vast differences in form and hardware between different tech zombies, they do have similarities—they're mindless undead driven to harm the living, with technological components and weaknesses that can be leveraged.

weapon->Integrated Commercial Laser Pist.name: Integrated Commercial Laser Pistol
weapon->Integrated Commercial Laser Pist.description:
Upgrades: 1

This compact pistol is the most popular sidearm in the Pact Worlds thanks to its reliability, durability, and affordability. Most common laser pistols have a lightweight polycarbon body ending in a long, slim barrel.

action->Cybernetics.name: Cybernetics
action->Cybernetics.description: A cybernetic zombie's cybernetics can be disabled for 1 hour by a creature that succeeds at a DC 15 check to [[/act disable-device dc=15]] or Disable a System. Attempting to do so can typically be done only while within reach of the zombie and is a 2-action activity that has the manipulate trait. The cybernetics are also disabled for 1 hour if the zombie takes any electricity damage. A cybernetic zombie with disabled cybernetics is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use any reactions.

action->Self-Destruct.name: Self-Destruct
action->Self-Destruct.description:
A cybernetic zombie must use this reaction unless its cybernetics are disabled

Trigger The cybernetic zombie is reduced to 0 Hit Points

Effect The zombie's damaged cybernetics explode, dealing @Damage[1d8[electricity]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] (@Check[reflex|dc:15|basic] save). This ability destroys the zombie's integrated items and any tech items on the zombie of 1st level or lower.

Daipex.name: Daipex
Daipex.publicNotes:
Daipexes are formed from souls of sinful mortals whose lives were consumed by rage and indiscriminate violence. Their hulking figures consist primarily of a pair of chain guns merged into the flesh of their large arms. By comparison, their legs are disproportionately small and incapable of bracing completely against the force of their attacks. Daipexes only use their legs when necessary and otherwise rely on their arms to move about to reduce the strain on their leg muscles.

Daipexes carry about the entrails of their prey, sometimes dangling loops of intestines from their necks or simply dragging it along the ground. They feed these organs into their arms and, by flexing their muscles there, condense the putrid flesh into ammunition that can then be fired directly from their bodies. While they often have enough ammunition to fire off their arm weapons for hours, in the rare instances that they run out of ammunition mid-combat, they either retrieve more from corpses on the battlefield or sacrifice their own flesh in the name of victory.

All mortal creatures have souls that are usually judged in the Boneyard after their demise. The souls of individuals who lived sinful lives—usually by hurting others or acting selfishly—are sent to the Outer Rifts, where they eventually coalesce into demons. These fiends care for nothing but the corruption of mortal life to ensure that the ranks of their fellow demons never wane.

action->Arm Cannon.name: Arm Cannon
action->Arm Cannon.description: A daipex's powerful arms can be fused into one or more cannons. These arm cannons also can't be Disarmed or Released. The daipex takes a –4 circumstance penalty to any action that requires fine motor control.

action->Char Miasma.name: Char Miasma
action->Char Miasma.description: 5 feet. The heat from a daipex's arm cannons burns the intestines fed into the grafted weapons as ammunition. A creature that enters or begins its turn in the aura must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:23] save or be @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

action->Misfire Vulnerability.name: Misfire Vulnerability
action->Misfire Vulnerability.description: A daipex is full of unceasing rage and despises it when they can't deal damage. When a daipex critically fails a Strike or when a creature critically succeeds at its save against Hail of Bullets, the daipex takes @Damage[3d6[mental]] damage.

action->Hail of Bullets.name: Hail of Bullets
action->Hail of Bullets.description: The daipex fires a @Template[type:cone|distance:30] of bullets, dealing @Damage[6d10[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:26|basic] save) to creatures in the area. The daipex is pushed 10 feet in the opposite direction and can't use Hail of Bullets again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Hail of Bullets]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Rain of Bullets.name: Rain of Bullets
action->Rain of Bullets.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The daipex makes two arm cannon Strikes against a single target. The daipex's multiple attack penalty is applied normally. If both Strikes hit, combine their damage for the purpose of resistances and weaknesses.

action->Recoil.name: Recoil
action->Recoil.description: A daipex's relatively small legs can't withstand their arm cannon's kickback. When a daipex makes an arm cannon Strike, they're pushed 5 feet in the opposite direction of the Strike's target. The daipex can take a –2 circumstance penalty to the Strike to avoid this forced movement.

Deh-Nolo.name: Deh-Nolo
Deh-Nolo.publicNotes:
Deh-nolos are the Dominion's foremost engineers, seamlessly and deviously merging technology and biological systems to create any device imaginable, from sinister weapons to massive starships to shipmind oozes. These creations are grown, not built, but they're neither cybernetics nor biotech—rather, something in between. Deh-nolos seek to understand all technology they encounter, and they believe it's their right to consume the brain of anyone they think might help them better understand an unfamiliar device. Then again, deh-nolos have no qualms about consuming brains for nearly any reason, seeing all forms of life outside the Dominion as lesser beings.

While mostly organic, deh-nolos can concentrate their shimmering liquid metal secretions into foul crystals that they can use as projectiles or mechanical components for their twisted inventions. A casual onlooker might assume these creations are biotechnological in nature, as they often look like atrophied organs and mutated body parts held together by seemingly crude or incomplete circuitry. Those who attempt to incorporate deh-nolo technology into their bodies as augmentations typically experience terrible pain and grisly deaths, even if they somehow manage to isolate or drain the toxins naturally produced by a deh-nolo's alien flesh. Even less intrusive experiments with deh-nolo technology are unpredictable and dangerous, and the results of a "successful" outcome are disturbing at best.
Deh-Nolo.languagesDetails: Any four others (see brain sacs), Telepathy 120 feet

action->Thoughtsense.name: Thoughtsense
action->Thoughtsense.description:
The deh-nolo senses a creature's mental essence as a precise sense with the listed range; they can't sense mindless creatures with thoughtsense.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Thoughtsense]

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Brain Loss.name: Brain Loss
action->Brain Loss.description: If a deh-nolo takes 60 damage from a critical hit or takes 50 mental damage, they must succeed at a DC 34 save (@Check[fortitude|dc:34] for critical damage or @Check[will|dc:34] for mental damage) or one of their brain sacs is destroyed.

action->Brain Sacs.name: Brain Sacs
action->Brain Sacs.description: A deh-nolo snatcher has four brain sacs that they use to store harvested brains. A deh-nolo knows one additional language for each brain they have stored in a brain sac, chosen from the languages that the creature knew when its brain was harvested. A deh-nolo without all four sacs full is stupefied with a value equal to the number of empty sacs.

action->Open Pustules.name: Open Pustules
action->Open Pustules.description: When the deh-nolo takes damage, pustules on their body burst, spraying foul poison. Each adjacent creature is exposed to dominion bile.

action->Dominion Bile.name: Dominion Bile
action->Dominion Bile.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:34]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[4d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[4d6[poison]] damage, enfeebled 1, and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[6d6[poison]] damage, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2}, and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2} (1 round)

Stage 4 death

action->Harvest Brain.name: Harvest Brain
action->Harvest Brain.description: The deh-nolo harvests the brain of a creature that's been dead for no more than 1 minute. They can then use an Interact action to secure the brain in one of their empty brain sacs.

Demolition-Class Assassin Robot.name: Demolition-Class Assassin Robot
Demolition-Class Assassin Robot.publicNotes:
Named for their tendency toward extreme violence and aggressiveness, demolition robots nevertheless start their mission with stealth being a priority. Outwardly, these robots conceal their true nature with an outer casing resembling that of industrial, civic, or even domestic robots and drones.

Once the target has been detected, all stealth flies out the window as these killer machines unfurl their weapons and sensory suite from hidden panels and rush toward the mark at full speed. With their encyclopedic data banks on the stress points and emergency release mechanisms of most doors, only the most solid barriers can hold them at bay for long.

In some societies, machines automate many processes. It only makes sense, then, that some would attempt to automate the act of murder. Most manufacturers would never admit to creating such designs, forcing wealthy figures to go through hidden channels to acquire units from secret facilities or unscrupulous manufacturers. Regardless of their origins, these robots can be programmed with a target and set loose, the owner assured that either their target will be dead or will be unable to prove who tried to kill them thanks to the unit's fried circuitry.

weapon->Integrated Breaching Gun.name: Integrated Breaching Gun
weapon->Integrated Breaching Gun.description:
Upgrades: 1

This snub-nosed scattergun is commonly used to blast through doors and walls. Smaller than a reaction breacher, this scattergun is infamous for its mighty recoil.

equipment->Integrated tools appropriate.name: Integrated tools appropriate for disguise shell

action->Burn Protocol.name: Burn Protocol
action->Burn Protocol.description: The circuitry of an assassin robot self-destructs upon the robot's destruction, making tracing its owner extremely difficult. Add 10 to the DC of a Computers check to recover data from a destroyed assassin robot.

action->Breaching Rush.name: Breaching Rush
action->Breaching Rush.description: The demolition-class assassin robot attempts to close the distance between it and its target, removing all obstacles in its way. The robot makes a ranged Strike with its breaching gun against the [[/act force-open]] DC of a door or other obstacle. If successful, the obstacle gains the broken condition. The robot then Strides twice toward (and even through) the obstacle, but if the obstacle still bars the robot's movement, it stops adjacent to the obstacle and attempts an Athletics check to Force Open the obstacle with a +4 circumstance bonus.

action->Disguise Shell.name: Disguise Shell
action->Disguise Shell.description: The demolition-class assassin robot enters or leaves its disguised form. While in its disguised form, it loses the ability to make Strikes or use its Breaching Rush ability, but it becomes indistinguishable from a noncombatant robot or drone model that it's based on; it gets an automatic result of 33 on Deception checks and DCs to pass as a robot of that model. Damage to the robot can prevent this disguise from being effective at the GM's discretion.

action->Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
action->Sneak Attack.description: The demolition-class assassin robot's Strikes deal an additional 2d6 precision damage to @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.

action->Target Tracking.name: Target Tracking
action->Target Tracking.description: The demolition-class assassin robot establishes a target lock on a creature it can see within 120 feet. The creature can't become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} against the robot or [[/act create-a-diversion]] against the robot. This ability lasts until the robot loses line of sight with the target or the target otherwise becomes hidden.

Deprimogon.name: Deprimogon
Deprimogon.publicNotes:
Deprimogons stalk hidden tunnels, shadowed alleys, and looming towers of settlements whose governments have made infernal pacts as they silently monitor citizens for any signs of sedition. Agitators or freedom fighters are harassed or chased down and trapped by these devils before disappearing forever. Deprimogons hide their faces behind sleek metallic masks that suppress their own emotions, blocking out any pleas, threats, or bargaining that might dissuade them from their mission. Deprimogons delight in summoning diabolic creatures from eras long forgotten to torment their prisoners.

In the shadows of space stations, halls of courtrooms, and offices of corporations, devils tempt mortals with promises of power and lay the groundwork for their conquest. A devil's pacts can vary from elaborate contracts to quick promises, but they all end the same way: a mortal soul condemned, and Hell's forces bolstered. From the open rule of Malfane, the unseen control of Embroi, and hidden pacts with souls across the galaxy, devils continue their relentless work to spread tyranny and force the universe to resemble the hellish bureaucracy of their home.

weapon->Dueling Sword.name: Dueling Sword
weapon->Dueling Sword.description:
Upgrades: 1

Coming in a variety of styles, these traditional and time-tested weapons have been honed with advanced smithing techniques and modern materials.

action->Masked Emotions.name: Masked Emotions
action->Masked Emotions.description: The deprimogon loses their immunity to emotion and mental effects if they aren't wearing a mask. In addition, an unmasked silencer devil uses the outcome one degree of success worse than they roll on saving throws against mental effects. A deprimogon's mask can be Disarmed as if it were a held item.

action->Evoke Paranoia.name: Evoke Paranoia
action->Evoke Paranoia.description:
The deprimogon infuses their weapons with paranoia and mistrust, instilling doubt in their victims with every attack. A creature damaged by a deprimogon's Strikes must attempt a @Check[will|dc:27] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and temporarily immune to the deprimogon's evoke paranoia for 1 minute.

Success The creature is unaffected and temporarily immune to the deprimogon's evoke paranoia for 1 round.

Failure Until the beginning of the deprimogon's next turn, the creature believes everyone it sees is a potential threat. It becomes unfriendly to all creatures to which it wasn't already hostile, even those who were previously allies. It treats no one as an ally.

Critical Failure As failure, except the target believes that everyone it sees is a mortal enemy. It uses its reactions and free actions against everyone, regardless of whether they were previously its allies, as determined by the GM. It otherwise acts as rationally as it normally does and likely prefers to attack creatures that are actively attacking or hindering it over those leaving it alone.

action->Infernal Disgrace.name: Infernal Disgrace
action->Infernal Disgrace.description: The deprimogon's Strikes count as magical and unholy.

action->Silent Prison.name: Silent Prison
action->Silent Prison.description: The deprimogon casts a 6th-rank @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.spells.Item.7Iela4GgVeO3LfAo]{Wall of Force} that dampens sound. Any creature that moves and begins its turn adjacent to the wall must attempt a @Check[will|dc:27] save. On a failure, the creature can't speak and can't use any actions and effects with the sonic or auditory traits while adjacent to the wall; this also prevents the creature from casting spells, with the exception of subtle spells.

Diaspora Worm.name: Diaspora Worm
Diaspora Worm.publicNotes:
Resembling fanged eels with manes of tendrils instead of eyes, diaspora worms originally ruled the inky depths of the ocean that later became the icy planetoid Nisis. The worms' hostility toward trespassers and lack of observable speech lead most people to consider them mere beasts, but xenobiologists know the worms' tendrils respond to electromagnetic waves, which they manipulate to see, communicate, and interact with their surroundings. Bioelectric radiation from coral samples recovered from the worms' home reef documents millennia of worm culture and history from even before the Diaspora's formation.

Juvenile members of this species are sleek, sinuous, and nimble despite their size. Their electromagnetic manipulation lets them briefly change the molecular structure of water, making it murky like their original depths. Young worms tend to commit brazen attacks, requiring decades of experience to value more complex strategies.

"Space worm" is a nonscientific term for a xenobiologically complex clade of invertebrate animals and beasts that make their home in the vastness of space. Some, like the diaspora and dust worms, show signs of intelligence and are directly related to each other. Others, like the surnoch, evolved separately, with their origins completely unknown to science.

action->Electrocommunication.name: Electrocommunication
action->Electrocommunication.description: Diaspora worms communicate by shaping and reading electromagnetic fields. This functions like telepathy with creatures that share this ability.

action->Electromagnetic Sight.name: Electromagnetic Sight
action->Electromagnetic Sight.description: Diaspora worms sense their surroundings by reading electromagnetic fields, including disruptions caused by creatures or objects. This is a precise sense within the listed range. Intense fields, such as areas emitting radiation or auras of electricity, make creatures within them @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} to the diaspora worm.

action->Electromagnetic Blindness.name: Electromagnetic Blindness
action->Electromagnetic Blindness.description:
Diaspora worms that take electricity damage must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:23] save.

Critical Success The worm is unaffected.

Success The worm is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round.

Failure The worm is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The worm is blinded for 1 round, then dazzled for 1 round.

action->Darkwater Veil.name: Darkwater Veil
action->Darkwater Veil.description:
Requirements The diaspora worm is in water

Effect The worm alters the structure of water within a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10], forming light-absorbing nanotubes. This field moves with the worm and lasts for 1 minute. The emanation deactivates non-magical light sources and automatically attempts to counteract magical light (counteract rank 4, counteract modifier [[/r 1d20+17 #Counteract]]{+17}). This field also provides cover for creatures inside of it from those outside, and vice versa.

action->Tongue Grab.name: Tongue Grab
action->Tongue Grab.description: A creature hit by the diaspora worm's tongue becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}. A creature can sever the tongue with a Strike against AC 19 that deals at least @Damage[12[slashing]] damage. This prevents the worm from using its tongue Strike until it regrows its tongue, which takes 1 day.

action->Tongue Reel.name: Tongue Reel
action->Tongue Reel.description:
Requirements The diaspora worm has @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} a creature with its tongue

Effect The diaspora worm attempts to [[/act reposition]] the grabbed creature toward the worm. If the grabbed creature is brought to within 10 feet or less of the worm, the worm can attempt to Swallow Whole the creature.

Diaspora Worm Sage.name: Diaspora Worm Sage
Diaspora Worm Sage.publicNotes:
Diaspora worms that survive for centuries grow significantly in size, power, and intelligence. They mostly protect their ancestral home, preserving bioelectric coral records and directing the actions of younger worms

"Space worm" is a nonscientific term for a xenobiologically complex clade of invertebrate animals and beasts that make their home in the vastness of space. Some, like the diaspora and dust worms, show signs of intelligence and are directly related to each other. Others, like the surnoch, evolved separately, with their origins completely unknown to science.

action->Electrocommunication.name: Electrocommunication
action->Electrocommunication.description: Diaspora worms communicate by shaping and reading electromagnetic fields. This functions like telepathy with creatures that share this ability.

action->Electromagnetic Sight.name: Electromagnetic Sight
action->Electromagnetic Sight.description: Diaspora worms sense their surroundings by reading electromagnetic fields, including disruptions caused by creatures or objects. This is a precise sense within the listed range. Intense fields, such as areas emitting radiation or auras of electricity, make creatures within them @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} to the diaspora worm.

action->Electromagnetic Blindness.name: Electromagnetic Blindness
action->Electromagnetic Blindness.description:
Diaspora worms that take electricity damage must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:23] save.

Critical Success The worm is unaffected.

Success The worm is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round.

Failure The worm is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The worm is blinded for 1 round, then dazzled for 1 round.

action->Darkwater Veil.name: Darkwater Veil
action->Darkwater Veil.description:
Requirements The diaspora worm is in water

Effect The worm alters the structure of water within a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20], forming light-absorbing nanotubes. This field moves with the worm and lasts for 1 minute. The emanation deactivates non-magical light sources and automatically attempts to counteract magical light (counteract rank 9, counteract modifier [[/r 1d20+38 #Counteract]]{+38}). This field also provides cover for creatures inside of it from those outside, and vice versa.

action->Darkwater Vortex.name: Darkwater Vortex
action->Darkwater Vortex.description: The diaspora worm sage stirs up a 40-foot-tall cylinder of water with a 20-foot radius within 300 feet. If the area isn't already filled with water, this ability fails. The vortex buffets all creatures, dealing @Damage[5d10[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:35|basic] save). Creatures that fail the save are pulled 5 feet toward the center of the vortex (or 10 feet on a critical failure).

action->Electromagnetic Surge.name: Electromagnetic Surge
action->Electromagnetic Surge.description:
The diaspora worm sage emits a concentrated wave of electromagnetism in a @Template[type:cone|distance:50]. Each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:35] save. A creature with the tech trait uses the outcome one degree of success worse than the result of its roll.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and becomes immune to Electromagnetic Surge for 1 hour.

Success The creature's items with the tech trait become glitching 1 for 1 round.

Failure The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}, and its items with the tech trait become glitching 2 for 1 minute. A creature with the tech trait also gains this glitching condition.

Critical Failure The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} for 1 round, and its items with the tech trait become glitching 3 for 10 minutes. A creature with the tech trait also gains this glitching condition.

action->Tongue Grab.name: Tongue Grab
action->Tongue Grab.description: A creature hit by the diaspora worm's tongue becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}. A creature can sever the tongue with a Strike against AC 37 that deals at least @Damage[32[slashing]] damage. This prevents the worm from using its tongue Strike until it regrows its tongue, which takes 1 day.

action->Tongue Reel.name: Tongue Reel
action->Tongue Reel.description:
Requirements The diaspora worm has @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} a creature with its tongue

Effect The diaspora worm attempts to [[/act reposition]] the grabbed creature toward the worm. If the grabbed creature is brought to within 10 feet or less of the worm, the worm can attempt to Swallow Whole the creature.

Diatha.name: Diatha
Diatha.publicNotes:
Often called "boom bugs" or "exploding slugs," diathas are invertebrates that store nutrients as hydrocarbon chains rather than fat deposits. Threatened diathas secrete hormones that prime their energy stores to combust, detonating themselves to drive off or kill predators. Even if several diathas sacrifice themselves this way, their hive rarely suffers thanks to their rapid reproductive cycle.

Diathas are hardy scavengers that can convert almost any carbon-based molecules into energy.
