Originally, diathas consumed biowaste in underground warrens, but their appetite for hydrocarbon-based fuels and industrial runoff drew them into contact with modernized civilizations, where they quickly adapted to urban environments. Though some entrepreneurs try to use these creatures as an organic means of converting plastic waste into petrol products, most see diathas as vermin that do far more harm than good when allowed to propagate.

Diathas can easily stow away in the nooks and crannies of starships, and interstellar travelers often don't notice them until it's too late. Because they can digest almost any carbon-containing matter, diathas that colonize new worlds can adapt to a wide range of biomes and persist as a threat to native species for generations. Efforts to eradicate invasive diathas carry substantial risks to the exterminators and the environment they're trying to protect, as the explosive vermin use literal scorched earth tactics to protect their hives. To make matters worse, diathas are hermaphroditic and can grow new hives from a single organism if they have sufficient food sources to multiply. As a result, the Pact Worlds and Veskarium maintain strict quarantine measures for vessels suspected of carrying diatha infestations.

As diathas age, their stored internal gases allow them to become buoyant. These "elder" diathas instinctively take prominent roles as scouts and guards for other diathas. To create an elder diatha, apply the aerial and elite adjustments to a diatha, or increase its level using the guidelines from GM Core.

action->Detonate.name: Detonate
action->Detonate.description:
Trigger The diatha takes acid, electricity, fire, piercing, slashing, or sonic damage

Requirements The diatha has 5 or fewer Hit Points

Effect The diatha dies, its body combusting in a flash of flame. All creatures in a 5-foot-radius emanation take @Damage[1d6[fire]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:16|basic] save).

action->Hydrocarbon Slick.name: Hydrocarbon Slick
action->Hydrocarbon Slick.description:
If a diatha dies before it can detonate, its body rapidly decomposes into a slick of highly volatile hydrocarbons. Any effect that deals acid, electricity, or fire damage in an area that includes the square where the diatha died, or targets a creature in that square, causes a small explosion and consumes the slick.

All creatures in the square and in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:5] take @Damage[1d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:16|basic] save). The slick evaporates after 10 minutes if it isn't ignited.

action->Explosive Charge.name: Explosive Charge
action->Explosive Charge.description:
Requirements The diatha has 5 or fewer Hit Points

Effect The diatha Strides twice and makes a melee Strike at the end of that movement. After the Strike, the diatha uses Detonate.

Digital Ghost Vidgamer.name: Digital Ghost Vidgamer
Digital Ghost Vidgamer.publicNotes:
Some vidgamers are so terminally online that they can manifest as a digital ghost.

Digital ghosts are data constructs crafted from forgotten user accounts and metadata that are gathered and formatted into a simulacrum of the source user.

action->Techsense (Imprecise) 30 feet.name: Techsense (Imprecise) 30 feet
action->Techsense (Imprecise) 30 feet.description: A digital ghost senses creatures and items with the tech trait at the listed range.

action->Backup.name: Backup
action->Backup.description:
An offline copy of the digital ghost is stored in a device. When an active digital ghost is destroyed, it reforms after [[/gmr 2d4 #days]]{2d4 days} within the device that the copy is stored in, fully healed, but with no memory of what destroyed them. A digital ghost can be permanently removed from that device by attempting a @Check[computers|dc:24] check against the digital ghost's Will DC.

On a success, the copy of the digital ghost is purged from the device, and no new copies will be generated. On a critical success, any active copies are also purged.

action->Device Bound.name: Device Bound
action->Device Bound.description: A digital ghost can stray only a short distance from the device where they're stored. A typical limit is 120 feet.

action->Malware Infection.name: Malware Infection
action->Malware Infection.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The digital ghost attempts to infect an item with the tech trait being held or used by a creature within 30 feet. The bearer can attempt a @Check[will|dc:21] save.

Critical Success The item is unaffected, and the digital ghost can't use Malware Infection for 1 week.

Success The item is unaffected.

Failure The item becomes glitching 2.

Critical Failure The item becomes glitching 2, and an offline digital ghost based on the bearer is created on the device in [[/gmr 2d4 #days]]{2d4 days}.

action->Virtual Arms.name: Virtual Arms
action->Virtual Arms.description: A digital ghost's weapons deal mental damage, have the ghost killer upgrade, and disappear if dropped.

Draiclipsed.name: Draiclipsed
Draiclipsed.publicNotes:
Draiclipsed are the undead heralds of the Insatiable Eclipse, an ancient and terrifying tzitzimitl warlord buried when the Blackmoon fell on Eox and recently awakened by the Newborn. The Insatiable Eclipse amasses its forces, including legions of draiclipsed, to retake Eox, a world he feels has fallen to decadence and frivolity, whose disgraceful leaders have made the blasphemous decision to ally with the living.

Draiclipsed are canny skeletal undead whose pitch-black bones absorb light, allowing them to cast deep shadows. They can also consume magical light, using the absorbed photons to obscure their form before unleashing it in a blast of electromagnetic energy. Utterly loyal to their creator and liege, draiclipsed are trained for open warfare and even more dangerous when fighting alongside one another.

weapon->Bone Scepter.name: Bone Scepter
weapon->Bone Scepter.description:
Upgrades: 1

This engraved club of solid bone is tempered using material from the void that can drain life energy.

action->Infrared Vision.name: Infrared Vision
action->Infrared Vision.description: A draiclipsed can detect infrared radiation (such as that given off by warm-blooded creatures) as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

action->Eclipse Shroud.name: Eclipse Shroud
action->Eclipse Shroud.description: 15 feet. A draiclipsed absorbs light and is perpetually surrounded by shifting shadows and lengthening darkness. Light in the area decreases by one step (for example, bright light becomes dim light).

action->Consume Light.name: Consume Light
action->Consume Light.description: The draiclipsed opens their mouth and sucks in a magical light, consuming it to fuel their own powers. The draiclipsed attempts a counteract check against one magical light effect within 60 feet ([[/r 1d20+15 #Counteract]]{+15} counteract modifier). If successful, the draiclipsed becomes ringed in diffuse light, becoming photonic for the next 24 hours. While a draiclipsed is photonic, they're @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}.

action->Cull the Betrayers.name: Cull the Betrayers
action->Cull the Betrayers.description: Whenever a draiclipsed would deal void damage to an undead or other creature with void healing, that void damage becomes cold damage instead.

action->Darkness Falls.name: Darkness Falls
action->Darkness Falls.description:
Requirements The draiclipsed is photonic

Effect The draiclipsed releases the light they've consumed in a blast of corrupted electromagnetic energy, dealing 3d8 electricity and @Damage[3d8[void]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:cone|distance:30] (@Check[reflex|dc:24|basic] save). The draiclipsed is no longer photonic.

action->Gathering Darkness.name: Gathering Darkness
action->Gathering Darkness.description: If at least one other draiclipsed is within the draiclipsed's eclipse shroud, the draiclipsed's Strikes deal an additional @Damage[1d8[void]] damage.

Dread Empathnid.name: Dread Empathnid
Dread Empathnid.publicNotes:
Dread empathnids are deadly hunters native to jungle planets. They thrive on populated worlds, and their preferred prey are intelligent humanoids. Drawn to negative emotions, dread empathnids absorb the terror of their dying victims and infuse their webbing with these horrific experiences.

Empathnids have tremendous empathy for other creatures. The fact that the 8-inch spidery creatures come in a variety of colors and have a lifesaving venom likely explains why they're frequently used as companions or pets across the Pact Worlds.

action->Emotionsense.name: Emotionsense
action->Emotionsense.description: This is a precise sense against creatures under an emotion effect or in the grips of overwhelming emotions (at the GM's discretion). Against other creatures, this is an imprecise sense. Creatures immune to emotion or mental effects or under the effects of a calm spell are undetectable by emotionsense.

action->Dread Venom.name: Dread Venom
action->Dread Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:18]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d6[mental]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 2d6 mental and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 As stage 2, plus @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed 1} (1 round)

action->Mental Mire.name: Mental Mire
action->Mental Mire.description: A non-flying creature damaged by the dread empathnid's psychic web Strike or psychic burst is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized}, stuck to the ground or nearest adjacent surface until it [[/act escape dc=18]]{Escapes}. A flying creature must instead succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:18] save or fall 20 feet (or 40 feet on a critical failure).

Dreamer.name: Dreamer
Dreamer.publicNotes:
Dancing between Liavara's peach-colored clouds are the Dreamers, the psychically gifted cousins of barathus. Not native to Liavara, the Dreamers were originally barathu explorers. They arrived by sailing one of the first living oma-ships long before the Gap. What exactly transformed them is still unknown to this day, though barathus as a people have been extremely protective of their prophetic cousins ever since.

The Dreamers lack barathus' ability to combine consciousnesses as well as their collectivist culture. That said, the Dreamers often dance through the skies of Liavara in flotillas together. To most of the Pact Worlds, they're a curiosity. To barathus, they're charges to be protected. The Dreamers themselves seem unconcerned with any such attention, giving neither care nor notice as to what's going on around them.

action->Atavistic Rage.name: Atavistic Rage
action->Atavistic Rage.description:
Trigger The Dreamer is reduced to half or less than half their total Hit Points

Effect The injured Dreamer erupts into a terrifying state of psychic fury, requiring all non-Dreamers in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] to attempt a @Check[will|dc:24] save. The Dreamer gains a +2 status bonus to attack and damage rolls for 1 minute but can't use their innate spells. After they stop raging, a Dreamer can't enter an Atavistic Rage again for 1 minute.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}.

Critical Failure The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 3} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D]{Fleeing} for 1 round.

action->Sluggish Mind.name: Sluggish Mind
action->Sluggish Mind.description: Any creature that uses an emotion or mental effect on a Dreamer must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:24] save or become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for the next [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds} as fragments of prophetic songs fill its mind.

action->Synesthetic Shock.name: Synesthetic Shock
action->Synesthetic Shock.description:
Any creature struck by a Dreamer's tentacle must attempt a @Check[will|dc:24] save to resist a wave of sensory overstimulation. The creature is then temporarily immune to all synesthetic shocks for 1 minute.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is suppressed and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} until the end of its next turn.

Failure As success, but the creature is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} until the end of its next turn.

Critical Failure As failure, but with a duration of 2 rounds, and the creature is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2}.

Dredgelit.name: Dredgelit
Dredgelit.publicNotes:
Dredgelits linger as flickers on the silver screen or neon silhouettes glimpsed backstage. They seethe in shortwave static and stare out from fading gravure tableaux. Dredgelits are the undead specters of deceased media megastars who haunt the venues of their former glories and crave the attention of forgetful fans.

Most dredgelits live in a fantasy version of their former lives, but once their delusions are shattered, a burning desire to recapture their lost fame drives them. At this point, they become unpredictable, and even the smallest perceived slight can lead to a murderous fit of rage.

Dredgelits embody their former stage personas. These decaying debutantes ensnare admirers into their eternal fan clubs, blissfully unaware of the life-draining consequences they have upon new admirers. Dredgelit seek sacrificial fans, luring in the unwary and draining their vitality to stay famous and fabulous forever.

action->Fan Club.name: Fan Club
action->Fan Club.description: A dredgelit maintains a bond with up to six other willing creatures. Creatures in the fan club always know the general distance and direction toward other bonded creatures, any conditions affecting them, and if they're @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.yZRUzMqrMmfLu0V1]{Dying}, or dead. Creatures in the fan club can always communicate telepathically while on the same plane of existence.

action->Phantasmal Fans.name: Phantasmal Fans
action->Phantasmal Fans.description: 20 feet. A rowdy spectral crowd always surrounds the dredgelit. The dredgelit has concealment against all creatures, and the crowd counts as difficult terrain.

action->Alluring Debut.name: Alluring Debut
action->Alluring Debut.description:
Frequency once every 10 minutes

Effect The dredgelit attempts a Performance check against the Will DC of a single creature within 30 feet, recreating an iconic show.

Critical Success The creature becomes part of their fan club for 24 hours, even if it's unwilling.

Success As critical success, but only for 1 hour.

Failure The creature is unaffected.

Critical Failure The creature is unaffected, and the dredgelit is so embarrassed by their failure to perform that they take @Damage[2d8[mental]] damage.

action->Parasocial Leech.name: Parasocial Leech
action->Parasocial Leech.description:
Frequency once per hour

Effect The dredgelit leeches vitality from a creature in their fan club. The dredgelit attempts a Performance check against the Will DC of the creature. The creature takes @Damage[6d6[void]] damage, and the dredgelit regains @Damage[10[healing]] Hit Points.

Critical Success The target takes double damage and is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} for 1 round.

Success The target takes full damage and is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} and immobilized for 1 round.

Failure The target is unaffected.

Critical Failure The target is unaffected. The dredgelit's abysmal performance results in them taking @Damage[2d8[mental]] damage instead of regaining Hit Points.

Driftdead Amalgam.name: Driftdead Amalgam
Driftdead Amalgam.publicNotes:
Amalgams are collections of driftdead that have fused together into one flesh ambulated by the shattered remnants of their component souls. The first amalgams formed spontaneously, but synthetic versions have been created in the Corpse Fleet's fleshforges and deployed as shock troops on the front lines of many battles.

Driftdead are created when a restless soul fuses with planar energies and reanimates its own corpse into a disturbing parody of life. Rarely, disturbed spirits snatched from elsewhere fuse together to inhabit a single dead body. Any death within the Drift might spawn a driftdead, but creatures that die in a frenzy of intense emotion are more likely to make the transition.

action->Dead Zone.name: Dead Zone
action->Dead Zone.description: 30 feet. The area around a driftdead amalgam bristles with chaotic space torn from the Drift. The area is zero gravity. A creature that enters or begin its turn in the area take @Damage[4d6[void]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:25|basic] save).

action->Torn from the Drift.name: Torn from the Drift
action->Torn from the Drift.description: While outside the Drift, the amalgam gains the incorporeal trait, becomes immune to precision damage, and gains resistance 10 to all damage (except force, ghost killer, or spirit; double resistance vs. non-magical).

action->Drift Ambush.name: Drift Ambush
action->Drift Ambush.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The driftdead teleports up to its Speed. If it's in the Drift, the distance a driftdead can teleport is doubled.

action->Ripping Blast.name: Ripping Blast
action->Ripping Blast.description: The amalgam's claws rip through reality in a @Template[type:cone|distance:30], dealing @Damage[8d6[slashing]|options:area-damage] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:25|basic] save. On a critical failure, a creature is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}. The amalgam can't use Ripping Blast again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Ripping Blast]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Voice of the Damned.name: Voice of the Damned
action->Voice of the Damned.description:
The amalgam calls out in a cacophony of voices from those slain in the Drift. Each living creature within 30 feet must attempt a @Check[will|dc:25] save.

Success The creature is temporarily immune to this amalgam's Voice of the Damned for 1 minute.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The creature is slowed 1 for 2 rounds.

Driftdead Crasher.name: Driftdead Crasher
Driftdead Crasher.publicNotes:
While most driftdead are spirits inhabiting their own corpses, some souls get ejected from their shells at death. These wraiths desperately struggle to return to their bodies, following their fragmented memories down aimless paths—woe to the living who cross them.

Crashers don't actually take their name from the Drift Crash that created many of them—they earned this name for their tendency to possess starships and reroute them into collision courses. If passengers trapped aboard a possessed ship don't survive, the victims might themselves twist into crashers instead of departing for the afterlife.

Driftdead are created when a restless soul fuses with planar energies and reanimates its own corpse into a disturbing parody of life. Rarely, disturbed spirits snatched from elsewhere fuse together to inhabit a single dead body. Any death within the Drift might spawn a driftdead, but creatures that die in a frenzy of intense emotion are more likely to make the transition.

action->Drift Ambush.name: Drift Ambush
action->Drift Ambush.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The driftdead teleports up to its Speed. If it's in the Drift, the distance a driftdead can teleport is doubled.

action->Inhabit Ship.name: Inhabit Ship
action->Inhabit Ship.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The driftdead crasher possesses a starship it's onboard or adjacent to. While inhabiting a ship in this manner, the crasher imposes a –2 circumstance penalty to all Piloting checks attempted by the ship's pilot. If the target ship is currently piloted by a creature, the pilot can attempt a @Check[will|dc:18] save to resist the possession.

action->Starship Possession.name: Starship Possession
action->Starship Possession.description: While Inhabiting a Ship, the driftdead crasher extends its senses. It has vision anywhere within the ship and gains all-around vision while within the ship.

action->Voice of the Lost.name: Voice of the Lost
action->Voice of the Lost.description:
The driftdead crasher calls out in the voice of someone who was lost in the Drift. Each living creature within 30 feet must attempt a @Check[will|dc:18] save.

Success The creature is temporarily immune to this driftdead's Voice of the Lost for 1 minute.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The creature is confused for 2 rounds and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} for 1 round.

Driftdead Returned.name: Driftdead Returned
Driftdead Returned.publicNotes:
The least of these wretched spirits are the returned. Appearing as twisted versions of the shapes they wore in life, the returned drag themselves through space with wriggling, clawed appendages or float with hideous grace. The returned haunt Drift beacons, castaway ships, and airless rocks.

Driftdead are created when a restless soul fuses with planar energies and reanimates its own corpse into a disturbing parody of life. Rarely, disturbed spirits snatched from elsewhere fuse together to inhabit a single dead body. Any death within the Drift might spawn a driftdead, but creatures that die in a frenzy of intense emotion are more likely to make the transition.

action->Drift Ambush.name: Drift Ambush
action->Drift Ambush.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The driftdead teleports up to its Speed. If it's in the Drift, the distance a driftdead can teleport is doubled.

Dust Manta.name: Dust Manta
Dust Manta.publicNotes: Deadly stealth predators, dust mantas lurk just below the surface on desert worlds across the Universe. Despite a wingspan averaging 10 feet across and weighing 1 ton, dust mantas are nearly undetectable in their native habitat thanks to their pebbly, sand-colored hide. Like a ray through water, they can sense nearby vibrations and glide through sand flats and dunes to ambush unfortunate prey. Their wicked stinger injects a lethal toxin that breaks down flesh and bone, dissolving it into sand so filter-feeding dust mantas can strain particles of food from the resulting suspension.

action->Sandsense.name: Sandsense
action->Sandsense.description: The dust manta can feel the slightest disturbance in nearby sand, granting it the ability to sense other creatures moving through or on top of the same body of sand that it's in. In addition, the dust manta ignores concealment from sandstorms, and they're immune to being @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} by sand or other grit.

action->Burrowing Charge.name: Burrowing Charge
action->Burrowing Charge.description: The dust manta surges through sand to attack unwary prey. It Burrows up to twice its burrow Speed, then Leaps vertically up to 25 feet high, making a stinger Strike against a creature at any point during the jump (this lets it attack a creature within 35 feet of the surface). After the [[/act leap]], the dust manta falls to the ground but takes no damage from the fall if it lands on sand.

action->Disappear in Dust.name: Disappear in Dust
action->Disappear in Dust.description: The dust manta's sand-colored hide allows it to [[/act hide]] in sand or any other fine, similarly colored substance even without cover or concealment.

action->Dust Manta Toxin.name: Dust Manta Toxin
action->Dust Manta Toxin.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:24]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[2d4[poison]] damage (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[3d4[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[3d4[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} (1 round)

Stage 4 @Damage[4d4[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 3} (1 round)

Stage 5 death, and the victim's body disintegrates into dust and can only be brought back via a wish ritual or similarly powerful magic

action->Spray Sand.name: Spray Sand
action->Spray Sand.description:
The dust manta sprays a cloud of sand from its gills in a @Template[type:burst|distance:30]. All creatures in the cloud become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}, and all creatures outside the cloud become concealed to creatures within it. The cloud lasts until the end of the dust manta's next turn. The dust manta can't use Spray Sand again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Spray Sand]]{1d4 rounds}. A non-dust manta creature that enters or starts its turn in the cloud must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:24] save.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 minute or until it spends an Interact action to wipe the dirt and grit from its eyes. Critical

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round, after which it's dazzled for 1 minute or until it spends an Interact action to wipe its eyes.

Dust Worm.name: Dust Worm
Dust Worm.publicNotes:
Diaspora worms mutated to navigate sandy or barren asteroid surfaces, and as a result, dust worms trade agility for bulk and can resist radiation. Their electromagnetic manipulation affects small bits of ferrous material, allowing them to telekinetically wield sand and small metallic shards as weapons or cloaks.

"Space worm" is a nonscientific term for a xenobiologically complex clade of invertebrate animals and beasts that make their home in the vastness of space. Some, like the diaspora and dust worms, show signs of intelligence and are directly related to each other. Others, like the surnoch, evolved separately, with their origins completely unknown to science.

action->Electrocommunication.name: Electrocommunication
action->Electrocommunication.description: Dust worms communicate by shaping and reading electromagnetic fields. This functions like telepathy with creatures that share this ability.

action->Electromagnetic Sight.name: Electromagnetic Sight
action->Electromagnetic Sight.description: Dust worms sense their surroundings by reading electromagnetic fields, including disruptions caused by creatures or objects. This is a precise sense within the listed range. Intense fields, such as areas emitting radiation or auras of electricity, make creatures within them @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} to the diaspora worm.

action->Electromagnetic Blindness.name: Electromagnetic Blindness
action->Electromagnetic Blindness.description:
Dust worms that take electricity damage must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:23] save.

Critical Success The worm is unaffected.

Success The worm is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round.

Failure The worm is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The worm is blinded for 1 round, then dazzled for 1 round.

action->Sandstorm Veil.name: Sandstorm Veil
action->Sandstorm Veil.description:
Requirements The dust worm is in a sandy or junk-ridden environment

Effect The dust worm uses its magnetic field to kick up a swirling shroud of sand and metallic bits in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] around itself. This shroud moves with the worm and lasts for [[/gmr 1d6 #rounds]]{1d6 rounds}. The shroud grants the worm resistance 6 to physical damage, and any creature that ends its turn within the area takes @Damage[2d6[slashing]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:24|basic] save).

action->Tongue Grab.name: Tongue Grab
action->Tongue Grab.description: A creature hit by the dust worm's tongue becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}. A creature can sever the tongue with a Strike against AC 21 that deals at least @Damage[14[slashing]] damage. This prevents the worm from using its tongue Strike until it regrows its tongue, which takes 1 day.

action->Tongue Reel.name: Tongue Reel
action->Tongue Reel.description:
Requirements The dust worm has @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} a creature with its tongue

Effect The diaspora worm attempts to [[/act reposition]] the grabbed creature toward the worm. If the grabbed creature is brought to within 10 feet or less of the worm, the worm can attempt to Swallow Whole the creature.

Dust Worm Augur.name: Dust Worm Augur
Dust Worm Augur.publicNotes:
Ancient diaspora dust worms become paragons of worm colonization, conquering asteroids and painstakingly terraforming them to support worm society.

"Space worm" is a nonscientific term for a xenobiologically complex clade of invertebrate animals and beasts that make their home in the vastness of space. Some, like the diaspora and dust worms, show signs of intelligence and are directly related to each other. Others, like the surnoch, evolved separately, with their origins completely unknown to science.

action->Electrocommunication.name: Electrocommunication
action->Electrocommunication.description: Dust worm augurs communicate by shaping and reading electromagnetic fields. This functions like telepathy with creatures that share this ability.

action->Electromagnetic Sight.name: Electromagnetic Sight
action->Electromagnetic Sight.description: Dust worm aurgurs sense their surroundings by reading electromagnetic fields, including disruptions caused by creatures or objects. This is a precise sense within the listed range. Intense fields, such as areas emitting radiation or auras of electricity, make creatures within them @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} to the diaspora worm.

action->Electromagnetic Blindness.name: Electromagnetic Blindness
action->Electromagnetic Blindness.description:
Dust worm aurgurs that take electricity damage must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:43] save.

Critical Success The worm is unaffected.

Success The worm is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round.

Failure The worm is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The worm is blinded for 1 round, then dazzled for 1 round.

action->Electromagnetic Surge.name: Electromagnetic Surge
action->Electromagnetic Surge.description:
The dust worm augur emits a concentrated wave of electromagnetism in a @Template[type:cone|distance:50]. Each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:40] save. A creature with the tech trait uses the outcome one degree of success worse than the result of its roll.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and becomes immune to Electromagnetic Surge for 1 hour.

Success The creature's items with the tech trait become glitching 1 for 1 round.

Failure The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}, and its items with the tech trait become glitching 2 for 1 minute. A creature with the tech trait also gains this glitching condition.

Critical Failure The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} for 1 round, and its items with the tech trait become glitching 3 for 10 minutes. A creature with the tech trait also gains this glitching condition.

action->Sandstorm Vortex.name: Sandstorm Vortex
action->Sandstorm Vortex.description:
The dust worm augur conjures a hurricane of sand and metallic bits in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:15]. This vortex moves with the worm and lasts for 1 minute. The vortex grants the worm resistance 11 to physical damage and makes any creature inside of it @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden} to creatures outside of it, and vice versa. Any creature that enters or starts its turn within the vortex must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:40] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes @Damage[3d10[slashing]|options:area-damage] damage.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[6d10[slashing]|options:area-damage] damage and takes a –15-foot status penalty to all Speeds while within the vortex.

Critical Failure As failure, but @Damage[12d10[slashing]|options:area-damage] damage, and the creature is also knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

action->Tongue Grab.name: Tongue Grab
action->Tongue Grab.description: A creature hit by the dust worm augur's tongue becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}. A creature can sever the tongue with a Strike against AC 42 that deals at least @Damage[38[slashing]] damage. This prevents the worm from using its tongue Strike until it regrows its tongue, which takes 1 day.

action->Tongue Reel.name: Tongue Reel
action->Tongue Reel.description:
Requirements The dust worm aurgur has @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} a creature with its tongue

Effect The diaspora worm attempts to [[/act reposition]] the grabbed creature toward the worm. If the grabbed creature is brought to within 10 feet or less of the worm, the worm can attempt to Swallow Whole the creature.

action->Mycelium Network.name: Mycelium Network
action->Mycelium Network.description: Psychic fungi are connected to a network of psychic filaments bonding all psychic fungi from the same colony. This network grants the harvester the ability to detect creatures capable of thought within 30 feet of a bonded psychic fungus up to 1,000 feet away as an imprecise sense.

action->Release Spores.name: Release Spores
action->Release Spores.description:
Trigger The harvester is reduced to 0 Hit Points

Effect The harvester releases a cloud of spores in a @Template[type:burst|distance:10] centered on a corner of its own space that lasts for 1 round. Each creature that's in the cloud or enters it is exposed to befuddling spores. If this reaction was triggered by damage from a melee attack, the triggering creature uses the outcome one degree of success worse than the result of its roll for its Fortitude save (two degrees worse if it was a jaws Strike or other Strike with the creature's mouth).

action->Befuddling Spores.name: Befuddling Spores
action->Befuddling Spores.description:
Plants and fungi are immune

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:21]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 3} (1 round)

Stage 4 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 4} (1 round)

action->Drain Brain.name: Drain Brain
action->Drain Brain.description: The elder psychic fungus consumes the fluids and psychic essences from the brain of a creature within 10 feet that has been dead for no more than 1 minute. The elder psychic fungus regains the use of their highest-ranked spent innate spell. The creature is considered to have died due to a death effect.

lore->Lore (all subcategories of all cre.name: Lore (all subcategories of all creatures trained in Lore skills within 1 mile)

Electrovore.name: Electrovore
Electrovore.publicNotes:
Electrovores consume electricity as their sole source of sustenance. On their native planet, they fed on a species of three-headed electric eels, but volcanic activity wiped out their food source, sending electrovores to the brink of extinction. Electrovores found their salvation when explorers landed on their planet. The explorer's equipment and vessels had ample amounts of the electricity that the electrovores require. They stowed away on the vessels and soon spread throughout the Pact Worlds, causing damage and mayhem wherever they appeared.

Nothing terrifies a team of engineers more than finding an electrovore chewing on wires in a remote part of their starship. Where there's one electrovore, a dozen more likely await discovery. These 3-foot-tall reptilian creatures, sometimes called "conduit rats," breed rapidly and create such a disturbance in power sources that, over the course of days or weeks, a starship or factory might completely shut down from lack of power. There are many lifeless star vessels adrift in space because an electrovore infestation wasn't stopped in time.

Removing an infestation is no easy task, as electrovores are single-minded and cunning. The creatures are adept at finding places to hide, stalking their preferred energy sources and finding the correct moment to strike. Packs of electrovores even coordinate feedings in different areas at the same time to make it harder to stop them.

When confronted, electrovores rarely fight to the death, preferring to eat some electricity and retreat, hide, and heal, then return for another feast.

action->Electricsense.name: Electricsense
action->Electricsense.description: An electrovore can sense electricity, including the electrical impulses found in most living creatures' nervous systems, as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

action->Electrical Discharge.name: Electrical Discharge
action->Electrical Discharge.description:
Effect The electrovore unleashes a shock wave that deals @Damage[2d6[electricity]|options:area-damage] damage to creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] (@Check[reflex|dc:15]). It can't use Electrical Discharge again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Electrical Discharge]]{1d4 rounds}.

Critical Success The target is unaffected.

Success The target takes half damage. Items in its possession with the tech trait becomes glitching 1. If the target has the tech trait, it becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6A2QDy8wRGCVQsSd]{Glitching 1}.

Failure As success, but full damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6A2QDy8wRGCVQsSd]{Glitching 2}.

Critical Failure As success, but double damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6A2QDy8wRGCVQsSd]{Glitching 3}.

action->Siphon.name: Siphon
action->Siphon.description: When an electrovore scores a critical hit with a tail Strike against a living creature wielding or wearing tech gear or a creature with the tech trait, it siphons off a portion of the target's electrical energy. This restores @Damage[5[healing]] Hit Points to the electrovore immediately, plus 1 Hit Point per minute for the next 10 minutes; the additional healing doesn't increase if the electrovore siphons multiple times.

Elimination-Class Assassin Robot.name: Elimination-Class Assassin Robot
Elimination-Class Assassin Robot.publicNotes:
Elegant and deadly, elimination models rely upon their stealth fields to keep foes guessing and strike where least expected. Their advanced intelligence gives them the capacity to set up more complex ambushes as well as react to changes in the situation as needed and handle requests from the client. This could mean making the killing as subtle or as gruesome as possible, depending on the intent and message intended.

In some societies, machines automate many processes. It only makes sense, then, that some would attempt to automate the act of murder. Most manufacturers would never admit to creating such designs, forcing wealthy figures to go through hidden channels to acquire units from secret facilities or unscrupulous manufacturers. Regardless of their origins, these robots can be programmed with a target and set loose, the owner assured that either their target will be dead or will be unable to prove who tried to kill them thanks to the unit's fried circuitry.

weapon->Integrated Advanced Nano-edge Ra.name: Integrated Advanced Nano-edge Rapier
weapon->Integrated Advanced Nano-edge Ra.description:
Upgrades: 1

The edge of this precision-crafted foil is sharpened to the thickness of a single atom, using regenerating nanites to maintain itself after countless strikes.

weapon->Integrated Advanced Semi-Auto Pi.name: Integrated Advanced Semi-Auto Pistol
weapon->Integrated Advanced Semi-Auto Pi.description:
Upgrades: 1

This pistol automatically ejects used cartridges and loads new ammunition after every shot fired.

weapon->Shirren-eye Rifle.name: Shirren-eye Rifle
weapon->Shirren-eye Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

This sniper rifle comes with a compound technological scope that allows snipers to adjust focus and magnification with natural eye movements instead of using moving parts that might disrupt their aim.

action->Accelerated Response.name: Accelerated Response
action->Accelerated Response.description:
Trigger The target of the elimination-class assassin robot's Target Tracking attempts a Strike against the robot

Effect The robot reads its target's movements, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering Strike.

action->Burn Protocol.name: Burn Protocol
action->Burn Protocol.description: The circuitry of an assassin robot self-destructs upon the robot's destruction, making tracing its owner extremely difficult. Add 10 to the DC of a Computers check to recover data from a destroyed assassin robot.

action->Holographic Camouflage.name: Holographic Camouflage
action->Holographic Camouflage.description:
Frequency once per hour

Effect The elimination-class assassin robot becomes invisible for 10 minutes. If the robot uses a hostile action or moves more than half its Speed in a single action, the robot becomes visible again after it completes that action.

action->Nanite Surge.name: Nanite Surge
action->Nanite Surge.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The elimination-class assassin robot restores @Damage[45[healing]] Hit Points to one technological creature or item.

action->Retractable Weapons.name: Retractable Weapons
action->Retractable Weapons.description: The elimination-class assassin robot can Interact to draw or retract any of its integrated weapons as a free action. An observer must succeed at a @Check[perception|dc:40] check to notice a retracted weapon.

action->Sneak Attack.name: Sneak Attack
action->Sneak Attack.description: The elimination-class assassin robot's Strikes deal an additional 3d6 precision damage to @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.

action->Target Tracking.name: Target Tracking
action->Target Tracking.description: The elimination-class assassin robot establishes a target lock on a creature it can see within 120 feet. The creature can't become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} against the robot or [[/act create-a-diversion]] against the robot. This ability lasts until the robot loses line of sight with the target or the target otherwise becomes hidden.

Elindrian Acolyte.name: Elindrian Acolyte
Elindrian Acolyte.publicNotes:
These elindrians are the rank-and-file worshippers of the Terror of Ukulam. Recently risen from the dead by some primal force or occult upheaval—no one is sure—they single-mindedly pursue their grisly task of unearthing fellow elindrians across Castrovel; many others have risen from the dead, but most still remain buried. They stop only to attack other living creatures that intervene.

The people known as elindrians vanished eons ago into desolate husk-hives beneath the surface of the planet Castrovel. Until recently, they were creatures of legend, existing only in the most obscure formian histories. Now, scholars on Castrovel desperately search for additional records about elindrians, their origins, and—most importantly—the truth about their connection to the terrifying ooze-like creature that recently descended from their moon, Elindrae. One theory is that elindrians share some primal bond with the ooze-thing called the Terror of Ukulam, and perhaps both originate from Elindrae—other theories claim that elindrians created the ooze in the first place or that they're distant cousins to formians, corrupted by the Terror long ago.

action->Husk Mind.name: Husk Mind
action->Husk Mind.description:
Elindrians can communicate nearly instantaneously via a primal bond similar to a formian hive mind. While within telepathic range of at least one other elindrian with husk mind, an elindrian acolyte gains a +2 circumstance bonus to initiative rolls, Perception checks, and saving throws against mental effects. If one elindrian is aware of a combatant, all members of the husk mind within range are aware of it.

The elindrian's husk mind is integrated with their scent; for purposes of detecting other elindrians, formians, undead, or corpses, their scent is a precise sense, rather than imprecise.

An elindrian always knows the precise distance and direction to the Terror of Ukulam, so long as they're on the same plane of existence.

action->Unfetter Allies.name: Unfetter Allies
action->Unfetter Allies.description: While the elindrian acolyte is within 30 feet of another elindrian who's unable to move or act normally (such as if they're buried, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, stunned, or otherwise impeded), the elindrian acolyte becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened} 1 and can use the extra action to Burrow, Fly, [[/act shove]], Stride, or Strike.

Elindrian Celebrant.name: Elindrian Celebrant
Elindrian Celebrant.publicNotes:
These elindrian warriors relish violence. Their only motivation seems to be spreading pain, which they themselves are immune to; their nerve endings developed in such a way that they can't feel pain at all, experiencing it in some way that causes them little to no suffering. As long as there's an elindrian queen nearby to revive them, celebrants spend most of their time battling one another, honing their capability to do violence until a better target comes along.

The people known as elindrians vanished eons ago into desolate husk-hives beneath the surface of the planet Castrovel. Until recently, they were creatures of legend, existing only in the most obscure formian histories. Now, scholars on Castrovel desperately search for additional records about elindrians, their origins, and—most importantly—the truth about their connection to the terrifying ooze-like creature that recently descended from their moon, Elindrae. One theory is that elindrians share some primal bond with the ooze-thing called the Terror of Ukulam, and perhaps both originate from Elindrae—other theories claim that elindrians created the ooze in the first place or that they're distant cousins to formians, corrupted by the Terror long ago.

action->Husk Mind.name: Husk Mind
action->Husk Mind.description:
Elindrians can communicate nearly instantaneously via a primal bond similar to a formian hive mind. While within telepathic range of at least one other elindrian with husk mind, an elindrian acolyte gains a +2 circumstance bonus to initiative rolls, Perception checks, and saving throws against mental effects. If one elindrian is aware of a combatant, all members of the husk mind within range are aware of it.

The elindrian's husk mind is integrated with their scent; for purposes of detecting other elindrians, formians, undead, or corpses, their scent is a precise sense, rather than imprecise.

An elindrian always knows the precise distance and direction to the Terror of Ukulam, so long as they're on the same plane of existence.

action->Pain Bond.name: Pain Bond
action->Pain Bond.description: A celebrant's painsaw is powered by the heart of another celebrant. If a celebrant is within 30 feet of a painsaw that contains their heart when the painsaw Strikes a creature, the celebrant regains a number of Hit Points equal to their level (typically 4). It's taboo for a celebrant to wield a painsaw made from their own heart or a heart from any celebrant whose death they didn't witness (or cause) themself. A painsaw otherwise functions in all ways like a painglaive but doesn't function with normal batteries. A single celebrant heart functions as a tactical battery when used with a painsaw; it recharges if the celebrant spends 10 minutes in the presence of an elindrian queen.

Elindrian Queen.name: Elindrian Queen
Elindrian Queen.publicNotes:
While no one has confirmed the existence of elindrian queens, the elindrians' few similarities to formians have led scholars to believe they must exist. Indeed, these formidable matriarchs are the primary force driving elindrians to unite with the Terror of Ukulam.

The people known as elindrians vanished eons ago into desolate husk-hives beneath the surface of the planet Castrovel. Until recently, they were creatures of legend, existing only in the most obscure formian histories. Now, scholars on Castrovel desperately search for additional records about elindrians, their origins, and—most importantly—the truth about their connection to the terrifying ooze-like creature that recently descended from their moon, Elindrae. One theory is that elindrians share some primal bond with the ooze-thing called the Terror of Ukulam, and perhaps both originate from Elindrae—other theories claim that elindrians created the ooze in the first place or that they're distant cousins to formians, corrupted by the Terror long ago.

spell->Resurrect (elindrians only; up to.name: Resurrect (elindrians only; up to 10 elindrians with one casting and a cast time of only 10 minutes if they perished within the last hour)

action->Husk Mind.name: Husk Mind
action->Husk Mind.description:
Elindrians can communicate nearly instantaneously via a primal bond similar to a formian hive mind. While within telepathic range of at least one other elindrian with husk mind, an elindrian acolyte gains a +2 circumstance bonus to initiative rolls, Perception checks, and saving throws against mental effects. If one elindrian is aware of a combatant, all members of the husk mind within range are aware of it.

The elindrian's husk mind is integrated with their scent; for purposes of detecting other elindrians, formians, undead, or corpses, their scent is a precise sense, rather than imprecise.

An elindrian always knows the precise distance and direction to the Terror of Ukulam, so long as they're on the same plane of existence.

action->Vision of Elindrae.name: Vision of Elindrae
action->Vision of Elindrae.description: The elindrian queen assails creatures with visions of environmental destruction on the moon Elindrae. She targets as many creatures as she wishes within range of her telepathy and to whom she has a line of effect. The creatures take @Damage[3d6[mental],1d6[persistent,mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:40|basic] save) and are @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} on a failure (or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 4} on a critical failure). On a critical success, creatures are temporarily immune to Vision of Elindrae for 24 hours.

Emganat.name: Emganat
Emganat.publicNotes:
Emganats were first encountered during the Krethiskar subcolony's sudden emergence and the first attacks on Szandite Collective space. These wolf-sized components can burrow beneath the ground, and they move at great speeds to reach a location where they can set up an ambush. Then, once they detect a threat, the emganats spring forth from their burrowed positions and lay into their foes with an acidic cannon located in their mouths. The more emganats that unleash their bio-acid on foes, the faster the substance dissolves their targets in an agonizing display.

Developing far out in the Vast from an insectile species known as kucharns, the Swarm is considered the greatest threat in existence for several cultures. Composed of countless subcolonies, each consisting of myriad component subspecies, the Swarm is a vast host that acts in psychic union for the purpose of consuming all matter across the cosmos. Most frightening of all is the Swarm's ability to assimilate the knowledge and DNA of those they consume. Thanks to its pre-Gap development of star travel, the Swarm had already consumed innumerable systems before history short-circuited, and the Swarm's pace only accelerated once it received access to the Signal and the hyperspace dimension known as the Drift.

Worlds touched by the Swarm are drained of their natural resources and rendered barren places known as huskworlds. What outsiders consider to be "Swarm space" is little more than a swathe of lifeless worlds that the Swarm have consumed in its reckless advance. The Swarm so thoroughly strips these worlds that surveyors struggle to find even trace amounts of inorganic resources, such as rare minerals and water. Few of these huskworlds have been thoroughly explored, as oftentimes exploration awakens inert drones, theorized to have been left behind in case the devoured system was ever colonized and repopulated. Pockets of Swarm activity exist well beyond this region of space, as the Swarm sent out countless subcolonies in the ages before the Gap, and even now, only some of them have reached their intended destinations.

The Swarm is perhaps most known in the current era for two important facts. First, its assault on the Pact Worlds and the Veskarium led to the cessation of hostilities and tenuous alliance between the two powers. Second, the Swarm is the direct ancestor of the shirren species. Having broken away sometime during the Gap, shirrens found succor with the deity Hylax, who was believed to have evolved from a pre-Swarm kucharn and who turned her back on the ravenous entity the Swarm has evolved into.

In recent years, the Swarm had been seen as little more than a distant boogeyman with no activities save for classified actions in the Suskillon system in the Vast. However, the recent discovery of the missing Szandite world of Krethiskar inadvertently awoke a dormant subcolony that had been responsible for the world's consumption. Since then, the newly dubbed Krethiskar subcolony has become a scourge of Near Space, engaged in an active invasion of Szandite Collective worlds and poised to spill over into other powers like the Veskarium and Pact Worlds. This rediscovered subcolony has begun rapid evolution of its components and remains cut off from the wider Swarm, but it still represents a clear danger to Near Space.

action->Motion Sense.name: Motion Sense
action->Motion Sense.description: An emganat can sense nearby creatures through vibrations in air or water caused by movement as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

action->Colony Mind.name: Colony Mind
action->Colony Mind.description: 30 feet. All allies with colony mind within the listed range of each other are in constant telepathic communication and are aware of all threats any individual knows about. While within range of at least one ally with colony mind, when a creature rolls a success on a save against a mental effect, it gets a critical success instead.

action->Burrowing Reveal.name: Burrowing Reveal
action->Burrowing Reveal.description:
Requirements Initiative hasn't yet been rolled, and the emganat is burrowed

Trigger A creature enters the range of the emganat‘s motion sense

Effect The emganat notices the creature and Burrows before it rolls initiative. This movement must cause the emganat to emerge from the ground.

action->Coordinated Digestion.name: Coordinated Digestion
action->Coordinated Digestion.description: If the emganat successfully Strikes a creature with its acidic mouth cannon and that creature was already taking persistent acid damage, increase the damage dice of the persistent damage by one step (to a maximum of d8s).

Emissar Angel.name: Emissar Angel
Emissar Angel.publicNotes:
Emissars, or propaganda angels, are a divine embodiment of radical hope and the celestial answer to information warfare. Some emissars spring from the sainted souls of revolutionary leaders or celebrities who used their platforms to help people in life, having been transformed into a celestial in their afterlife. Others spontaneously form out of the condensed faith and desires of a movement or ideal.

Emissar angels take on the role of celestial spin doctors and political organizers, inspiring their allies to rally together and keep pushing toward a goal even when defeat seems inevitable. Emissars often support mortal causes that align with their own beliefs and goals, and while they always hope to change hearts with an inspiring speech or an act of radical kindness, emissars aren't afraid to fight for what they believe in—no matter the cost to themselves. As soon as a battle ends, their first priority is caring for their allies and saving any enemies who might be swayed to join the cause. While their allies usually appreciate their unshakable hope and upbeat attitude, their opponents resent what can be construed as the emissars' toxic positivity and comforting lies.

While many angels in modern times ascended from mortal souls across the cosmos, these celestial beings were among the first creatures to exist in all the cosmos. Warriors and messengers of the gods, they're utterly devoted to their cause, whether that be destroying evil or spreading a deity's message across the galaxy.
Emissar Angel.allSavesBonus: +1 status bonus vs. emotion and mental

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Menta.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Mental

action->Encouraging Hope.name: Encouraging Hope
action->Encouraging Hope.description: 30 feet. Allies within the angel's aura gain a +1 status bonus to all saves against emotion and mental effects. Enemies in the area take a –1 status penalty to all saves against emotion and mental effects.

action->Morale Boost.name: Morale Boost
action->Morale Boost.description: The emissar angel urges their allies to hustle for the cause. Until the beginning of the emissar's next turn, the emissar and their allies within 100 feet that can sense the angel gain a +5-foot status bonus to their Speeds.

action->Spin Doctor.name: Spin Doctor
action->Spin Doctor.description: The emissar commands an ally within 30 feet to ignore a harmful effect and keep fighting. The target gains 2d10 temporary Hit Points for 1 minute and suppresses one condition that's currently affecting it for the next [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}, chosen from the following list: @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.HL2l2VRSaQHu9lUw]{Fatigued}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D]{Fleeing}, frightened, or stupefied. The target is then temporarily immune to Spin Doctor for 1 hour.

Emissary-Class Infiltrator Robot.name: Emissary-Class Infiltrator Robot
Emissary-Class Infiltrator Robot.publicNotes:
While many of the earliest infiltrator robots were designed for more direct stealth missions, the emissary-class infiltrator robots were created for more insidious tasks. These include planting evidence, spreading rumors and propaganda, and generally creating unrest or fomenting open rebellion.

Programmed with a sophisticated virtual intelligence and constructed with the ability to disguise itself as a creature of flesh and blood, an emissary-class infiltrator robot can wreak havoc on an organization or settlement without ever having to engage in combat. They are considered the ultimate tool in corporate or governmental espionage and fetch a high price on most illegal markets.

Brought to the forefront during the war against the Veskarium, and further perfected by various corporate interests within the Pact Worlds, infiltrator robots are known for being able to get into places where no one else could. Generally small and agile, infiltrator robots sneak into enemy territory and either download precious data or record incriminating evidence.
Emissary-Class Infiltrator Robot.languagesDetails: Common plus up to three other languages

weapon->Puzzleblade.name: Puzzleblade
weapon->Puzzleblade.description:
Upgrades: 1

This kasathan sword breaks down into interlocking pieces for storage and transport. Traditionalists practice the art of ritually assembling puzzleblades, with different pieces symbolizing the kasathan virtues of conviction, dedication, moderation, and tradition. Criminals and smugglers value the puzzleblade for its discreet design.

weapon->Semi-Auto Pistol.name: Semi-Auto Pistol
weapon->Semi-Auto Pistol.description:
Upgrades: 1

This pistol automatically ejects used cartridges and loads new ammunition after every shot fired.

equipment->Hacking Toolkit (Advanced).name: Hacking Toolkit (Advanced)
equipment->Hacking Toolkit (Advanced).description: A hacking toolkit is required for Computers checks to Hack computers. You can use a hacking toolkit to access a computer without using a user interface, but this requires physical contact with the computer or contact via an infosphere or a similar linked network. An advanced hacking toolkit adds a +1 item bonus to checks made with it and allows you to access computers at a range of 30 feet, unless you're in a radioactive environment.

equipment->Infiltrator's Toolkit (Tactic.name: Infiltrator's Toolkit (Tactical)
equipment->Infiltrator's Toolkit (Tactic.description: You need an infiltrator's toolkit to @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.2EE4aF4SZpYf0R6H]{Pick Locks} or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{Disable Devices} (of some types) using the Thievery skill. A tactical infiltrator's toolkit adds a +1 item bonus to checks to Pick Locks or Disable Devices.

action->Adaptive Disguise.name: Adaptive Disguise
action->Adaptive Disguise.description: An emissary-class infiltrator robot is covered in a layer of synthetic programmable skin that counts as a disguise kit. The robot can alter the skin over the course of a minute to Impersonate a Medium humanoid ancestry or specific person (if it has information about that person or has previously interacted with them). If the robot makes a retractable spike Strike or uses Morphing Visage, it takes a –4 circumstance penalty to its Deception DCs and skill checks to Impersonate against any who witnessed the action

action->Exploit Nausea.name: Exploit Nausea
action->Exploit Nausea.description: An emissary-class infiltrator robot's Strikes deal an additional 3d6 precision damage to sickened creatures.

action->Morphing Visage.name: Morphing Visage
action->Morphing Visage.description:
By sending ripples through its synthetic skin, the emissary-class infiltration robot creates a nauseating display that affects all creatures within 20 feet that can see it. Each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[will|dc:30] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and becomes immune to the robot's Morphing Visage for 10 minutes.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2}.

Empathnid.name: Empathnid
Empathnid.publicNotes:
Empathnids take a liking to those who show them genuine empathy. While they usually avoid combat, empathnids jump into action if their friends are threatened.

Empathnids have tremendous empathy for other creatures. The fact that the 8-inch spidery creatures come in a variety of colors and have a lifesaving venom likely explains why they're frequently used as companions or pets across the Pact Worlds.

action->Emotionsense.name: Emotionsense
action->Emotionsense.description: This is a precise sense against creatures under an emotion effect or in the grips of overwhelming emotions (at the GM's discretion). Against other creatures, this is an imprecise sense. Creatures immune to emotion or mental effects or under the effects of a calm spell are undetectable by emotionsense.

action->Moral Support.name: Moral Support
action->Moral Support.description: Allies sharing the same space as the empathnid receive a +1 circumstance bonus on saving throws against emotion and mental effects.

action->Stabilizing Antivenom.name: Stabilizing Antivenom
action->Stabilizing Antivenom.description:
Frequency once per day

Requirements The empathnid is sharing a space with a creature with the dying condition

Effect The empathnid injects its proto-venom into the creature. That creature loses the dying condition, though it remains @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} at 0 Hit Points.

Emvermod.name: Emvermod
Emvermod.publicNotes:
A form of house spirit, the emvermod, or "moderator fey," is a shy resident of one or more online communities who helps keep the online space vibrant, engaged, and orderly. They often take on the appearance of their avatar, choosing one that fits with the other members of their infosphere niche.

When given proper respect, an emvermod is a diligent administrator who helps an online community thrive while working alongside other moderators in the online space. When disrespected or accused of causing harm to the community, they cause all sorts of mischief, such as deleting posts, shadow banning members, and even imitating other users.

weapon->Pulsecaster Pistol.name: Pulsecaster Pistol
weapon->Pulsecaster Pistol.description:
Upgrades: 1

This imposing pistol fires a jolt of paralyzing electricity from its barrel. Its remaining charges are visible as glowing lines of energy radiating down its body. Pulsecaster pistols are often used by bounty hunters and law enforcement who need to keep their targets alive.

equipment->Comm Unit.name: Comm Unit
equipment->Comm Unit.description:
A personal comm unit is a pocket-sized device that combines a minor portable computer and a cellular communications device, allowing instantaneous wireless communication with other comm units in both audio- and text-based formats at planetary range. A personal comm unit also includes a calculator, a flashlight (emits bright light in a 5-foot radius around you and dim light in the next 5 feet), a browser that accesses any local infospheres, and several entertainment options (including games).

Personal comm units integrated into armor have some voice-activated capabilities; you can communicate with other comm units in audio-based formats and receive responses without needing a free hand, but typing a message, browsing the infosphere, or using an app requires the use of at least one hand.

Comm units that function at longer ranges aren't as portable; they include built-in generators that provide the necessary amount of power and rely on active Drift beacons to communicate. Short-term use of these units can be purchased in most major settlements.

action->Dutiful Moderator.name: Dutiful Moderator
action->Dutiful Moderator.description: An online community moderated by an emvermod never experiences random bugs or downtime. Any checks to @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.Yn4jLPVWVE1vtAaF]{Access Infosphere}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.rmwa3OyhTZ2i2AHl]{Craft} virtual items, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.QyzlsLrqM0EEwd7j]{Earn Income}, or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.RF8xNJ8QsMwogerB]{Hack} using the community as a tool receive a +2 circumstance bonus. If the emvermod is unfriendly, such checks take a –2 circumstance penalty instead. An emvermod must spend a week in an online space to become a moderator.

action->Modvision.name: Modvision
action->Modvision.description: An emvermod can sense items and creatures with active accounts on any community they moderate as an imprecise sense at the listed range. They recognize community members, even if they use an infosphere alias.

action->Shy.name: Shy
action->Shy.description: An emvermod is naturally invisible while holding a comm unit or in a virtual space. They don't appear to have an account in any infosphere space they moderate. They can become visible, or even selectively visible, allowing only specific people to see them.

action->Shadow Ban.name: Shadow Ban
action->Shadow Ban.description:
Frequency once per 10 minutes

Effect A creature within 60 feet with a comm unit or other computer connected to an infosphere must attempt a @Check[will|dc:18] save as the emvermod tries to ban it from communicating.

Critical Success No effect, and the creature is temporarily immune to Shadow Ban for 1 day.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature can't use auditory actions or communicate, even by gesturing, generating text, or using telepathy. This also prevents the target from casting spells due to the magical words involved in casting, with the exception of subtle spells. This effect lasts for 1 minute, or until the moderator fey retracts the Shadow Ban or dies, whichever comes first.

Critical Failure As failure, except this effect lasts 24 hours.

Enraged Noquasar.name: Enraged Noquasar
Enraged Noquasar.publicNotes:
A noquasar's rage increases as its torture extends over many years.

When a solarian perishes while out of sync with the cycle of stars, their soul might become entangled with their solar mote. Extreme cosmic forces act on the soul as it attempts to reach the River of Souls, stretching it infinitely thin for all of eternity.

action->Gravity Crash.name: Gravity Crash
action->Gravity Crash.description: A creature critically hit by an enraged noquasar's graviton flare is knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}. If the target is flying, it falls up to 30 feet.

action->Ionized Plasma Blas.name: Ionized Plasma Blas
action->Ionized Plasma Blas.description: The noquasar spark unleashes plasma in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] or @Template[type:line|distance:30]. Each creature in the area takes @Damage[3d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic] save). A creature that critically fails its save also takes @Damage[1d8[persistent,electricity]|options:area-damage] damage and is knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}. The noquasar spark can't use Ionized Plasma Blast again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Ionized Plasma Blast]]{1d4 rounds}.

Erabryth.name: Erabryth
Erabryth.publicNotes:
When androids die or give their bodies up for renewal—a celebrated and respected event akin to procreation—it's the silent and calm erabryths who usher their souls into the Boneyard. Beings of reflection and introspection, these psychopomps help androids come to terms with their choices, reconcile the trying events of their lives, and realize that the time for renewal has finally come.

Erabryths are lanky and androgynous, with reflective, ribboned flesh and a mirrored disk for a face. They communicate through posture and emotive lights, offering comfort through their soothing, persistent presence.

Psychopomps are death's shepherds who safeguard the cycle of life, death, and the afterlife by slaying undead or ushering souls safely through the Boneyard.

action->Buffering Zone.name: Buffering Zone
action->Buffering Zone.description:
15 feet. A creature that begins its turn within the area must attempt a @Check[will|dc:14] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and is temporarily immune to buffering zone for 1 day.

Success The creature treats the buffering zone as difficult terrain for 1 round.

Failure As success, and the creature is pushed back 5 feet and takes a –1 status penalty to attack rolls for 1 round.

Critical Failure As failure, but the creature is pushed back beyond the boundary of the buffering zone and can't reenter the buffering zone for 1 round.

action->Reflect Aggression.name: Reflect Aggression
action->Reflect Aggression.description:
Trigger A creature hits the erabryth with a melee or ranged Strike

Effect The erabryth reflects some of their attacker's anger and aggression back at them. The erabryth gains resistance 3 to the triggering damage and deals @Damage[3[mental]] damage to their attacker.

action->Forced Reflection.name: Forced Reflection
action->Forced Reflection.description:
The erabryth forces a creature within 60 feet to relive its most painful memories and regrets in an instant, confronting it with it difficult memories to help it reconcile its actions and let go of its pain. The target must attempt a @Check[will|dc:17] save. Regardless of the result, the target is then temporarily immune to Forced Reflection for 1 day.

Critical Success The target is unaffected.

Success The target is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}.

Failure The target is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} and frightened 1.

Critical Failure The target is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2}.

action->Shepherd's Touch.name: Shepherd's Touch
action->Shepherd's Touch.description: An erabryth's Strikes have the benefit of a ghost killer upgrade and deal an extra 1d4 void damage to living creatures or 1d4 vitality damage to undead.

Excuba.name: Excuba
Excuba.publicNotes:
Unlike all other known types of spectra, excuba spectra are fragmented creatures made of countless tiny pieces that act together as a single networked whole. No accounts of an excuba encounter exist before the Drift crashed, and prevailing theories hold that either the trauma of the crisis created them, or they were created by the Drift as a response to the crisis itself. Whatever the case, excuba encounters have become all too common. These spectra swarms are often dispatched to infiltrate mortal worlds as spies or observers. They collect information for more powerful spectra like wyspirias to analyze and preserve. Some speculate that excubas have always lurked in the galaxy as invisible spies for other spectra, and that the Drift Crisis merely caused them to take a new, less cohesive form.

In the Great Beyond, time is measured not in hundreds, thousands, or millions of years, but rather in eons—in iterations of reality itself. Only rising to prominence within the last three centuries alongside the advent and proliferation of Drift technology, spectra have thrived in a burgeoning niche of the otherwise stagnant zeitgeist of the Great Beyond.

Though their origins and objectives remain shrouded in mystery, encounters with spectra revolve around new technological discoveries, sharing the knowledge of faster-than-light travel, and protecting the Drift. No one knows if spectra existed before the Drift, but their connection to the hyperspace plane is indisputable. Prominent metaphysicians believe spectra were created as amalgams of raw quintessence pulled into the Drift, just as the Drift itself grows from pieces of the Multiverse. If this is true, spectra's interest in the proliferation of Drift technology takes a subtle sinister turn, as each new Drift engine serves to harvest the Great Beyond and all its denizens for the growth of the Drift and spectra themselves.
Excuba.languagesDetails: Arc network, Digital telepathy, Truespeech cant speak any language

action->Digital Telepathy.name: Digital Telepathy
action->Digital Telepathy.description: 100 feet. An excuba can communicate telepathically with any item or creature with the tech trait within their aura as well as with other technologically telepathic creatures (such as those with shortwave and similar abilities). This ability also allows the spectra to remotely attempt Computers checks within their aura.

action->Arc Network.name: Arc Network
action->Arc Network.description: The excuba can communicate through items and creatures with the tech trait, projecting sound from and speaking through the item or creature's voice, speakers, or other audio output. In addition, the excuba can use any item or creature with the tech trait within their digital telepathy aura as the point of origin for their spells and abilities when calculating range, distance, line of effect, and area of effect.

action->Slip Drive.name: Slip Drive
action->Slip Drive.description: An excuba has an internal biomechanical Drift engine, allowing them to function as a Drift engine for a starship or vehicle they pilot as a 1-minute activity. An excuba can enter or exit the Drift themself as a 1-minute activity. When an excuba gets a critical failure on a Piloting check to Navigate or Plot a Course through the Drift, they get a failure instead.

action->Techsense.name: Techsense
action->Techsense.description: The excuba senses creatures and objects with the tech trait as a precise sense within the listed range.

action->Autoencode.name: Autoencode
action->Autoencode.description: An excuba's visual appearance is altered when the excuba is perceived by creatures, items, and objects with the tech trait (such as robotic creatures, cameras, and sensors) unless they succeed at a Perception check against the excuba's Deception DC. Excubas in their swarm form appear to be formless shadows and are additionally @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}, while excubas in their humanoid forms register as familiar- or unremarkable-looking humanoids.

action->Data Vault.name: Data Vault
action->Data Vault.description: An excuba can store data within their body as if they were a computer. Hacking an excuba requires three successes against their Will DC to access their data.

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description:
The excuba can take on the appearance of any Small or Medium humanoid.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]

action->Data Search.name: Data Search
action->Data Search.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The excuba selects one creature with the tech trait in their space, searching its mind and memories. The creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:21] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and immune to Data Search for 24 hours.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The excuba accesses the creature's memories of the last 24 hours, downloading a holographic copy into their data vault and gaining insights into the creature's tactics. The creature must roll twice and take the lower result on its next attack roll, skill check, or saving throw against the excuba or one of the excuba's spells or abilities. This effect has the misfortune trait.

Critical Failure As failure, but the excuba also obtains a specific type of memory (such as what happened during the last time the creature encountered a Drift beacon) regardless of how long ago it was. The target creature loses this memory until it gains access to the excuba's data vault.

action->Swarming Synchronization.name: Swarming Synchronization
action->Swarming Synchronization.description: Each enemy creature in the swarm's space takes @Damage[2d8[sonic]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic] save). On a failure, creatures and objects with the tech trait become glitching 1 (or glitching 2 on a critical failure).

Ferrofluid Magneto-Cluster.name: Ferrofluid Magneto-Cluster
Ferrofluid Magneto-Cluster.publicNotes:
Magneto-clusters are usually created when several smaller ferrofluid oozes combine.
