There have, however, been documented cases of these creatures spontaneously appearing after large industrial accidents. Like their smaller "cousins," magneto-cluster oozes seek out sources of electromagnetism. They also search for and consume magnetic objects and metals capable of being magnetized. They completely disregard organic life and usually are only a danger when a life-form doesn't want to relinquish their magnetic material. Some clusters consume so much metal and objects they're mistaken for scavenger slimes. Any metal consumed by a magneto-cluster immediately becomes magnetic.

As living magnetic accelerators, ferrofluid magneto-cluster oozes are capable of launching the metal they collect at high speeds as a defense mechanism. They do so at such high velocities as to make even a simple metal shard accelerate fast enough to puncture high-tech ballistic armor.

Oozes of many types lurk in dark and abandoned places across the galaxy, emerging only to satiate their appetites and threaten adventurers, explorers, and hapless workers alike.

action->Magnetic Sense.name: Magnetic Sense
action->Magnetic Sense.description: A ferrofluid magneto-cluster can feel magnetic fields, allowing it to detect large sources of magnetic metal (Bulk 1 or greater) and items with the tech trait within the listed range.

action->Magnetic Field.name: Magnetic Field
action->Magnetic Field.description: 30 feet. A ferrofluid magneto-cluster is surrounded by a constant field that interferes with nearby equipment. Items with the tech trait inside the aura take a –1 circumstance penalty to all checks using them. Unattended metal objects in the aura of 1 Bulk or less are pulled adjacent to the ooze.

action->Attach.name: Attach
action->Attach.description:
A ferrofluid magneto-cluster can attach itself to any creature its size or larger that has the tech trait or is wearing or wielding items with the tech trait. This is similar to Grab, but the ooze moves with that creature rather than holding it in place.

As long as the ooze is attached, it's @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard}, and the creature it's attached to must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:11] to Interact with items with the tech trait. On a failure, the item becomes attached to the ooze (treat as if being held by the ooze).

action->Demagnetization.name: Demagnetization
action->Demagnetization.description: A ferrofluid magneto-cluster that takes fire damage has its magnetic field deactivated until the end of the ooze's next turn. It releases itself from any creature it was attached to, drops any held items, and can't use Magnetic Leap or Attach until its magnetic field returns.

action->Magnetic Leap.name: Magnetic Leap
action->Magnetic Leap.description: The ferrofluid magneto-cluster instantly Attaches to a creature within its magnetic field that meets the requirements of that ability. A ferrofluid ooze can't use this ability again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Magnetic Leap]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Metal Storm.name: Metal Storm
action->Metal Storm.description: The ferrofluid magneto-cluster contracts, then spews metal shards in a @Template[type:cone|distance:30], dealing @Damage[5d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:30|basic] save). Any creature that fails its save is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} for 1 round (@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} on a critical failure).

action->Polarity Shift.name: Polarity Shift
action->Polarity Shift.description:
The ferrofluid magneto-cluster shifts the polarity of its magnetic field, causing it to briefly repulse magnetic objects. Each creature in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:30] save or else they're forced to drop any items with the tech trait they're wielding in an adjacent square.

In addition, each creature with the tech trait or wearing armor with the tech trait must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:30] save or be knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

stealth.label: in areas with no magnetic objects

Ferrofluid Ooze.name: Ferrofluid Ooze
Ferrofluid Ooze.publicNotes:
Since the earliest days of space travel, engineers have used ferromagnetic fluids to help with the construction, operation and maintenance of starships. It was only a matter of time before overeager spellcasters tinkered with this substance and inadvertently imbued a modicum of life into it, creating yet another strain of ooze to plague the cosmos. These strange oozes exert magnetic powers and have an instinctive desire to seek out sources of electromagnetism. Ferrofluid oozes are considered galactic nuisances, and many shipyards across the Pact Worlds have begun retaining the services of expert "ooze control" agents to ensure these fluids don't impede their day-to-day operations.

A common ferrofluid ooze appears as a spiked pool of dark metal liquid that shifts in erratic ways but always reacts to nearby magnetic sources. They're mostly found hiding in the darkest corners of starships and space stations.

Oozes of many types lurk in dark and abandoned places across the galaxy, emerging only to satiate their appetites and threaten adventurers, explorers, and hapless workers alike.

action->Magnetic Sense.name: Magnetic Sense
action->Magnetic Sense.description: A ferrofluid ooze can feel magnetic fields, allowing it to detect large sources of magnetic metal (Bulk 1 or greater) and items with the tech trait within the listed range.

action->Magnetic Field.name: Magnetic Field
action->Magnetic Field.description: 30 feet. A ferrofluid ooze is surrounded by a constant field that interferes with nearby equipment. Items with the tech trait inside the aura take a –1 circumstance penalty to all checks using them. Unattended metal objects in the aura of 1 Bulk or less are pulled adjacent to the ooze.

action->Attach.name: Attach
action->Attach.description:
A ferrofluid ooze can attach itself to any creature its size or larger that has the tech trait or is wearing or wielding items with the tech trait. This is similar to Grab, but the ooze moves with that creature rather than holding it in place.

As long as the ooze is attached, it's @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard}, and the creature it's attached to must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:11] to Interact with items with the tech trait. On a failure, the item becomes attached to the ooze (treat as if being held by the ooze).

action->Demagnetization.name: Demagnetization
action->Demagnetization.description: A ferrofluid ooze that takes fire damage has its magnetic field deactivated until the end of the ooze's next turn. It releases itself from any creature it was attached to, drops any held items, and can't use Magnetic Leap or Attach until its magnetic field returns.

action->Magnetic Leap.name: Magnetic Leap
action->Magnetic Leap.description: The ferrofluid ooze instantly Attaches to a creature within its magnetic field that meets the requirements of that ability. A ferrofluid ooze can't use this ability again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Magnetic Leap]]{1d4 rounds}.

Finitrium Fatebender.name: Finitrium Fatebender
Finitrium Fatebender.publicNotes: Finitrium fatebenders are powerful magical constructs created from refined finitrium, a rare starmetal with divinatory properties. Thanks to their ability to see—and react to—the future, finitrium fatebenders make exceptional guardians and formidable foes.

action->Glimpse Fate.name: Glimpse Fate
action->Glimpse Fate.description: A finitrium fatebender gains a +5 circumstance bonus when rolling Perception for initiative, as it acts on flashes of insight harvested from potential futures.

action->A Million Fates.name: A Million Fates
action->A Million Fates.description: 20 feet. A finitrium fatebender is surrounded by an aura of countless shifting potential futures—fragmented milliseconds of possibility all overlapping in a tumultuous blur. A creature that ends its turn in the aura must attempt a @Check[will|dc:33] save. If it fails, it's @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} for 1 round (or [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds} on a critical failure). A creature that critically succeeds becomes temporarily immune to the aura for 1 day.

action->Fated Outcome.name: Fated Outcome
action->Fated Outcome.description:
Frequency once per day

Trigger The finitrium fatebender fails or critically fails an attack roll or saving throw

Effect The finitrium fatebender rerolls the triggering check and takes the better result.

action->Tactical Prescience.name: Tactical Prescience
action->Tactical Prescience.description:
Frequency once per round

Trigger The finitrium fatebender would be hit by a Strike

Effect Having foreseen the incoming attack, the finitrium fatebender shifts position, gaining a +4 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering attack.

action->Fate Wave.name: Fate Wave
action->Fate Wave.description: The finitrium fatebender releases a wave of twisted futures and shattered possibilities, dealing @Damage[16d6[mental]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:cone|distance:60] (@Check[will|dc:36|basic] save). The finitrium fatebender can't use Fate Wave again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Fate Wave]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Foretell Doom.name: Foretell Doom
action->Foretell Doom.description: Any creature hit by the finitrium fatebender's fist or ray of twisted fate Strikes receives a vision of their impending death at the hands of the finitrium fatebender. It must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:36] save or become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2}; on a critical failure, the creature is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}. If the creature is already affected by foretold doom, it increases the appropriate stunned and stupefied values by 1 on a failed save, to a maximum of @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 4}. When the finitrium fatebender is destroyed, the creature has avoided this tragic fate and immediately recovers from its stupefied condition.

action->Inexorable March.name: Inexorable March
action->Inexorable March.description: The finitrium fatebender Strides up to its Speed, pushing back each creature whose space it moves into and damaging creatures that try to stop its movement. A creature can attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:40] save to bar the way, stopping the finitrium fatebender's movement on a success. On a critical success, the resisting creature takes no damage; otherwise, it's damaged as if hit by the finitrium fatebender's fist Strike.

Flarysca.name: Flarysca
Flarysca.publicNotes:
What seem to be glimmering motes of dust drifting in a sunbeam might be the scattered forms of flaryscas drifting across space, dormant but poised to ignite at any moment. Flaryscas materialize ethereally within a sun's rays, dancing to the farthest reaches of space where they flare up for a brief, intense period, then presumably fade away into repose.

While pleasant to look at, flaryscas are responsible for unexplained deaths occurring on many worlds, and even in space. Their soporific aura lulls creatures to curl up lazily in the sun, ignoring cravings for sustenance as flaryscas cavort around these slumberers. While perfect for an afternoon nap or a leshy cosmonaut in search of a snack, on rare occasions such a slumber might prove deadly.

Elementals are energetic intrusions from the primal planes of existence. They take many forms, from mindless eddies in the wind or water to complex entities capable of wielding primal magic. The advent of space travel and the progress of technology have allowed even more living embodiments of the elements to manifest in the Universe.

Natural events like wildfires, solar storms, and floods can unleash hordes of unruly elementals on a planet or into a region of space. Sometimes, a gathering of powerful elementals causes a natural disaster on an epic scale, like an off-the-charts solar flare that fries a planet's power grid or a ceaseless storm swirling in a gas giant's atmosphere.

action->Sun Sense.name: Sun Sense
action->Sun Sense.description: A flarysca can sense the presence of sunlight within 60 feet as a precise sense.

action->Lazy Sunlight.name: Lazy Sunlight
action->Lazy Sunlight.description:
15 feet. Creatures other than the flarysca that enter or begin their turn within the aura must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:25] save. On a failure, a creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1}, or increases it clumsy value by 1 if it was already clumsy.

If it was already @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} or greater, it instead becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} until it begins its turn outside the lazy sunlight aura. Creatures can't reduce their clumsy values while within the lazy sunlight aura.

On a critical success, a creature becomes temporarily immune to lazy sunlight for 1 hour.

action->Reactive Burst.name: Reactive Burst
action->Reactive Burst.description:
Trigger A creature interacts with or moves through a sunbeam containing a sleeping flarysca

Effect The flarysca startles awake, letting out a burst of fire as their body reconstitutes within the sunlight. The triggering creature and any other creature within 30 feet of the flarysca must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:25|basic] save or take @Damage[8d6[fire]] damage.

action->Rejuvenate (Deactivated by Cold).name: Rejuvenate (Deactivated by Cold)
action->Rejuvenate (Deactivated by Cold).description:
The flarysca has @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.lR9R5Vld8Eu2Dha5]{Regeneration} 20 (deactivated by cold) while in direct sunlight. In addition to being deactivated by cold, this regeneration deactivates for 1 round whenever the flarysca takes an Attack action.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.Regeneration]

action->Creeping Warmth.name: Creeping Warmth
action->Creeping Warmth.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The flarysca shines brightly, increasing the radius of their lazy sunlight aura by 5 feet for 1 minute.

action->Light Jump.name: Light Jump
action->Light Jump.description:
Frequency once per round

Requirements The flarysca is standing within direct sunlight

Effect The flarysca teleports themself to another sunbeam or area of direct sunlight they can sense within 60 feet, with the effects of the translocate spell.

Flayer Leech.name: Flayer Leech
Flayer Leech.publicNotes:
Flayer leeches are tiny, invertebrate hunters with multi-hinged mouths that have developed an interesting life cycle: they wear their victim's skin to pose as them, consuming their innards to reproduce.

Flayer leeches will kill and feed on living creatures, feasting on the bone marrow of their victims. This consumption gives them sustenance to survive for weeks. Flayer leeches disengage the tendrils of their petallike mouths, extending them up to 2 meters and using them to stitch together a prey's remains, leaving the brain for it to consume. They then use these tendrils as a pseudo-skeleton to give structure to the body and move it, allowing them to convincingly reanimate the corpse and take on its movements and previous life. The flayer leech lacks the corpse's specific memories, however, which can make it easy to spot for those familiar with the leech's victim. Flayer leeches use this disguise as a safe harbor while feeding off the remaining marrow and nervous system and will defend these new bodies like their home.

action->Effigy Identity.name: Effigy Identity
action->Effigy Identity.description: While a flayer leech is in an effigy, it gains the ability to understand and speak all languages known by the corpse as well as knowledge of the corpse's physical abilities, identity, role in society, and personality. However, it doesn't gain the specific memories or knowledge of the corpse.

action->Create Effigy.name: Create Effigy
action->Create Effigy.description: A flayer leech consumes the brain of the corpse of a Medium or Small creature dead for no longer than an hour, taking over its body. It also stitches together any wounds the corpse might have, presenting only barely visible lines. It can use Stealth to [[/act impersonate skill=stealth]] and doesn't need a disguise kit to do so, but it takes a –2 circumstance penalty to the check if any creature engages the flayer leech in conversation for 1 minute. When in this effigy form, it loses its weakness to bludgeoning and gains weakness 5 to sonic damage. It can make proboscis melee Strikes through extension in its wrists, but it can't make subsonic blast ranged Strikes. A flayer leech can Dismiss the effigy.

action->Drink Marrow.name: Drink Marrow
action->Drink Marrow.description:
Requirements The flayer leech's last action was a successful proboscis Strike against a living creature

Effect The flayer leech vibrates its proboscis at subsonic speed, drilling into a creature's marrow or equivalent bone structure. The required creature must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:21] saving throw or become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}. On a critical failure, it can't reduce this sickened condition for 1 minute.

action->Mandible Dance.name: Mandible Dance
action->Mandible Dance.description:
Requirements The flayer leech isn't currently in an effigy

Effect The flayer leech wriggles its facial tendrils in a tantalizing way. Each creature within 30 feet that can see the flayer leech must attempt a @Check[will|dc:21] saving throw or be @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AdPVz7rbaVSRxHFg]{Fascinated} by the flayer leech for 1 minute.

action->Warp Bones.name: Warp Bones
action->Warp Bones.description:
Requirements The flayer leech is in an effigy

Effect s The flayer leech has a link to any marrow it's tasted. It sends out subsonic waves to vibrate its enemies' skeletal structures, causing immense pain. Any creature within 40 feet with the sickened condition from the flayer leech's Drink Marrow ability takes @Damage[3d8[sonic]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:21|basic] save).

Free Captain.name: Free Captain
Free Captain.publicNotes:
Captain is the highest rank on board any vessel. They answer only to admirals of the Free Captains and only if their ship isn't engaged in active combat. This captain uses the void mode of her cutlass by default, the hundreds of shimmering stars in the blade representing the lives taken in her countless engagements.

The Free Captains have been a scourge of interstellar shipping across the Pact Worlds for generations, but since the adoption of Drift Lanes, the outlaws have expanded their reach and scale by targeting ships across the galaxy using the new standardized interstellar shipping routes.

weapon->Phase Cutlass.name: Phase Cutlass
weapon->Phase Cutlass.description:
Upgrades: 1

A phase cutlass resembles a traditional curved sword until it's powered. Then its blade morphs into a shimmering void, with a tiny star for each life it ended.

weapon->Starfall Pistol.name: Starfall Pistol
weapon->Starfall Pistol.description:
Upgrades: 1

While originally a kit-bashed plasma caster, the commercial models fire streams of superheated plasma. Akitonian revelers enjoy discharging these pistols into the air during outdoor celebrations.

armor->Freebooter Armor.name: Freebooter Armor
armor->Freebooter Armor.description:
Upgrades: 1

Freebooter armor is named for the pirates and outlaws who often wear these outfits. Freebooter armor typically consists of a breastplate worn under a jacket or flight suit, heavy boots and gloves, a helmet, and hidden straps and holsters for concealing weapons.

equipment->Seashell Religious Symbol of.name: Seashell Religious Symbol of Besmara
equipment->Seashell Religious Symbol of.description: This piece of wood or silver is emblazoned with an image representing a deity. Some divine spellcasters, such as clerics, can use a religious symbol of their deity to use certain abilities and cast some spells. A religious symbol can be worn on the body on a chain or pin, or can be held.

action->Give 'Em No Quarter!.name: Give 'Em No Quarter!
action->Give 'Em No Quarter!.description: The Free Captain telepathically orders their crew to mercilessly slaughter one target. All allied creatures of equal or lower level within 60 feet of the Free Captain gain a +1 status bonus to attack rolls and damage rolls against one creature until the end of the Free Captain's next turn.

action->Soul Squall.name: Soul Squall
action->Soul Squall.description: The stars of the Free Captain's cutlass seem to empower their starfall pistol, which deals an additional @Damage[2d6[void]] damage as long as the Free Captain is holding both weapons.

action->Stardust Storm.name: Stardust Storm
action->Stardust Storm.description: The Free Captain uses Area Fire with their starfall pistol split by their phase cutlass, causing the starry darkness to spread. The pistol's Area Fire uses a @Template[type:cone|distance:10] that deals @Damage[2d6[void]|options:area-damage] damage. Creatures that fail their save against the Area Fire become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} on a critical failure).

Free Captain Gunner.name: Free Captain Gunner
Free Captain Gunner.publicNotes:
Leading the assault with an explosion of cannon fire, the gunner's role in a boarding party is to incite a rout while protecting their fellow crew by suppressing a ship's defenses.

The Free Captains have been a scourge of interstellar shipping across the Pact Worlds for generations, but since the adoption of Drift Lanes, the outlaws have expanded their reach and scale by targeting ships across the galaxy using the new standardized interstellar shipping routes.

weapon->Baton.name: Baton
weapon->Baton.description:
Upgrades: 1

This reinforced rod is commonly made from metal alloys and designed to strike and parry incoming blows.

weapon->Breaching Gun.name: Breaching Gun
weapon->Breaching Gun.description:
Upgrades: 1

This snub-nosed scattergun is commonly used to blast through doors and walls. Smaller than a reaction breacher, this scattergun is infamous for its mighty recoil.

shield->Carbon Shield.name: Carbon Shield
shield->Carbon Shield.description: This durable yet lightweight defensive plate comes in a variety of shapes and sizes, and it's often customized with LED displays that broadcast personal insignia or an organization's colors and symbols.

armor->Freebooter Armor.name: Freebooter Armor
armor->Freebooter Armor.description:
Upgrades: 1

Freebooter armor is named for the pirates and outlaws who often wear these outfits. Freebooter armor typically consists of a breastplate worn under a jacket or flight suit, heavy boots and gloves, a helmet, and hidden straps and holsters for concealing weapons.

action->Four-Armed.name: Four-Armed
action->Four-Armed.description: You have four arms, which allows you to wield and hold up to four hands' worth of weapons and equipment. At any time, one pair of hands is designated as your active hands. You can change this designation from one pair of hands to another by taking the Switch Hands action, which is a single action. You can wield items only with your active hands.

action->Raise a Shield.name: Raise a Shield
action->Raise a Shield.description:
Requirements You are wielding a shield.

You position your shield to protect yourself. When you have Raised a Shield, you gain its listed circumstance bonus to AC. Your shield remains raised until the start of your next turn.

action->Fire in the Hole!.name: Fire in the Hole!
action->Fire in the Hole!.description: A special payload gives the breaching gun the area (@Template[type:cone|distance:15]) and unwieldy traits until the end of the gunner's turn. The gunner makes an attack using Area Fire (@Check[reflex|dc:19|basic] save) that uses 3 projectiles. Enemies in the affected area who fail their save against the attack become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.enA7BxAjBb7ns1iF]{Suppressed} until the start of the gunner's next turn.

action->Raid Ready.name: Raid Ready
action->Raid Ready.description: The Free Captain gunner Switches Hands, then Raises a Shield or Reloads, in any order.

action->Shiver Your Timbers.name: Shiver Your Timbers
action->Shiver Your Timbers.description: A creature damaged by the gunner's breaching gun can't reduce its frightened condition until the gunner's next turn.

Free Captain Knave.name: Free Captain Knave
Free Captain Knave.publicNotes:
The Free Captains aren't picky employers and will take almost anyone they believe capable of following the Pirate Code. Most Free Captain ships carry a handful of fresh recruits each trip, some of whom will actually return for a second voyage. While usually relegated to the most demeaning and mundane jobs on board, these sailors take every opportunity to prove themselves to the rest of the crew once combat starts.

The Free Captains have been a scourge of interstellar shipping across the Pact Worlds for generations, but since the adoption of Drift Lanes, the outlaws have expanded their reach and scale by targeting ships across the galaxy using the new standardized interstellar shipping routes.

weapon->Baton.name: Baton
weapon->Baton.description:
Upgrades: 1

This reinforced rod is commonly made from metal alloys and designed to strike and parry incoming blows.

weapon->Laser Pistol.name: Laser Pistol
weapon->Laser Pistol.description:
Upgrades: 1

This compact pistol is the most popular sidearm in the Pact Worlds thanks to its reliability, durability, and affordability. Most common laser pistols have a lightweight polycarbon body ending in a long, slim barrel.

armor->Armored Coat.name: Armored Coat
armor->Armored Coat.description:
Upgrades: 1

This overcoat is made of real or synthetic leather and reinforced with armored plates. Armored coats are often tailor-made to match the wearer's personal style. Standard versions are issued to military officers as part of their uniforms.

action->Blow the Man Down.name: Blow the Man Down
action->Blow the Man Down.description: A Free Captain knave's melee attacks gain the trip trait and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.BCLvAx4Pz4MLa2pu]{Knockdown} ability against @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures.

action->Capitalize on Fear.name: Capitalize on Fear
action->Capitalize on Fear.description: Any creature that has the frightened condition is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} against the Free Captain knave's attacks.

action->Free Swing.name: Free Swing
action->Free Swing.description:
Trigger A creature within melee reach is hit by a ranged weapon or rolls a failure or critical failure against an area attack

Effect The Free Captain knave makes a melee Strike against the triggering creature.

Garaggakal.name: Garaggakal
Garaggakal.publicNotes:
Most garaggakals are around 8 feet tall, weighing 400 pounds, with a 20-foot wingspan. Always on the move, they might find a temporary lair on a broken starship or floating chunk of terrain but are soon off again, in search of a new creature to be their next meal. While one rarely encounters garaggakals in the Universe, it can happen, particularly if their temporary lair exits in the Drift.

The Drift is a strange place, and the creatures native to it are stranger still. Garaggakals prove no exception. Shaped vaguely like humanoids, they have arms and legs but also sallow, rubbery skin with long, scaly tails and gauzelike wings. Most horrifyingly, their faces are almost entirely taken up by their enormous, funnel-like mouth, lined with sharp teeth. While they use these mouths for the obvious purpose of biting, they can also use its powerful suction to draw actual life force from their prey.

Also known as "Drift wraiths," garaggakals hunt down any living creatures that linger too long in the Drift. For garaggakals, anything that isn't a fellow garaggakal is prey. However, they're no mere mindless hunters. Garaggakals are surprisingly intelligent and prefer to dissect victims, learning all about them before eating them. Often, garaggakals take their victims apart while they're still alive. Xenobiologists have determined that garaggakals don't even technically need to eat to survive, so their relentless hunger is seemingly psychological. They do require the energy of the Drift to survive in the absence of food, however, and further need the energy of the Drift to reproduce, seeking out areas of intense radiation to absorb and then build a new offspring from their own cells. Their children are fully grown at creation.

Garaggakals surprise their prey. They are quite stealthy and can even phase through solid matter, suddenly appearing on the inside of a starship—bad news for whatever living creatures happen to be inside. Con artists sell garaggakal repelling devices for travelers to use while in the Drift to prevent such visits.
Garaggakal.languagesDetails: Garaggakal, Can't speak any language, Telepathy 100 feet

action->Emotion Sense.name: Emotion Sense
action->Emotion Sense.description: The garaggakal senses all creatures that are under emotion effects as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

action->Sense Through.name: Sense Through
action->Sense Through.description: The garaggakal's imprecise senses function through most materials and walls. The senses are blocked by energy fields (such as force fields and force effects) and sufficiently dense material: 10 feet of wood or plastic, 5 feet of stone, 1 foot of common metal, or 6 inches of lead or any starmetal.

action->Draining Saliva.name: Draining Saliva
action->Draining Saliva.description: A creature that takes damage from a garaggakal's spit Strike must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:20] save. On a failure, it's @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 2} on a critical failure).

action->Leech Life.name: Leech Life
action->Leech Life.description:
Requirements A living creature within 30 feet of the garaggakal has the drained condition

Effect The garaggakal amplifies the drain on the required creature's essential life force, dealing @Damage[5d6[void]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:20|basic] save). The garaggakal gains temporary Hit Points equal to half the damage dealt that last 1 minute. Regardless of the result of the save, the garaggakal then Flies up to 15 feet closer to the required creature, and the required creature becomes temporarily immune to Leech Life for 24 hours.

action->Phase Through.name: Phase Through
action->Phase Through.description: A garaggakal can shift out of phase with reality and thus can't be held by walls or cages. The garaggakal moves through up to 15 feet of solid matter. They must end their turn outside of the solid matter or take @Damage[5d6[bludgeoning]] damage. A garaggakal can't phase through force effects.

Garaggakal Polymath.name: Garaggakal Polymath
Garaggakal Polymath.publicNotes:
These garaggakals have lived for centuries and reached sizes greater than 15 feet tall and 1,000 pounds. Garaggakal polymaths have spent their many years tormenting and tearing apart all the creatures they've encountered, and they have extensive recollection of anatomy of a wide variety of living things. They're even crueler than younger garaggakals, taking great delight in causing excruciating pain to their victims before stealing their life force. They travel much further through the Drift than their younger counterparts, driven by their insatiable desire to find and dissect new creatures.

The Drift is a strange place, and the creatures native to it are stranger still. Garaggakals prove no exception. Shaped vaguely like humanoids, they have arms and legs but also sallow, rubbery skin with long, scaly tails and gauzelike wings. Most horrifyingly, their faces are almost entirely taken up by their enormous, funnel-like mouth, lined with sharp teeth. While they use these mouths for the obvious purpose of biting, they can also use its powerful suction to draw actual life force from their prey.

Also known as "Drift wraiths," garaggakals hunt down any living creatures that linger too long in the Drift. For garaggakals, anything that isn't a fellow garaggakal is prey. However, they're no mere mindless hunters. Garaggakals are surprisingly intelligent and prefer to dissect victims, learning all about them before eating them. Often, garaggakals take their victims apart while they're still alive. Xenobiologists have determined that garaggakals don't even technically need to eat to survive, so their relentless hunger is seemingly psychological. They do require the energy of the Drift to survive in the absence of food, however, and further need the energy of the Drift to reproduce, seeking out areas of intense radiation to absorb and then build a new offspring from their own cells. Their children are fully grown at creation.

Garaggakals surprise their prey. They are quite stealthy and can even phase through solid matter, suddenly appearing on the inside of a starship—bad news for whatever living creatures happen to be inside. Con artists sell garaggakal repelling devices for travelers to use while in the Drift to prevent such visits.
Garaggakal Polymath.languagesDetails: Garaggakal, Can't speak any language, Telepathy 100 feet

action->Emotion Sense.name: Emotion Sense
action->Emotion Sense.description: The garaggakal polymath senses all creatures that are under emotion effects as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

action->Sense Through.name: Sense Through
action->Sense Through.description: The garaggakal's imprecise senses function through most materials and walls. The senses are blocked by energy fields (such as force fields and force effects) and sufficiently dense material: 10 feet of wood or plastic, 5 feet of stone, 1 foot of common metal, or 6 inches of lead or any starmetal.

action->Analyzed Strike.name: Analyzed Strike
action->Analyzed Strike.description:
Requirements The garaggakal's last action damaged a living creature with a jaws Strike

Effect The garaggakal uses their extensive knowledge of anatomy to dig into the wound, causing agonizing pain to the target. The garaggakal attempts a jaws Strike against the required creature, using the same multiple attack penalty as the previous Strike. On a hit, the target is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical hit). This counts as two Strikes for the garaggakal's multiple attack penalty.

action->Draining Saliva.name: Draining Saliva
action->Draining Saliva.description: A creature that takes damage from a garaggakal's spit Strike must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:36] save. On a failure, it's @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 2} on a critical failure).

action->Leech Life.name: Leech Life
action->Leech Life.description:
Requirements A living creature within 30 feet of the garaggakal has the drained condition

Effect The garaggakal amplifies the drain on the required creature's essential life force, dealing @Damage[10d6[void]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:38|basic] save). The garaggakal gains temporary Hit Points equal to half the damage dealt that last 1 minute. Regardless of the result of the save, the garaggakal then Flies up to 15 feet closer to the required creature, and the required creature becomes temporarily immune to Leech Life for 24 hours.

action->Phase Through.name: Phase Through
action->Phase Through.description: A garaggakal can shift out of phase with reality and thus can't be held by walls or cages. The garaggakal moves through up to 15 feet of solid matter. They must end their turn outside of the solid matter or take @Damage[5d6[bludgeoning]] damage. A garaggakal can't phase through force effects.

Glass Serpent.name: Glass Serpent
Glass Serpent.publicNotes:
The great glass serpents of the barren planet of Eox are one of the Pact Worlds' most notorious apex predators. With an average length of almost 60 feet and a weight of about 5,000 pounds, the size and grace of glass serpents are only part of what makes them such efficient killers. Thanks to an innate invisibility provided by their unique scales, glass serpents remain outside of the visual spectrum of most creatures, allowing them to silently approach unsuspecting prey. Having evolved through Eox's numerous cataclysms, these serpents find sustenance from the rare bands of living creatures who visit the world, and in an odd turn, while they're consuming the living is when glass serpents are at their most vulnerable. The combination of acids and digestive fluids used in consuming a living creature also deprives the serpents of their invisibility, and canny glass serpent hunters actively tempt their quarry with animals to consume before attacking in force.

Glass serpents have made their way well beyond the confines of Eox, and some have even found an accepting ecosystem in the Diaspora's strange waterway, the River Between. The local sarcesians blame Eox for intentionally polluting their waterways with predators, though Eox denies all accusations of intentional meddling. Such debates have only intensified since the Diaspora was granted provisional Pact World status under the sarcesians' stewardship.

action->Ambush.name: Ambush
action->Ambush.description:
Trigger A creature passes within 20 feet of the glass serpent and hasn't detected it

Effect The glass serpent lunges out of hiding. It Strides directly toward the triggering creature and makes a jaws Strike against it. The target creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} to this attack.

action->Ravenous Invisibility.name: Ravenous Invisibility
action->Ravenous Invisibility.description: The glass serpent is naturally invisible. When a glass serpent takes a hostile action of any kind, it is hidden instead of undetected until the start of its next turn, as parts of its body become momentarily tangible. A glass serpent that has swallowed a creature becomes visible for the next day as its meal is being digested. If the swallowed creature escapes or is otherwise removed, the glass serpent immediately returns to being invisible.

action->Concealing Coil.name: Concealing Coil
action->Concealing Coil.description:
Requirements The glass serpent's last action was a successful tail whip Strike

Effect The creature the glass serpent hit is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} from all creatures except the glass serpent until that creature moves out of the glass serpent's reach or until the start of the glass serpent's next turn.

Gnackle.name: Gnackle
Gnackle.publicNotes:
Many poor souls who encounter a gnackle don't realize until it's too late. These gremlins relish watching other creatures suffer humiliating failure and often spend weeks or longer selecting and grooming a victim into bringing out their own downfall. After reading their target's mind to learn what they want most, gnackles then magically disguise themselves, presenting to their target as a fairy godmother or similar granter of wishes and convincing their victims of some great destiny. They offer a magical "gift" and encourage the target toward acts of greater and greater ambition. However, once gnackles deem their victims in a suitably embarrassing or dangerous situation, they twist the gift into a terrible curse.

Gremlins have plagued the Universe with cruel tricks since long before the Gap, and they've fully adapted to a galaxy filled with technology. Whether meddling with a comm unit, a starship, or an entire space station, gremlins delight in ruination and chaos.

action->False Confidence Aura.name: False Confidence Aura
action->False Confidence Aura.description: 30 feet. Non-gremlin creatures that enter the aura must attempt a @Check[will|dc:18] save. On a failure, the creature gains a +1 status bonus to attack rolls and skill checks while in the aura, but if it misses an attack roll or fails a skill check while in the aura, it loses that bonus and instead takes a –2 status penalty to all attack rolls and skill checks for 1 minute. After 1 minute has elapsed, or if a creature succeeds at its save, the creature becomes temporarily immune to that gnackle's aura for 24 hours.

action->Gremlin's Gift.name: Gremlin's Gift
action->Gremlin's Gift.description:
A gnackle can imbue a willing creature with a magical gift of talent for 24 hours, imparting a +2 status bonus to checks with a specific skill, chosen when this ability is used. The gnackle always knows when the creature attempts checks with the chosen skill and, at any time, can choose to invert the gift to instead immediately impart a –4 status penalty to all checks attempted with that skill for 1 minute, after which the creature is no longer affected by this ability.

@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.1uk1rvqSP0S2HfVG]{Effect: Gremlin's Gift}

@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.LdbqPPiSg5gn5Kqp]{Effect: Gremlin's Inverted Gift}

Gubbin.name: Gubbin
Gubbin.publicNotes:
Gubbins—also known as data gremlins—are spontaneously born from corrupted data, especially as a result of errors in artificial intelligence programs. While gubbins aren't particularly powerful, they're notoriously hard to hit due to the way their bodies flicker and jolt through space as if slightly out of sync with the rest of the world. Gubbins are most easily set apart from other gremlins by their fingers, which vary in number from moment to moment and sprout from illogical locations on their hands, such as the backs or palms. While lacking in fine mobility, their warped hands are disturbing to observe in motion, a fact they delightfully use to their advantage.

Due to being weaponized in corporate espionage efforts and later multiplying out of control, gubbins are one of the most ubiquitous types of gremlin on heavily computerized planets. While not as malevolent as other gremlins, gubbins delight in irrevocably corrupting computer data, which they do for their own amusement as well as to create more gubbins. Gubbins are often found where large amounts of data are stored, accompanied by corrupted technological constructs such as hardlight life-forms or robots.

Gremlins have plagued the Universe with cruel tricks since long before the Gap, and they've fully adapted to a galaxy filled with technology. Whether meddling with a comm unit, a starship, or an entire space station, gremlins delight in ruination and chaos.

action->Unsettling Appearance.name: Unsettling Appearance
action->Unsettling Appearance.description: 20 feet. A non-gremlin creature that enters the aura must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:17] save or become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} on a critical failure) and is then temporarily immune to unsettling appearance for 1 minute. If the gubbin used any action with the manipulate trait, an Interact action, or a claw Strike since the start of their last turn, creatures take a –4 status penalty to their saves against this effect.

action->Not Really There.name: Not Really There
action->Not Really There.description:
Trigger A creature targets the gubbin with an attack or area effect, and the gubbin is aware of the attacker

Effect The gubbin teleports 10 feet. If this puts the gubbin out of the range or area of the attack, the attack misses. If not, the gubbin gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC and Reflex saves against the attack.

action->Scramble.name: Scramble
action->Scramble.description: Gubbins can spread their glitchiness to others. Creatures damaged by the gubbin's claw or glitchy beam Strikes must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:17] save or become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical hit). If the target has the tech trait, it becomes glitching instead of sickened.

Gwereiad.name: Gwereiad
Gwereiad.publicNotes:
Gwereiads are aloof and enigmatic nymphs who keep to themselves, nestling deep inside the phenomena known as black holes. Whether their solitary nature is an active preference or simply a consequence of their homes is up for debate, as few creatures can brave the gravitational forces of a black hole long enough to make contact with gwereiads. They're rarely hostile unless provoked and occasionally even rescue starships at risk of being devoured by their homes.

Gwereiads adore art and music, though their tastes tend toward the strange and avant-garde. While most nymphs aren't overtly religious, gwereiads devote themselves to esoteric spirituality focused on space-time.

Nymphs are beautiful fey who appear as humanoids with elven features. They generally take female forms, but nymphs of all genders and presentations exist. While many nymphs live on planets and act as protectors of natural ponds, forests, caves, and cliffsides, other nymphs—often called space nymphs—are known for their association with celestial bodies. Like their planet-bound kin, space nymphs guard their bonded territories from exploitation or harm.

As admirers of the arts, nymphs are especially friendly toward creatives, and offering to depict a nymph in story, picture, or song is a sure way to win their favor—unless the nymph doesn't like the final result and lashes out at the artist for insulting them with a mediocre product. Vidcasting and livestreaming are popular pastimes among more sociable nymphs, whether to show off their remote environments or find audiences for performances. Some nymphs entice movie crews to film in their territories, with two provisos: first, that the production not damage the environment, and second, that the nymph receive a prominent role in the film.

Unless their territories are threatened, most space nymphs are friendly or indifferent to mortals, but they have long memories. Anyone visiting a space nymph's territory would be wise to research that nymph's grudges, past encounters with mortals, or any recent events in the area that might color the nymph's perspective of those traveling near their home.

A mortal who demonstrates the right attitude and abilities, such as by protecting a stellar body from destruction or creating an especially beautiful work of art, might draw a space nymph's attention. From time to time, space nymphs will offer their services as mentors to solarians or mystics, though they seldom seek pupils on their own. Space nymphs rarely enter into more than one such arrangement at a time and typically only make commitments that promise to last decades or centuries, so they're extremely selective in their choice of mentee.

action->Sense Transponder.name: Sense Transponder
action->Sense Transponder.description: While on their bonded celestial body, a nymph can sense approaching starships within a day's travel from the celestial body. This doesn't give them any information about the ship, its occupants, or its exact position. The nymph can send a message to the ship as if using a personal comm unit.

action->Black Hole-Dependent.name: Black Hole-Dependent
action->Black Hole-Dependent.description: A gwereiad is mystically bonded to a single black hole. If they're away from their bonded black hole for more than 24 hours, they become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} and must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:29] save each additional 24 hours or increase their drained value by 1. A gwereiad can perform a 24-hour ritual to bond themself to a new black hole.

action->Singularity Field.name: Singularity Field
action->Singularity Field.description: 30 feet. The area around a gwereiad inexorably draws things toward its center. Creatures entering or starting their turns inside the aura must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:29] save or be pulled 5 feet toward the gwereiad (10 feet on a critical failure).

action->Gravitic Crush.name: Gravitic Crush
action->Gravitic Crush.description:
The gwereiad summons a gravitational collapse around a creature within 30 feet, dealing @Damage[6d6[bludgeoning]] damage. The affected creature must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:29] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature's body crumples under the gravity, and it takes half damage.

Failure The creature takes full damage and is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} by the gravitational collapse. It takes @Damage[2d6[persistent,bludgeoning]] damage until it [[/act escape dc=29]]{Escapes}.

Critical Failure As failure, but the creature takes double damage and the persistent damage is 4d6.

Gwereiad Queen.name: Gwereiad Queen
Gwereiad Queen.publicNotes:
The rarest of nymphs, gwereiad queens form within supermassive black holes, either from a weaker gwereiad's ascension or created spontaneously amid the black hole's powerful energies. They tend to be even more detached than the typical gwereiad, speaking only in peculiar metaphors blending science and mysticism.

Nymphs are beautiful fey who appear as humanoids with elven features. They generally take female forms, but nymphs of all genders and presentations exist. While many nymphs live on planets and act as protectors of natural ponds, forests, caves, and cliffsides, other nymphs—often called space nymphs—are known for their association with celestial bodies. Like their planet-bound kin, space nymphs guard their bonded territories from exploitation or harm.

As admirers of the arts, nymphs are especially friendly toward creatives, and offering to depict a nymph in story, picture, or song is a sure way to win their favor—unless the nymph doesn't like the final result and lashes out at the artist for insulting them with a mediocre product. Vidcasting and livestreaming are popular pastimes among more sociable nymphs, whether to show off their remote environments or find audiences for performances. Some nymphs entice movie crews to film in their territories, with two provisos: first, that the production not damage the environment, and second, that the nymph receive a prominent role in the film.

Unless their territories are threatened, most space nymphs are friendly or indifferent to mortals, but they have long memories. Anyone visiting a space nymph's territory would be wise to research that nymph's grudges, past encounters with mortals, or any recent events in the area that might color the nymph's perspective of those traveling near their home.

A mortal who demonstrates the right attitude and abilities, such as by protecting a stellar body from destruction or creating an especially beautiful work of art, might draw a space nymph's attention. From time to time, space nymphs will offer their services as mentors to solarians or mystics, though they seldom seek pupils on their own. Space nymphs rarely enter into more than one such arrangement at a time and typically only make commitments that promise to last decades or centuries, so they're extremely selective in their choice of mentee.

action->Sense Transponder.name: Sense Transponder
action->Sense Transponder.description: While on their bonded celestial body, a nymph can sense approaching starships within a day's travel from the celestial body. This doesn't give them any information about the ship, its occupants, or its exact position. The nymph can send a message to the ship as if using a personal comm unit.

action->Astronomical Ties.name: Astronomical Ties
action->Astronomical Ties.description:
A nymph queen is intrinsically tied to a specific celestial body, such as a supergiant star for a heliad queen.

As long as the queen is healthy, her territory thrives, and she can attempt to [[/r 1d20+32 #Counteract]] counteract spells and rituals that alter its physical properties with a counteract rank of 10.

If a nymph queen is injured or unhealthy, however, her celestial body also weakens: asteroids wobble out of orbit, stars dim, and the gravity of black holes diminishes. Restoring the nymph queen returns her celestial body to its equilibrium.

action->Singularity Field.name: Singularity Field
action->Singularity Field.description: 60 feet. The area around a gwereiad inexorably draws things toward its center. Creatures entering or starting their turns inside the aura must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:40] save or be pulled 5 feet toward the gwereiad (10 feet on a critical failure).

action->Broadcast Allure.name: Broadcast Allure
action->Broadcast Allure.description:
The nymph queen magically superimposes her image on all technological items capable of displaying it, such as datapads or comm units, within planetary range. Alternatively, she can send this image to any comm address or addresses that she knows.

Each creature that can see the image must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:40] or have their attitude toward her improve by one step (two steps on a critical failure).

Affected creatures' attitudes revert to their previous level if the nymph queen uses a hostile action against them or their allies.

action->Celestial Step.name: Celestial Step
action->Celestial Step.description: A nymph queen can traverse her celestial body near-instantaneously. A nymph queen can use Celestial Step to teleport to any area on or within her territory, vanishing into its surface and reemerging at her intended destination.

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description: Nymph queens can transform between their original form, which looks much like a typical nymph of their kind, and any Small or Medium humanoid form, typically choosing a version of their natural form with the appearance of the chosen species.

action->Fan Mail.name: Fan Mail
action->Fan Mail.description:
A nymph queen can inspire a single intelligent creature by sending them a motivational video or text message. As long as the creature keeps the message saved and remains in good standing with the nymph queen, they gain a +1 status bonus to all Crafting, Performance, and Lore checks related to art or performance.

As a 1-action Interact action, the creature can play or view the message to bolster their spirits. Doing so allows the creature to attempt a [[/r 1d20+26 #Counteract]] counteract check against a single emotion effect affecting them.

When the nymph queen's message is used in this way, it becomes a mundane video or text afterward.

action->Gravitic Crush.name: Gravitic Crush
action->Gravitic Crush.description:
The gwereiad summons a gravitational collapse around a creature within 30 feet, dealing @Damage[5d12[bludgeoning]] damage. The affected creature must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:40] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature's body crumples under the gravity, and it takes half damage.

Failure The creature takes full damage and is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} by the gravitational collapse. It takes @Damage[2d6[persistent,bludgeoning]] damage until it [[/act escape dc=40]]{Escapes}.

Critical Failure As failure, but the creature takes double damage and the persistent damage is 4d6.

Haeshi-Shaa (Haeshi Form).name: Haeshi-Shaa (Haeshi Form)
Haeshi-Shaa (Haeshi Form).publicNotes:
A haeshi-shaa in their haeshi form is aggressive and persistent, unlikely to back down from an argument or a fight unless their life is in danger. While aggressive, haeshis are far from foolish; they prepare carefully for any encounter and often have dozens of nested contingencies to fall back on should any situation evolve beyond their control.

Haeshi-shaas are relatively new members of the Dominion of the Black. These long-lived creatures shift unpredictably between a liquid and a gaseous form in a mysterious cycle that lasts their entire lives. In their liquid haeshi form, they're a churning, chunky fluid, while in their vaporous shaa form, they're more akin to hazy brown fog. Regardless of their form, they hum with atonal harmonies that cause great discomfort in others.

Haeshi-shaas serve as a sort of priest caste for the Dominion of the Black, each form preaching a doctrine of entropy and annihilation, though with slightly different nuances between each form. Haeshis tend toward assertive, aggressive practices, while shaas are meditative, often spending many months or years in contemplation. Haeshi-shaas believe that the most perfect and divine state of any object or being is complete separation into its most basic, individual particles. They claim (dubiously) that they can see, even predict, the journey of all things as they travel toward this ultimate entropic end.

In truth, haeshi-shaas can't even predict when they'll shift into their alternate form. Some have tried to catalyze the change by seeking out specific types of life experience or knowledge, but despite the many claims to the contrary, there are no verified instances of a haeshi-shaa forcing the change. Most choose to simply await their next transformation, during which time they have many centuries to spread the Dominion's disturbing doctrines and pursue their inscrutable agendas.

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Frenetic Death.name: Frenetic Death
action->Frenetic Death.description: When killed, a haeshi explodes in a wave of psychic energy, dealing @Damage[13d6[mental]|options:area-damage] damage to all creatures in a @Template[type:burst|distance:20] (@Check[will|dc:29|basic] save).

action->Compression.name: Compression
action->Compression.description: A haeshi can move through a gap at least 2 feet wide without Squeezing and can Squeeze through a gap at least 1 foot wide.

action->Viral Vapor.name: Viral Vapor
action->Viral Vapor.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:32]

Stage 1 carrier (1 day)

Stage 2 the creature becomes partially vaporous and treats all other creatures as @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} (1 day)

Stage 3 the creature is incorporeal and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} (1 day)

Stage 4 the creature dies, and its body dissipates into fine particles

Haeshi-Shaa (Shaa Form).name: Haeshi-Shaa (Shaa Form)
Haeshi-Shaa (Shaa Form).publicNotes:
While demonstrably more powerful while in shaa form, haeshi-shaas tend to spend this portion of their lives in careful contemplation. A shaa interrupted in their contemplation is a vengeful enemy indeed.

Haeshi-shaas are relatively new members of the Dominion of the Black. These long-lived creatures shift unpredictably between a liquid and a gaseous form in a mysterious cycle that lasts their entire lives. In their liquid haeshi form, they're a churning, chunky fluid, while in their vaporous shaa form, they're more akin to hazy brown fog. Regardless of their form, they hum with atonal harmonies that cause great discomfort in others.

Haeshis tend toward assertive, aggressive practices, while shaas are meditative, often spending many months or years in contemplation. They claim (dubiously) that they can see, even predict, the journey of all things as they travel toward this ultimate entropic end.

In truth, haeshi-shaas can't even predict when they'll shift into their alternate form. Some have tried to catalyze the change by seeking out specific types of life experience or knowledge, but despite the many claims to the contrary, there are no verified instances of a haeshi-shaa forcing the change. Most choose to simply await their next transformation, during which time they have many centuries to spread the Dominion's disturbing doctrines and pursue their inscrutable agendas.

action->+1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic.name: +1 Status to All Saves vs. Magic

action->Expand.name: Expand
action->Expand.description: The shaa spreads their matter thin, becoming Gargantuan and gaining a space and reach of 20 feet. The shaa can take only purely mental actions or use Thicken while in this state. A shaa can return to their normal size by spending a single action, which has the concentrate trait.

action->Thicken.name: Thicken
action->Thicken.description: The shaa agitates their molecules and becomes semitransparent and virtually impenetrable for 1 minute. In this form, the shaa isn't incorporeal, gains resistance 25 to all damage, and gains 150 temporary Hit Points for 1 minute. They can take no actions and are immovable. The shaa reverts to their natural form at the end of the duration.

action->Viral Vapor.name: Viral Vapor
action->Viral Vapor.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:37]

Stage 1 carrier (1 day)

Stage 2 the creature becomes partially vaporous and treats all other creatures as @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} (1 day)

Stage 3 the creature is incorporeal and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} (1 day)

Stage 4 the creature dies, and its body dissipates into fine particles

Hardlight Havoc.name: Hardlight Havoc
Hardlight Havoc.publicNotes:
This hardlight life-form is unstable, displaying stuck frames and erratic movements.

Unlike normal holograms, hardlight life-forms are tangible, living entities.

action->Error State.name: Error State
action->Error State.description:
Before the hardlight havoc begins its turn in combat, it gains one of the following error states at random, losing any previous error state.

Change Character The hardlight havoc regains @Damage[2d8[healing]|options:area-damage] Hit Points.

Pixelation The hardlight havoc is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} from all creatures.

Power Leak The hardlight havoc is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}. At the end of its turn, it deals @Damage[4d6[electricity]|options:area-damage] damage to creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] (@Check[reflex|dc:22|basic] save).

Surge The hardlight havoc is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened} until the end of its turn and can use the extra action to Stride or Strike.

action->Tethered 120 feet.name: Tethered 120 feet
action->Tethered 120 feet.description: A hardlight life-form can't travel more than the indicated number of feet from its projector. A hardlight life-form reduced to 0 HP vanishes, though its projector reconstructs it in [[/gmr 1d4 #hours]]{1d4 hours}. The only way to permanently destroy a hardlight life-form is to find its projector and either repair or destroy it.

action->Flicker.name: Flicker
action->Flicker.description: The hardlight havoc teleports up to 40 feet. If the destination is within melee reach of an enemy, it can make a melee Strike against that enemy. If it teleports to a square without a surface to stand on, it falls after attempting a Strike and takes no damage from falling.

action->Arcade Leap.name: Arcade Leap
action->Arcade Leap.description: The hardlight mascot can make a special Leap up to 15 feet vertically and up to 20 feet horizontally without a check.

action->Stomp.name: Stomp
action->Stomp.description: The hardlight mascot Leaps adjacent to a Medium or smaller creature, then makes a kick Strike against it. On a successful attack, it deals kick damage plus an additional 1d8 force damage. On a critical hit, the target is also knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

action->Taunt.name: Taunt
action->Taunt.description: The hardlight mascot sings a jingle to a creature within 60 feet, dealing @Damage[4d6[mental]] damage (@Check[will|dc:19|basic] save).

Hardlight Scamp.name: Hardlight Scamp
Hardlight Scamp.publicNotes:
These creatures typically resemble the ad or media they were born from, though they often also resemble bat-like elemental scamps, thus earning their name.

Unlike normal holograms, hardlight life-forms are tangible, living entities.

action->Freeze.name: Freeze
action->Freeze.description: The hardlight scamp holds perfectly still so it appears as a normal hologram and becomes hidden. A hardlight scamp can Freeze even while being observed and counts as being @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}.

action->Holospark.name: Holospark
action->Holospark.description: The hardlight scamp shoots sparks at a creature within 60 feet. The target must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:17] save or be @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round (1 minute on a critical failure).

action->Tethered 200 feet.name: Tethered 200 feet
action->Tethered 200 feet.description: A hardlight life-form can't travel more than the indicated number of feet from its projector. A hardlight life-form reduced to 0 HP vanishes, though its projector reconstructs it in [[/gmr 1d4 #hours]]{1d4 hours}. The only way to permanently destroy a hardlight life-form is to find its projector and either repair or destroy it.

action->Digital Reality.name: Digital Reality
action->Digital Reality.description: 60 feet. Within the aura, everything looks digitalized. Visible creatures in the aura can't be @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}, and invisible creatures are concealed rather than undetected.

action->Virtual Roadblocks.name: Virtual Roadblocks
action->Virtual Roadblocks.description: The hardlight weaver creates a stationary medium (1), large (2), or huge (3) hardlight obstacle, the center of which must be within its digital reality aura. These obstacles are difficult and hazardous terrain for non-hardlight life-forms, dealing @Damage[9[force]] damage. The Virtual Roadblocks remain until the hardlight weaver uses this ability again or until its aura moves out of range, whichever comes first.

Heliad.name: Heliad
Heliad.publicNotes:
Denizens of stars throughout the galaxy, heliads tend to be sociable and friendly, but most have mercurial tempers befitting their fiery homes. Heliads reside among still-coalescing protostars or smaller dwarf stars. Though not mortal, they follow a "life cycle" mirroring that of their star, growing in power as their star burns hotter and matures, then gradually weakening as the star burns out.

Many heliads take a keen interest in their star's entire system, eagerly following news, gossip, and activities of its planets' residents, if any, or travelers passing through. They view the arrival of visitors with excitement and frequently broadcast messages offering hospitality to those who venture near their stars. To host such visitors, heliads often build lodgings within special protective bubbles for creatures who couldn't otherwise survive the environment.

Nymphs are beautiful fey who appear as humanoids with elven features. They generally take female forms, but nymphs of all genders and presentations exist. action->Radiant Gaze.name: Radiant Gaze
action->Radiant Gaze.description:
30 feet. A heliad's eyes blaze like a sun. When a creature enters or starts its turn in the aura, it must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:24] save. The heliad can deactivate or activate this aura by using a single action, which has the concentrate trait.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} until the start of its next turn.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} until the start of its next turn.

action->Solar-Dependent.name: Solar-Dependent
action->Solar-Dependent.description: A heliad is mystically bonded to a single protostar or small dwarf star. If they're away from their bonded star for more than 24 hours, they become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} and must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:24] save each additional 24 hours or increase their drained value by 1. A heliad can perform a 24-hour ritual to bond themself to a new star.

action->Supernova.name: Supernova
action->Supernova.description:
Trigger The heliad dies

Effect The heliad's body explodes into brilliant, luminous flame. Each creature in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] takes @Damage[6d8[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:24|basic] save). Creatures that critically fail are @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 minute.

Heliad Queen.name: Heliad Queen
Heliad Queen.publicNotes:
Heliad queens live on the largest dwarf stars, mature stars, and supergiants. They take great pride in the luminosity of their stars, often bedecking themselves in clothing specially designed to refract light to show off their home's brilliance.
