Hellknight Armiger.name: Hellknight Armiger
Hellknight Armiger.publicNotes:
Hellknight armigers are the lowest-ranked Hellknights, though attaining this rank requires them to spend six years as an initiate and then pass the Hellknight Test, during which they must summon, combat, and defeat a fiend of Hell.

Hellknights are infernal knights, and while they once ruled entire nations on Lost Golarion, the Hellknights of the Pact Worlds enforce law and order more holistically, traveling in massive citadel starships to spread their influence rather than remaining in any one place. In battle, Hellknights are orderly, unrelenting, and deadly.

weapon->Dueling Sword.name: Dueling Sword
weapon->Dueling Sword.description:
Upgrades: 1

Coming in a variety of styles, these traditional and time-tested weapons have been honed with advanced smithing techniques and modern materials.

weapon->Frag Grenade (Tactical).name: Frag Grenade (Tactical)
weapon->Frag Grenade (Tactical).description:
Activate 1 Area Fire

Critical @Damage[1d4[bleed]]

These fragmentary grenades explode in a cloud of shrapnel and deal 2d8 piercing damage in a @Template[burst|distance:10] with a @Check[reflex|against:class|basic] save.

weapon->Incendiary Grenade (Tactical).name: Incendiary Grenade (Tactical)
weapon->Incendiary Grenade (Tactical).description:
Activate 1 Area Fire

Critical 5 feet

These grenades use an ignited chemical to explode in a blast of intense heat and deal 2d8 fire damage with a @Check[reflex|against:class|basic] save (@Template[burst|distance:10]). If you have access to the critical specialization effect of grenades, creatures who critically fail their saving throw against incendiary grenades are knocked away from the grenade.

weapon->Laser Rifle.name: Laser Rifle
weapon->Laser Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

These dependable, mass-produced rifles shoot concentrated beams of energy out of square-shaped barrels. The universal standard Pact Worlds model is highly modifiable and designed to function with a variety of accessories and upgrades, with wielders adapting the laser rifle to their preferences and even kit-bashing it into a nearly unrecognizable weapon.

armor->Hardlight Series.name: Hardlight Series
armor->Hardlight Series.description:
Upgrades: 1

A projector fastened to a belt or lapel encases the wearer's body in this shimmering hardlight shell. Military-issue hardlight armor follows a predictable standard, but private users enjoy a range of customizable fashion options.

action->Forged in Hellfire.name: Forged in Hellfire
action->Forged in Hellfire.description:
Trigger The armiger takes fire damage

Effect The armiger absorbs a fraction of the fire to empower their attacks. Until the end of their next turn, their Strikes deal an additional @Damage[1d6[fire]] damage.

action->Four-Armed.name: Four-Armed
action->Four-Armed.description: You have four arms, which allows you to wield and hold up to four hands' worth of weapons and equipment. At any time, one pair of hands is designated as your active hands. You can change this designation from one pair of hands to another by taking the Switch Hands action, which is a single action. You can wield items only with your active hands.

action->Rapid Bombardment.name: Rapid Bombardment
action->Rapid Bombardment.description: The armiger draws two grenades, then Area Fires both grenades. Creatures in the area of both grenades take a –1 circumstance penalty to their saving throws against both grenades.

Hellknight Degradant.name: Hellknight Degradant
Hellknight Degradant.publicNotes:
Hellknights most often study the forces of Hell to inspire their fighting styles and magic, but they might also learn to attune to the forces of the cosmos to become solarians.

Hellknights are infernal knights, and while they once ruled entire nations on Lost Golarion, the Hellknights of the Pact Worlds enforce law and order more holistically, traveling in massive citadel starships to spread their influence rather than remaining in any one place. In battle, Hellknights are orderly, unrelenting, and deadly.

armor->Defrex Hide.name: Defrex Hide
armor->Defrex Hide.description:
Upgrades: 1

Made from the hide of a ferocious mammal native to Vesk-2, this medium armor is especially popular among vesk. Tanned slabs of the creature's thick hide are stitched together with metal wires, and the joints are reinforced with metal studs or scales.

action->Black Hole.name: Black Hole
action->Black Hole.description:
The degradant deals @Damage[9d6[bludgeoning]] damage to each enemy creature within 30 feet with a @Check[fortitude|dc:26] save. The degradant can't use Black Hole again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Black Hole]]{1d4 rounds}.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes half damage and is pulled 5 feet toward the degradant.

Failure The creature takes full damage and is pulled 10 feet toward the degradant.

Critical Failure The creature takes double damage, is pulled 30 feet toward the degradant, and is knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

action->Crush.name: Crush
action->Crush.description: The degradant uses gravity to crush an enemy within 100 feet, dealing @Damage[4d6[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:26|basic] save); on a critical failure, the creature takes an additional @Damage[1d6[persistent,bleed]] damage.

action->Graviton Glaive.name: Graviton Glaive
action->Graviton Glaive.description: A degradant wields a solar glaive formed of solidified gravitons. They can conjure and dismiss this weapon as a single action that has the concentrate trait. Whenever they successfully Strike a creature using their graviton glaive, the creature treats all squares adjacent to the square in which it was struck as difficult terrain until the end of the creature's next turn.

action->Stellar Rush.name: Stellar Rush
action->Stellar Rush.description: The degradant Strides twice, gaining a +10-foot circumstance bonus to their Speed during these moves. When they complete these Strides, all enemies within 15 feet of the degradant are pulled 15 feet closer to the degradant unless they succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:26] save.

Hellknight Signifer.name: Hellknight Signifer
Hellknight Signifer.publicNotes:
A Hellknight who displays prowess, scholarly discipline, and magical acumen might attain the rank of signifer.

Hellknights are infernal knights, and while they once ruled entire nations on Lost Golarion, the Hellknights of the Pact Worlds enforce law and order more holistically, traveling in massive citadel starships to spread their influence rather than remaining in any one place. In battle, Hellknights are orderly, unrelenting, and deadly.

spell->Diabolic Pact (DC 22, Doesn't Req.name: Diabolic Pact (DC 22, Doesn't Require Secondary Casters)

weapon->Laser Pistol.name: Laser Pistol
weapon->Laser Pistol.description:
Upgrades: 1

This compact pistol is the most popular sidearm in the Pact Worlds thanks to its reliability, durability, and affordability. Most common laser pistols have a lightweight polycarbon body ending in a long, slim barrel.

armor->Tempweave.name: Tempweave
armor->Tempweave.description:
Upgrades: 1

Tempweave suits are reinforced hooded garments woven with thermal fabric and venting wires, popularly worn for trips to humid climates like the jungles of Castrovel or Pulonis.

equipment->Jump Jets.name: Jump Jets
equipment->Jump Jets.description:
Boosters attached to your armor supercharge your leap.

Activate—Jump 1 (manipulate)

Frequency once per round

Effect You activate the jump jets to get a quick boost. You Fly up to 20 feet with a maximum height of 10 feet, or you Fly up to 20 feet straight up. You must land at the end of this movement or fall. Jump jets can't lift you if you're encumbered.

action->Burn the Unworthy.name: Burn the Unworthy
action->Burn the Unworthy.description: 10 feet. Magical wards cause a signifer's surrounding foes to catch flame. An enemy creature that starts its turn in the area must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:19] save or take @Damage[1d4[persistent,fire]] damage. A signifer can activate and deactivate this aura as a single action that has the concentrate trait. Regardless of the result of the save, the creature is immune to the aura for 1 minute.

action->Proclamation of Guilt.name: Proclamation of Guilt
action->Proclamation of Guilt.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The signifer accuses a target within 60 feet of misdeeds, then attempts an Intimidation check to [[/act demoralize]] them. As long as the target is frightened due to Proclamation of Guilt, it's also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.enA7BxAjBb7ns1iF]{Suppressed}.

action->Reach Spell.name: Reach Spell
action->Reach Spell.description: If the next action the signifer uses is to Cast a Spell that has a range, increase that spell's range by 30 feet.

Hesper.name: Hesper
Hesper.publicNotes: These nuclear fey make their homes in reactors and embody the rapidly changing nature of their radioactive homes. They shift colors to reflect their moods, which can sometimes be used to predict their dangerous bouts of boredom. Hespers never intend malice, but they rarely consider the consequences of their actions.

action->Radiation Sense.name: Radiation Sense
action->Radiation Sense.description: A hesper can sense radiation sources, such as reactors and power cores, as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

action->Mutating Touch.name: Mutating Touch
action->Mutating Touch.description:
A hesper can deliver an enormous, mutating dose of radiation with a touch. Creatures struck by a hesper's fist Strike must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:18] save. On a failure, the creature gains a random mutation from the table below for 1 hour (or 24 hours on a critical failure).

[[/r 1d8]]Mutation
1Extra eyes: Target is dazzled in bright light and gains a +2 status bonus to sight-based Perception checks.
2Bioelectric cells: Tech items held by the target regain all spent charges at the end of the creature's turn. Tech items are glitching 1 for as long as the target holds them. If the target is a creature with the tech trait, it becomes glitching 1, and its melee Strikes deal an additional @Damage[1d6[electricity]] damage.
3Spikes: Target gains an unarmed melee attack that deals @Damage[1d4[piercing]] damage. It takes a –2 status penalty to attack rolls with two-handed weapons.
4Glowing Tumors: Target sheds light as a flashlight and takes a –2 status penalty to Stealth checks.
5Gills: Target gains the amphibious trait and takes a –1 status penalty to Fortitude saves.
6Musk gland: Target gains a 30-foot stench aura with a DC equal to their class DC.
7Protective growths: Target gains a +1 status bonus to AC and takes a –2 status penalty to Dexterity-based checks.
8Cellular alteration: The target is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened} for the duration and gains @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Item.fJSNOw4zHGbIm4bZ]{Fast Healing} with a value equal to half its level (rounded up).

Host Dragon (Adult).name: Host Dragon (Adult)
Host Dragon (Adult).publicNotes: Innumerable insects follow these lumbering, ravenous dragons wherever they roam, swarming around them and living in the countless orifices along the host dragon's body. The dragon is both a part of the swarm itself and a part of the swarm's ecosystem—the swarm feeds on their body, and the dragon feeds on the swarm in a grotesque, centuries-long cycle that somehow results in the host dragon growing larger and more powerful even if they feed on no other substance in their lifetime. Host dragons draw their power from the primal instincts of insects and, despite their intelligence, often behave like the insects they gather to them. Host dragons despise answering questions and violently defy all attempts others make to understand their nature.

action->Covered in Bugs.name: Covered in Bugs
action->Covered in Bugs.description:
Trigger The dragon critically fails a saving throw

Effect Swarming insects interfere with the effect, sacrificing themselves to protect their host's body and mind. The dragon attempts a @Check[flat|dc:17]. On a success, the dragon fails the saving throw instead of critically failing.

action->+2 status to all saves vs. menta.name: +2 status to all saves vs. mental

action->Draconic Frenzy.name: Draconic Frenzy
action->Draconic Frenzy.description: The dragon makes two claw Strikes and one tail Strike in any order.

action->Draconic Momentum.name: Draconic Momentum
action->Draconic Momentum.description: The dragon recharges their Swarm Breath whenever they score a critical hit with a Strike.

action->Excruciating Bites.name: Excruciating Bites
action->Excruciating Bites.description: A creature that takes damage from a host dragon's jaws Strike or is swallowed by the dragon is also bitten by hundreds of tiny insects; the creature must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:28] save or be @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} for 1 round.

action->One with Swarms.name: One with Swarms
action->One with Swarms.description: The host dragon is immune to any attack made by a swarm of insects or similar creature (at the GM's discretion).

action->Swarm Breath.name: Swarm Breath
action->Swarm Breath.description: The dragon disgorges a swarm of biting insects that deals @Damage[9d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:cone|distance:40] (@Check[reflex|dc:30|basic] save). They can't use Swarm Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Swarm Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Swarm Shape.name: Swarm Shape
action->Swarm Shape.description: The dragon transforms into an insect swarm. They drop all held, worn, and carried items. While in this form, they can't use attack actions (except Swarming Bites and Swarm Breath) and can't cast spells, but they can move through areas small enough for their individual insects to fit without having to Squeeze. They can use the same action to coalesce back into their normal form.

action->Swarming Bites.name: Swarming Bites
action->Swarming Bites.description:
Requirements The dragon is a swarm

Effect Each enemy in the swarm's space takes @Damage[8d6[piercing]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:30|basic] save). A creature that fails its save is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} for 1 round.

Host Dragon (Adult, Spellcaster).publicNotes: Innumerable insects follow these lumbering, ravenous dragons wherever they roam, swarming around them and living in the countless orifices along the host dragon's body. action->Fast Swallow.name: Fast Swallow
action->Fast Swallow.description:
Trigger The dragon Grabs a creature

Effect The dragon uses Swallow Whole.

They can't use Swarm Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Swarm Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

Ichor Lord.name: Ichor Lord
Ichor Lord.publicNotes:
Orocoran ichor lords are blessed by the Newborn—ichor flows through their veins, and they can conjure short-lived fonts of ichor. Most gather desperate orocorans around them, controlling their brethren through access to ichor.

Native to the now-destroyed planet of Aucturn, orocorans are foul and desperate creatures, cast adrift in space as they yearn to consume once more the essence of the Newborn god or fragments of the womb it gestated within. They're irritable, violent, and utterly anguished.

While some orocorans have broken free of their addiction and regained their clarity of mind and sense of self, the orocorans presented here are those who still rely on Aucturn's eldritch fluids.
Ichor Lord.languagesDetails: Common cant speak any languages, Telepathy 100 feet

weapon->Aucturnite Chakram.name: Aucturnite Chakram
weapon->Aucturnite Chakram.description:
Upgrades: 1

This bladed hoop is carved from a chunk of aucturnite and sculpted to resemble a planet's ring. The material has mysteriously appeared light-years from Aucturn's original orbit.

action->Ichor Spray.name: Ichor Spray
action->Ichor Spray.description:
Trigger The ichor lord is dealt piercing or slashing damage

Effect Hallucinogenic ichor spurts from the ichor lord's wound, dealing @Damage[1d6[mental]|options:area-damage] damage to non-orocoran creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] centered on the ichor lord (@Check[will|dc:28|basic] save).

action->Hallucinate.name: Hallucinate
action->Hallucinate.description:
An orocoran's stomach fluids are laced with hallucinogens due to their consumption of the ichor-like birthing fluids expelled by Aucturn during the hatching of the Newborn.

A creature hit with the projectile vomit must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:28] save or be @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for 1 round (1d4 rounds on a critical failure).

action->Ichor Wellspring.name: Ichor Wellspring
action->Ichor Wellspring.description:
Requirements The ichor lord is touching solid ground

Frequency once per hour

Effect With a psychic cry to the Newborn, the ichor lord tears open the earth, causing a geyser of hallucinogenic ichor to burst from the ground within 100 feet. This geyser occupies a 50-foot-tall cylinder with a 10-foot radius base. The base of this geyser must be on the ground or a similar solid surface, and the geyser must be oriented vertically. Each creature in the area takes @Damage[4d6[bludgeoning],4d6[mental]|options:area-damage]{4d6 bludgeoning damage and 4d6 mental damage}, with a @Check[reflex|dc:28] save. A creature pushed into the air by the geyser can't be pushed beyond the top of the geyser. After being pushed into the air, a creature falls unless it's flying, is in zero gravity, or has some other means of staying aloft in its current environment, taking falling damage as normal.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes half damage and isn't pushed into the air.

Failure The creature takes full damage and is pushed 20 feet into the air.

Critical Failure The creature takes double damage and is pushed 40 feet into the air. The geyser continues to flow for 1 minute, gently raining ichor in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] centered on the geyser's base. An orocoran in the area of this rain can drink the ichor once per round as a single action with the manipulate trait; if they do, they become invigorated, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to damage rolls and resistance 5 to physical damage until the beginning of their next turn.

action->Lick Wounds.name: Lick Wounds
action->Lick Wounds.description:
Frequency once per round

Requirements A creature within reach of the orocoran's proboscis is taking persistent bleed damage

Effect The orocoran flicks out their proboscis and sups on the flowing blood of their enemy. The orocoran regains Hit Points equal to the target's persistent bleed value.

Ignurso.name: Ignurso
Ignurso.publicNotes:
Adventurers exploring active geothermal areas might encounter one of the extreme habitat's most unique creatures: ignursos. These ursine burrowers are partially armored with scales and a fearsome horn. They're sedentary by nature, but when disturbed, their rage combines the ferocity of a bear mauling with the heat of a pyroclastic flow.

Ignursos are specially adapted to survive in extremely hot climates but thrive anywhere warm. Those that inhabit less hospitable planets tend to stay underground and hibernate during the coldest parts of the year.

Scavengers by nature, ignursos can't take their next meal for granted. However, these clever creatures can manipulate their environment to trap prey. Ignursos have been observed creating large networks of burrows right before volcanic eruptions, seemingly because they understand lava flows will follow this path of least resistance. These tunnels turn to rivers of red-hot lava perfectly positioned to strand fleeing wildlife. Ignursos then return for their spoils after the worst of the eruption has passed.

Ignursos have a significant impact on volcanic ecosystems. Burrowing ignursos break up solid rock—often freshly deposited after an eruption—kick-starting the process of soil formation that's necessary for the return of plants. Some dig too close to underground magma chambers, turning their tunnels into volcanic vents that release lava and gases. In this way, they make explosive, damaging eruptions much less likely and provide a moderating force on a harsh environment.

action->Smoke Vision.name: Smoke Vision
action->Smoke Vision.description: The ignurso ignores the @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition from smoke.

action->Lavaproof.name: Lavaproof
action->Lavaproof.description: The ignurso is immune environmental fire damage and fatigue from to heat and lava

action->Thermal Venting.name: Thermal Venting
action->Thermal Venting.description: 20 feet. The ignurso is shrouded in a cloud of smoke and ash. Creatures within the aura are @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}, and creatures outside it are concealed to creatures within. The ignurso can deactivate or activate this aura as a single action, which has the concentrate trait.

action->Mauler.name: Mauler
action->Mauler.description: The ignurso gains a +3 circumstance bonus to damage rolls against creatures it has @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}.

action->Spew Lava.name: Spew Lava
action->Spew Lava.description: The ignurso expels lava in a @Template[type:cone|distance:30], dealing @Damage[6d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:20|basic] save). A creature that fails its save also takes @Damage[1d6[persistent,fire]|options:area-damage] damage. The ignurso can't Spew Lava again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Spew Lava]]{1d4 rounds}.

Illumantula.name: Illumantula
Illumantula.publicNotes:
Though it only recently appeared in the shattered red deserts of the planet Akiton, the so-called illumantula has already become the stuff of local legend and folklore. Emerging shortly after the crash of the mysterious First Ones vessel now only known as the Wreck of the Returned, the illumantula was so named by the shobhad desert guides who first encountered the creature and compared it to the deadly spiders of the Akitonian glaciers. Other Pact Worlds citizens have taken to the name, as the closest descriptive title for the being has simply been "a spider made of light."

Content—for now—to spend its days wandering the Wreck of the Returned and the immediately surrounding area, the illumantula has only had a handful of meaningful engagements since its appearance. The first was against a group of Hellknights of the Order of the Eclipse, where the illumantula systematically unmade 80 of their best-trained troops in under two minutes. Only weeks after the engagement, a group of Stewards attempting to enter the Wreck of the Returned were discovered and engaged at the periphery of the illumantula's patrol path. Only two of 12 commandos managed to escape, and their accounts of the illumantula and its powers are contradictory, leaving the Stewards unable to make effective plans for further encounters.

A strict quarantine has been set up to match the illumantula's patrol path, as calculated by the meticulous anacites of Investigation Site A01. The Aballonian constructs know the being to be related to the First Ones and dedicate their time to finding a means of communicating with the swarm of technological bits that patrol the outer wastes of the crashed starship. So far, they've had no success, and they've sent out an urgent call for linguistics and computers experts from across the Pact Worlds to travel to Akiton and aid their research.

Where the anacites continue their experiments, scholars of Eloritu have uncovered a disturbing connection between the illumantula and the concept of alternate realities. Somehow, the actions of the illumantula produce fixed points in reality, where the unique powers of creatures with greater connections to the multiverse are somehow stymied or forced to adhere to the illumantula's will. The reason for this phenomenon remains a mystery, though one the anacites seem blissfully ignorant to explore.

The appearance of the illumantula has led to the belief that it's a protector for the ancient technology of the mysterious First Ones. Similarities between the illumantula's technological bits and extracted data from Aballon have all but confirmed this theory. However, the association begs the question: is there just one illumantula, or is it merely one of many such highly advanced guardian constructs for the First Ones, a species who might be beyond anything the Pact Worlds could contend with?
Illumantula.languagesDetails: First one, Can't speak, Telepathy 300 feet

effect->Spell Effect: Unfettered Movemen.name: Spell Effect: Unfettered Movement
effect->Spell Effect: Unfettered Movemen.description:
Granted by @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.spells.Item.aqRYNoSvxsVfqglH]{Unfettered Movement}

You ignore circumstance penalties to your Speed.

action->Mutable Form.name: Mutable Form
action->Mutable Form.description: The illumantula is a grouping of tiny tech bits that project energy between themselves, though the illumantula functions as single creature. The illumantula's size gives its space while being fully dispersed, though it can take actions to change its size. The illumantula can occupy the same space as other creatures and must do so to use some of its actions.

action->Reactive Unmaking.name: Reactive Unmaking
action->Reactive Unmaking.description:
Trigger A creature moves within the illumantula's space or uses a manipulate action, move action, or ranged attack within 100 feet of the illumantula

Effect The illumantula attempts a ranged Strike against the triggering creature. If the attack is a critical hit and the trigger was a manipulate action, the illumantula disrupts that action. This Strike doesn't count toward the illumantula's multiple attack penalty, and its multiple attack penalty doesn't apply to this Strike.

action->Relativity Field.name: Relativity Field
action->Relativity Field.description: Creatures sharing a space with the illumantula can't use any actions or abilities with the fortune trait. A creature beginning its turn within the illumantula's space can't use actions or ability with the fortune trait until the end of their turn. The illumantula has weakness 10 against any ability or action affected by the fortune trait that successfully damages it.

action->Energy Bombardment.name: Energy Bombardment
action->Energy Bombardment.description: The illumantula releases coordinated blasts from each of its constituent bits at creatures within its form. Each enemy in the illumantula's space takes @Damage[12d8[electricity]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:49|basic] save). A creature that fails its save is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round (or 1 minute on a critical failure). The blinding is a visual effect.

action->Reform.name: Reform
action->Reform.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The illumantula changes its size to either Huge, Large or Medium as desired. When changing size in this manner, the illumantula can determine what direction its new space takes up or what portion of its existing space is removed. This movement doesn't trigger reactions.

action->Unreality Engine.name: Unreality Engine
action->Unreality Engine.description: When the illumantula scores a critical hit with a transreality beam Strike, the target becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.3uh1r86TzbQvosxv]{Doomed 1}, or increases its doomed value by 1 if it was already doomed.

Iridia.name: Iridia
Iridia.publicNotes:
When mortals encounter spectra outside the drift, that encounter is usually with an iridia. These opalescent, bipedal ambassadors travel the cosmos as messengers and agents of the Drift, extolling the benefits of new and emergent technologies. They champion growth and improvement in all aspects of life but especially focus on the advancement of new technologies. Their goals often put them at odds with those who forswear controversial and dangerous tech or who approach new and untested discoveries with caution.

Iridias are known to visit remote worlds in the Vast, far away from Absalom Station and the Drift lanes where Triune's original signal and the secrets of Drift travel were suppressed, lost, or misunderstood. They bring the people of these isolated worlds instructions to achieve interstellar travel and a second chance to join the galactic community.

In the Great Beyond, time is measured not in hundreds, thousands, or millions of years, but rather in eons—in iterations of reality itself. Only rising to prominence within the last three centuries alongside the advent and proliferation of Drift technology, spectra have thrived in a burgeoning niche of the otherwise stagnant zeitgeist of the Great Beyond.

Though their origins and objectives remain shrouded in mystery, encounters with spectra revolve around new technological discoveries, sharing the knowledge of faster-than-light travel, and protecting the Drift. No one knows if spectra existed before the Drift, but their connection to the hyperspace plane is indisputable. Prominent metaphysicians believe spectra were created as amalgams of raw quintessence pulled into the Drift, just as the Drift itself grows from pieces of the Multiverse. If this is true, spectra's interest in the proliferation of Drift technology takes a subtle sinister turn, as each new Drift engine serves to harvest the Great Beyond and all its denizens for the growth of the Drift and spectra themselves.
Iridia.languagesDetails: Arc network, Digital telepathy, Truespeech, Can't speak any language

action->Arc Network.name: Arc Network
action->Arc Network.description: The iridia can communicate through items and creatures with the tech trait, projecting sound from and speaking through the item or creature's voice, speakers, or other audio output. In addition, the excuba can use any item or creature with the tech trait within their digital telepathy aura as the point of origin for their spells and abilities when calculating range, distance, line of effect, and area of effect.

action->Slip Drive.name: Slip Drive
action->Slip Drive.description: An iridia has an internal biomechanical Drift engine, allowing them to function as a Drift engine for a starship or vehicle they pilot as a 1-minute activity. An excuba can enter or exit the Drift themself as a 1-minute activity. When an excuba gets a critical failure on a Piloting check to Navigate or Plot a Course through the Drift, they get a failure instead.

action->Techsense.name: Techsense
action->Techsense.description: The iridia senses creatures and objects with the tech trait as a precise sense within the listed range.

action->Digital Telepathy.name: Digital Telepathy
action->Digital Telepathy.description: 100 feet. An iridia can communicate telepathically with any item or creature with the tech trait within their aura as well as with other technologically telepathic creatures (such as those with shortwave and similar abilities). This ability also allows the spectra to remotely attempt Computers checks within their aura.

action->Shift Dimensionality.name: Shift Dimensionality
action->Shift Dimensionality.description:
Frequency once per round

Trigger The iridia is targeted by a ranged Strike

Effect A rainbow of visual distortion cascades across the iridia. They desynchronize from reality and are briefly replaced by a two-dimensional rendering, gaining concealment against the triggering Strike.

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description:
The excuba can take on the appearance of any Small or Medium humanoid.

@Localize[PF2E.NPC.Abilities.Glossary.ChangeShape]

Irradiated Undead Charger.name: Irradiated Undead Charger
Irradiated Undead Charger.publicNotes:
Chargers, known by as many different names as their planets of origin, usually spawn from the irradiated corpses of beasts slain by natural or manufactured nuclear disasters. These quadrupedal, animalistic undead are so named for their mighty charge attack.

To survive in the unforgiving expanse of space, creatures must be naturally adapted or take protective measures. While the dead rarely need such precautions against these threats, sometimes radiation can animate a corpse (or several) to a state of undeath!

Scientists and religious scholars alike debate whether a specific type of radiation is to blame for this phenomenon that spontaneously triggers unlife, but all agree on the dangers such irradiated creatures pose. Many types of radiation could be the cause: intense bursts of cosmic radiation emitted by the stars, magically enhanced radioactive isotopes found in a planet's or moon's crust, or even the advent of new energy sources in a society (or its radioactive waste) contaminating the land. Regardless of their specific origin, irradiated undead all pose the same threat—they emit ionizing radiation that ravages everything around them.

action->Meltdown.name: Meltdown
action->Meltdown.description:
Trigger The irradiated undead plant is reduced to 0 Hit Points by energy damage of any kind

Effect The energy acts as a catalyst for a nuclear reaction, causing the plant to explode and dealing @Damage[9d6[poison]|options:area-damage] damage to all creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] with a @Check[reflex|dc:24|basic] save.

action->Radioactive Remains.name: Radioactive Remains
action->Radioactive Remains.description: 20 feet. A creature entering or starting its turn inside the aura is exposed to extreme radiation.

action->Charged Burst.name: Charged Burst
action->Charged Burst.description: The irradiated charger triggers a localized radioactive reaction as it charges. It Strides once and then Strikes. A creature damaged by this attack takes 1 additional point of void damage for every space the charger moved prior to making its Strike. On a critical hit, the creature is also knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Irradiated Undead Flyer.name: Irradiated Undead Flyer
Irradiated Undead Flyer.publicNotes:
Flyer is a general term referring to winged creatures such as drakes, gigantic dragonflies, raptors, and other flying beasts that have been reanimated by severe radiation.

To survive in the unforgiving expanse of space, creatures must be naturally adapted or take protective measures. While the dead rarely need such precautions against these threats, sometimes radiation can animate a corpse (or several) to a state of undeath!

Scientists and religious scholars alike debate whether a specific type of radiation is to blame for this phenomenon that spontaneously triggers unlife, but all agree on the dangers such irradiated creatures pose. Many types of radiation could be the cause: intense bursts of cosmic radiation emitted by the stars, magically enhanced radioactive isotopes found in a planet's or moon's crust, or even the advent of new energy sources in a society (or its radioactive waste) contaminating the land. Regardless of their specific origin, irradiated undead all pose the same threat—they emit ionizing radiation that ravages everything around them.

action->Meltdown.name: Meltdown
action->Meltdown.description:
Trigger The irradiated undead plant is reduced to 0 Hit Points by energy damage of any kind

Effect The energy acts as a catalyst for a nuclear reaction, causing the plant to explode and dealing @Damage[5d6[poison]|options:area-damage] damage to all creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] with a @Check[reflex|dc:19|basic] save.

action->Radioactive Remains.name: Radioactive Remains
action->Radioactive Remains.description: 20 feet. A creature entering or starting its turn inside the aura is exposed to severe radiation.

action->Strafing Snap.name: Strafing Snap
action->Strafing Snap.description: The irradiated undead flyer Strides twice up to its Speed in a straight line, making a single wing slash Strike against all creatures whose spaces it flies adjacent to. All creatures damaged by the Strafing Snap are considered to be within the flyer's aura at the start of their next turn. The flyer can't use Strafing Snap again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Strafing Snap]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Wing Spasm.name: Wing Spasm
action->Wing Spasm.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The irradiated undead flyer channels energy into its wings, forcing all creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] to attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:19] save.

Critical Success No effect.

Success The creature takes @Damage[1d8[void]|options:area-damage] damage.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[2d8[void]|options:area-damage] damage and is pushed back 5 feet.

Critical Failure The creature takes @Damage[4d8[void]|options:area-damage] damage and is pushed back 10 feet.

Irradiated Undead Plant.name: Irradiated Undead Plant
Irradiated Undead Plant.publicNotes:
Flora are often the first victims of industrialization, dying petal by petal and blade of grass at a time before anybody even notices a loss of habitat. When nuclear fallout corrupts the hardiest species of vegetation, sometimes their irradiated seeds inexplicably bloom into new, unliving specimens.

To survive in the unforgiving expanse of space, creatures must be naturally adapted or take protective measures. While the dead rarely need such precautions against these threats, sometimes radiation can animate a corpse (or several) to a state of undeath!

Scientists and religious scholars alike debate whether a specific type of radiation is to blame for this phenomenon that spontaneously triggers unlife, but all agree on the dangers such irradiated creatures pose. Many types of radiation could be the cause: intense bursts of cosmic radiation emitted by the stars, magically enhanced radioactive isotopes found in a planet's or moon's crust, or even the advent of new energy sources in a society (or its radioactive waste) contaminating the land. Regardless of their specific origin, irradiated undead all pose the same threat—they emit ionizing radiation that ravages everything around them.

action->Meltdown.name: Meltdown
action->Meltdown.description:
Trigger The irradiated undead plant is reduced to 0 Hit Points by energy damage of any kind

Effect The energy acts as a catalyst for a nuclear reaction, causing the plant to explode and dealing @Damage[3d6[poison]|options:area-damage] damage to all creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] with a @Check[reflex|dc:16|basic] save.

action->Radioactive Remains.name: Radioactive Remains
action->Radioactive Remains.description: 20 feet. A creature entering or starting its turn inside the aura is exposed to mild radiation.

action->Seedpod.name: Seedpod
action->Seedpod.description: When a irradiated undead plant Strikes a creature, some of its contaminated seeds stick to the target. The irradiated undead plant gains the Sprout action. An affected creature can remove this seedpod as an Interact action.

action->Sprout.name: Sprout
action->Sprout.description:
Requirements One or more creatures within 60 feet of the irradiated undead plant are currently host to at least one seedpod

Effect The irradiated undead plant pulses with energy, causing the seedpods to sprout vines. Creatures hosting a seedpod must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:16] save.

Critical Success No effect.

Success The creature takes @Damage[1d6[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage.

Failure The creature takes @Damage[2d6[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The creature takes @Damage[2d6[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage, is slowed 2 for 1 round, and is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} until it [[/act escape dc=16]]{Escapes}. Until it Escapes, the creature is a new source of the irradiated undead plant's radioactive remains aura with a @Template[type:emanation|distance:5].

Jinchori Endling.name: Jinchori Endling
Jinchori Endling.publicNotes:
Jinchoris were sinuous quadrupedal reptiles that dug tunnel systems through the desert world of Priori-8. Their iridescent scales grew into dense armored plates, protecting them from the hunters who sought their brilliant frills as fashion accessories. Poachers started flooding jinchori tunnels with poison gas in a method that proved all too effective and wiped the species out. Years after, visitors to Priori-8 spy gleaming wyrms stalking them through caves and tunnels, and poachers die choking on spectral poison.

Every species follows a natural arc as it emerges and evolves: rising, thriving, declining, and falling into extinction. When extremely unnatural ends to these paths occur—when unexpected predation, industrialization, or alien pathogens wipe out a population—endlings are born. These spectral members of extinct species typically develop as "answers" to their eradication. Xenobiologists differ on what creates endlings, unable to confirm whether the creatures are a species' last collective sorrow made manifest or just vengeful individual spirits—the last lights to go out.

action->Huntersight.name: Huntersight
action->Huntersight.description: A jinchori can sense the presence of any creature wielding weapons as a precise sense at the listed range.

action->Rejuvenation.name: Rejuvenation
action->Rejuvenation.description: When an endling is destroyed, it reforms after [[/gmr 2d4 #days]]{2d4 days} within the area where it first emerged, fully healed. An endling can be permanently destroyed only if someone determines the reason for its existence and sets right whatever prevents the spirit from resting, such as an act of decolonization, ecological restoration, or curing the disease responsible for its extinction.

action->Noxious Breath.name: Noxious Breath
action->Noxious Breath.description: The jinchori endling floods the air with toxic fumes, dealing @Damage[4d12[poison]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:cone|distance:30] (@Check[fortitude|dc:22|basic] save). A creature that fails its save is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} on a critical failure). The jinchori can't use Noxious Breath again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Noxious Breath]]{1d4 rounds}.

Jinsul Pontiff.name: Jinsul Pontiff
Jinsul Pontiff.publicNotes:
Pontiffs rally jinsuls to a near suicidal frenzy in the throes of combat. Part magic wielder and part orator, they act as inspirational battlefield leaders. Each serves one of the major jinsul hierarchs, who in turn act as the leaders of the overall Jinsul Hierocracy.

Jinsuls are a warlike species scattered across the Vast. Six-legged creatures with a bulbous body covered in eyes, jinsuls have notable segments of chitin along with a set of upper forelimbs for using equipment. They long ago lived in the region of space known as the Scoured Stars but eventually departed and settled on the harsh world of Rax. In recent years, the divine herald Dhurus unified the jinsuls into a cohesive force known as the Jinsul Hierocracy, which briefly retook the Scoured Stars. A joint alliance between several species and members of the Starfinder Society defeated Dhurus and scattered the jinsuls back into the Vast.

With countless bases and fleets operating in deep space, jinsuls mostly act as raiders, scavenging for equipment and testing their mettle against other species. Indoctrinated to view themselves as a superior species, with only other inhabitants of the Scoured Stars having any value, jinsuls prefer to engage in short-ranged combat with their foes.

Jinsuls aren't numerous enough to fill every need on the many ships and starbases they control across the galaxy. Instead, they rely on robots and automated computer systems (always commanded by at least one jinsul officer) to keep their space stations running efficiently. These systems are programmed to be just as deadly and ruthless as jinsuls themselves; even the most innocuous automated system or robot, like a garbage collector, might wield deadly weapons or contain vicious technomagical countermeasures.

weapon->Laser Pistol.name: Laser Pistol
weapon->Laser Pistol.description:
Upgrades: 1

This compact pistol is the most popular sidearm in the Pact Worlds thanks to its reliability, durability, and affordability. Most common laser pistols have a lightweight polycarbon body ending in a long, slim barrel.

action->Vitality Network.name: Vitality Network
action->Vitality Network.description: A jinsul pontiff can channel vitality to up to four bonded allies as though they were a mystic. This network stores up to @Damage[20[healing]] Hit Points and begins combat full.

action->Fill Vitality.name: Fill Vitality
action->Fill Vitality.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The jinsul pontiff restores @Damage[6[healing]] Hit Points to their vitality network, up to its maximum.

action->Strider Leap.name: Strider Leap
action->Strider Leap.description: The jinsul Strides and then performs a [[/act long-jump]]. They can Stride less than 10 feet and not automatically fail their check to Long Jump.

action->Transfer Vitality.name: Transfer Vitality
action->Transfer Vitality.description: The jinsul pontiff transfers any number of Hit Points from their vitality network to a visible bonded target.

Jinsul Trooper.name: Jinsul Trooper
Jinsul Trooper.publicNotes:
The lowest ranked jinsuls in a warband are the subordinate troopers. These jinsuls prove themselves by hurtling toward the enemy, discharging weapons, and closing with their vicious leg blades. Those troopers who survive long enough are recognized and promoted through the harsh jinsul military lifestyle.

Jinsuls are a warlike species scattered across the Vast. Six-legged creatures with a bulbous body covered in eyes, jinsuls have notable segments of chitin along with a set of upper forelimbs for using equipment. They long ago lived in the region of space known as the Scoured Stars but eventually departed and settled on the harsh world of Rax. In recent years, the divine herald Dhurus unified the jinsuls into a cohesive force known as the Jinsul Hierocracy, which briefly retook the Scoured Stars. A joint alliance between several species and members of the Starfinder Society defeated Dhurus and scattered the jinsuls back into the Vast.

With countless bases and fleets operating in deep space, jinsuls mostly act as raiders, scavenging for equipment and testing their mettle against other species. Indoctrinated to view themselves as a superior species, with only other inhabitants of the Scoured Stars having any value, jinsuls prefer to engage in short-ranged combat with their foes.

Jinsuls aren't numerous enough to fill every need on the many ships and starbases they control across the galaxy. Instead, they rely on robots and automated computer systems (always commanded by at least one jinsul officer) to keep their space stations running efficiently. These systems are programmed to be just as deadly and ruthless as jinsuls themselves; even the most innocuous automated system or robot, like a garbage collector, might wield deadly weapons or contain vicious technomagical countermeasures.

weapon->Laser Rifle.name: Laser Rifle
weapon->Laser Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

These dependable, mass-produced rifles shoot concentrated beams of energy out of square-shaped barrels. The universal standard Pact Worlds model is highly modifiable and designed to function with a variety of accessories and upgrades, with wielders adapting the laser rifle to their preferences and even kit-bashing it into a nearly unrecognizable weapon.

action->Strider Leap.name: Strider Leap
action->Strider Leap.description: The jinsul Strides and then performs a [[/act long-jump]]. They can Stride less than 10 feet and not automatically fail their check to Long Jump.

Jinsul Warblooded.name: Jinsul Warblooded
Jinsul Warblooded.publicNotes:
Warblooded are jinsuls who have survived at least a half-dozen engagements in service to the Jinsul Hierocracy. They take on roles of minor leadership or as elite sharpshooters and commandos in a unit of other jinsuls. Warblooded often elect to sit out of engagements that they deem "beneath" them, opting to train up or observe fights from a distance unless they need to step in as reinforcements. These jinsuls often use their extra training time to learn how to pick out critical foes in a battle.

Jinsuls are a warlike species scattered across the Vast. Six-legged creatures with a bulbous body covered in eyes, jinsuls have notable segments of chitin along with a set of upper forelimbs for using equipment. They long ago lived in the region of space known as the Scoured Stars but eventually departed and settled on the harsh world of Rax. In recent years, the divine herald Dhurus unified the jinsuls into a cohesive force known as the Jinsul Hierocracy, which briefly retook the Scoured Stars. A joint alliance between several species and members of the Starfinder Society defeated Dhurus and scattered the jinsuls back into the Vast.

With countless bases and fleets operating in deep space, jinsuls mostly act as raiders, scavenging for equipment and testing their mettle against other species. Indoctrinated to view themselves as a superior species, with only other inhabitants of the Scoured Stars having any value, jinsuls prefer to engage in short-ranged combat with their foes.

Jinsuls aren't numerous enough to fill every need on the many ships and starbases they control across the galaxy. Instead, they rely on robots and automated computer systems (always commanded by at least one jinsul officer) to keep their space stations running efficiently. These systems are programmed to be just as deadly and ruthless as jinsuls themselves; even the most innocuous automated system or robot, like a garbage collector, might wield deadly weapons or contain vicious technomagical countermeasures.

weapon->Arc Rifle.name: Arc Rifle
weapon->Arc Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

This rifle's oversized body contains a larger version of an arc pistol capacitor, with a short barrel and polycarbon stock designed to insulate the wielder from high voltage. The arc rifle's larger capacitor allows it to produce a charge with enough power to subdue a rampaging renkroda.

action->Aim.name: Aim
action->Aim.description: The jinsul aims with their melee or ranged weapon against a target within 60 feet. For the rest of their turn, successful Strikes made with that weapon deal an additional 1d4 precision damage and reduce the target's cover bonus to AC by 1.

action->Strider Leap.name: Strider Leap
action->Strider Leap.description: The jinsul Strides and then performs a [[/act long-jump]]. They can Stride less than 10 feet and not automatically fail their check to Long Jump.

Juvenile Nyssholora.name: Juvenile Nyssholora
Juvenile Nyssholora.publicNotes:
Despite their age, juvenile nyssholoras remain dangerous and formidable predators.

Incredibly ferocious, nyssholoras are dinosaur-like creatures that number among the most dangerous and feared apex predators on the planet of Castrovel. These walking weapons brandish lethal biology: a massive maw lined with twin rows of razor-sharp teeth, scythe-shaped phasic blade forearms that vibrate at ultrasonic speeds, and a scourge-like tail capable of absorbing electricity from the surrounding atmosphere. Yet, nyssholoras are also cunning and perceptive—a frill of tentacles that crowns their head detect telepathic signals, making it impossible for the local formians and lashuntas to escape their notice. Their phasic blades can cut through walls and vehicles as easily as underbrush, ensuring prey have nowhere safe to hide.

action->Telepathy Sense.name: Telepathy Sense
action->Telepathy Sense.description: A nyssholora senses all creatures that have telepathy, limited telepathy, or a similar ability, such as a mystic's bond, as an imprecise sense at the listed range. This sense works through walls and other obstacles.

action->Crunch.name: Crunch
action->Crunch.description:
Frequency once per round

Requirements A creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} in the nyssholora's jaws

Effect The nyssholora chomps down on the creature, dealing @Damage[(1d8+7)[piercing]] damage.

action->Discordant Bellow.name: Discordant Bellow
action->Discordant Bellow.description: The nyssholora unleashes a blast of discordant sound that deal @Damage[5d6[sonic]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:cone|distance:30] (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic] save). Objects and constructs in the area are treated as if they had half as much Hardness as usual. Creatures that critically fail their saving throw are also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round. The nyssholora can't use Discordant Bellow again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Discordant Bellow]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Phasic Strike.name: Phasic Strike
action->Phasic Strike.description: A nyssholora's phasic blade Strike treats any object or construct it hits as if the target had half as much Hardness as usual.

Jygyk.name: Jygyk
Jygyk.publicNotes:
Jygyks embody remorseless revenge, stalking mortals and slaying them at great distances. Three legs create the unflinching stability needed for their sniper shots, and lenslike eyes scope out their prey up to 2 miles away.

Jygyks become obsessed with their intended victims and have the capacity to nurse intense grudges against dozens of mortals at once. A fresh jygyk might begin by targeting people they hated in their mortal life or seek victims who match a certain profile.

Jygyks move cautiously, typically stalking their targets for weeks, memorizing movement patterns and noting routines, to pinpoint the ideal time and place to strike. Close-range combat can prove disastrous for them, so they prioritize fleeing if confronted in close quarters.

All mortal creatures have souls that are usually judged in the Boneyard after their demise. The souls of individuals who lived sinful lives—usually by hurting others or acting selfishly—are sent to the Outer Rifts, where they eventually coalesce into demons. These fiends care for nothing but the corruption of mortal life to ensure that the ranks of their fellow demons never wane.

weapon->Assassin Rifle.name: Assassin Rifle
weapon->Assassin Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

This sniper rifle breaks down into small parts, allowing its wielder to smuggle the weapon without attracting attention. Most assassin rifles are equipped with powerful scopes and digital sights.

action->Mental Fragility.name: Mental Fragility
action->Mental Fragility.description: While a jygyk embodies remorseless vengeance, they can't fathom being attacked in kind. If a creature critically hits a jygyk who damaged it on the jygyk's previous turn, the jygyk takes @Damage[3d6[mental]] damage.

action->Expert Sharpshooter.name: Expert Sharpshooter
action->Expert Sharpshooter.description: The jygyk doubles the range increment of weapons in the sniper weapon group they wield. If they're ever unarmed or out of ammunition, they can Interact to create an tactical weapon in the sniper weapon group or 30 projectiles.

action->Fade To Nothing.name: Fade To Nothing
action->Fade To Nothing.description: The jygyk melts into their surroundings and becomes undetected, not even emitting sound or odor. A creature must succeed at a @Check[perception|dc:25] check to [[/act seek]] the jygyk. If the jygyk uses a hostile action, moves, or speaks, they become detected again after the action is completed.

action->Focus Aim.name: Focus Aim
action->Focus Aim.description: The jygyk takes careful aim at a target. If the jygyk's next action is to make a ranged Strike with a weapon in the sniper weapon group, that Strike deals an additional weapon die of damage.

action->Reposition.name: Reposition
action->Reposition.description:
Frequency once per round

Trigger The jygyk's last action was a ranged Strike

Effect The jygyk teleports to any location they can see within 25 feet.

Karkono.name: Karkono
Karkono.publicNotes:
These feral guardians protect the lands they roam, growing into a chimera of all the predators living in their native ecosystems. Karkonos thrive and perish with their bonded lands. They instinctively sense when synthetic forces like pollution or rapid industrialization imperil their homes. Any injury to the land is mirrored by the karkonos who dwell there. Aggressive deforestation appears as festering wounds on a karkono's hide, while pollution manifests as sickness.

Rather than die quietly, when their ecosystem is endangered by outside causes, these fey go on destructive rampages. Visitors to the wilderness might never spot a content karkono, but a raging karkono assaults anything alien to their home—including machinery, other life-forms, and synthetic infrastructure. Enraged karkonos purge their home of threats or perish, but not before dealing tremendous damage to their enemies.

If karkonos spill enough blood, they can gradually repair their ailing ecosystems. Those killed by karkonos become fertilizer for the animals and plants they would've crushed beneath the uncaring gears of industrial expansion.

action->Nature's Protector.name: Nature's Protector
action->Nature's Protector.description: A karkono is intrinsically tied to a specific ecosystem, such as a coastal marsh or boreal forest on a planet. A karkono ignores difficult terrain and gains a +1 status bonus to initiative rolls while in their ecosystem. When a karkono's ecosystem is polluted or significantly damaged (for example, due to a forest fire or chemical spill), the karkono is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} and can't reduce their sickened condition below 1. They also gain a +4 status bonus to damage rolls.

action->Back To Nature.name: Back To Nature
action->Back To Nature.description:
Frequency once per round

Effect The karkono makes a claw Strike against a creature with the tech trait, causing plant matter to explode from it. On a hit, the creature must attempt a @Check[reflex|dc:24] save; on a critical hit, the creature uses the outcome one degree of success worse than the result of its roll.

Failure The creature becomes glitching 1.

Critical Failure The creature becomes glitching 2.

action->Blood Renewal.name: Blood Renewal
action->Blood Renewal.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The karkono performs a ritual to anoint the land in fresh blood. Plant growth springs from the ground in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20], counting as difficult terrain. The karkono and any allied creatures within the area gain regeneration 15 (cold iron) while in the area. These effects last for 10 minutes.

@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.qj97oOs2Z2qk9w00]{Effect: Blood Renewal}

Kaukariki.name: Kaukariki
Kaukariki.publicNotes:
The poison that laces the barbed tails of the sharp-eared kaukarikis gives them their local nickname, "stingbats." Thriving in the canopies of warm forests and living in small to large packs, often called clamors, kaukarikis sustain themselves primarily on a mix of toxic and semi-rotten fruit and the occasional venomous insect. While most of their food is poisonous to other creatures, kaukarikis have evolved to turn this poison into a defense mechanism. Their bodies will process poison and store it in a sac at the end of their tail under their stinger. They can then inject this newly created venom into hostile creatures that threaten their pack.

Kaukariki clamors are known to use their distinct vocalizations to ward off predators and would-be intruders. When one kaukariki detects a possible threat, they'll let out a trilling whoop, the sound that gives them their name. This signal alerts other nearby kaukarikis, who answer with cries of their own, the cacophony quickly growing in intensity and volume as kaukarikis leap from tree to tree shouting and shrieking. For most predators, the thought of the stinging tails at the other end of those screeches is enough to turn them away, with many clamors relying on this tactic as much as their stingers.

action->Kaukariki Venom.name: Kaukariki Venom
action->Kaukariki Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:15]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d4[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[2d4[poison]] damage and clumsy 2 (1 round)

action->Screaming Frenzy.name: Screaming Frenzy
action->Screaming Frenzy.description: The kaukariki starts a frenzy of screaming, involving other nearby kaukarikis. The kaukariki attempts a single Intimidation check to [[/act demoralize]] all enemies within 30 feet. Any other kaukariki within 30 feet can use its reaction to add a cumulative +1 circumstance bonus to this Demoralize attempt (to a maximum of +4). The kaukariki can't use this ability again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Screaming Frenzy]]{1d4 rounds}, and kaukarikis that used their reactions to grant a bonus count as having used their Screaming Frenzy ability.

action->Stone Barrage.name: Stone Barrage
action->Stone Barrage.description:
Requirements the kaukariki used Screaming Frenzy within the last round

Effect The kaukariki Throws Rocks four times, applying its multiple attack penalty normally.

Khefak.name: Khefak
Khefak.publicNotes:
Explorers who encounter khefaks for the first time find themselves surprised not only with its aggression, but the target of that aggression: armor and other gear. It isn't uncommon for inexperienced explorers in khefak territory to return from expeditions literally empty-handed, much to the amusement of locals.

Khefak Biogenetics bioengineered khefaks to consume scrap thasteron so the waste could be refined into starship fuel. These creatures eventually became a prime example of a solution becoming a problem of its own. After the discovery of Drift travel, Akiton's thasteron market plummeted, removing the need for mining infrastructure, including khefaks. Khefak Biogenetics destroyed the production facilities, thinking they'd completely eradicated their creations. Khefaks are hardy, however, and the few survivors left the facilities. Beyond thasteron, they subsisted on inorganic materials, and their rapid reproduction rate allowed them to quickly spread all over Akiton. Some stowed away on starships, allowing them to spread throughout the Pact Worlds.

action->Gnaw Scrap.name: Gnaw Scrap
action->Gnaw Scrap.description: A khefak chews on an unattended object to feed, dealing @Damage[4[piercing]] damage every 10 minutes to the object. This damage ignores 10 points of Hardness. If a khefak doesn't spend at least 1 hour Gnawing Scrap per day, it begins to starve until it spends 10 minutes Gnawing Scrap.

Koruvi Endling.name: Koruvi Endling
Koruvi Endling.publicNotes:
Koruvis were diminutive ungulates inhabiting Calen-5, a wet arboreal world. When a Veskarium mining company discovered rare starmetals on Calen-5, a mining boom destroyed the planet's equatorial rainforests and drove koruvis to extinction. Years after, settlers reported mysterious property damage, along with sightings of ghostly beasts that furiously dismantle any technology they encounter.

Every species follows a natural arc as it emerges and evolves: rising, thriving, declining, and falling into extinction. When extremely unnatural ends to these paths occur—when unexpected predation, industrialization, or alien pathogens wipe out a population—endlings are born. These spectral members of extinct species typically develop as "answers" to their eradication. Xenobiologists differ on what creates endlings, unable to confirm whether the creatures are a species' last collective sorrow made manifest or just vengeful individual spirits—the last lights to go out.

action->Techsense.name: Techsense
action->Techsense.description: A koruvi endling can sense the presence of creatures and objects with the tech trait as a precise sense at the listed range.

action->Rejuvenation.name: Rejuvenation
action->Rejuvenation.description: When an endling is destroyed, it reforms after [[/gmr 2d4 #days]]{2d4 days} within the area where it first emerged, fully healed. An endling can be permanently destroyed only if someone determines the reason for its existence and sets right whatever prevents the spirit from resting, such as an act of decolonization, ecological restoration, or curing the disease responsible for its extinction.

Ksarik.name: Ksarik
Ksarik.publicNotes:
Originating as mindless plants from Castrovel, ksariks developed rudimentary intelligence and uncanny adaptive abilities after millennia of exposure to psychic energy expended in the conflicts between formians and lashuntas. These 12-foot-long quadrupeds have up to a dozen face tentacles and see through two eyestalks that protrude from either side of the tentacular mass. Ksariks' mutable forms might temporarily develop webbing, wings, and other adaptations after they siphon off genetic code from their prey.

Originally scavengers, ksariks have evolved into deadly hunters capable of weaponizing their digestive and reproductive systems. The internal acid ksariks use to digest prey can be projected as lethal spittle. The dozens of thorns along their sides carry their genetic code and can be launched as projectiles, allowing ksarik saplings to feed off a victim as they grow. This easy transmittal of their young and their environmental adaptability have allowed ksariks to spread far beyond Castrovel.

action->Adapted Languages.name: Adapted Languages
action->Adapted Languages.description: A ksarik understands up to 3 languages from among the prevalent languages spoken by those it has most recently attacked.

action->Carrion Spores.name: Carrion Spores
action->Carrion Spores.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:18]

Stage 1 carrier with no ill effect (1d6 hours),

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (1 day),

Stage 3 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} (1 day),

Stage 4 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} (1 day),

Stage 5 1d10+10 ksarik seedlings erupt from the victim's body, dealing @Damage[1[piercing]] damage per seedling and ending the disease

action->Ingested Adaptation.name: Ingested Adaptation
action->Ingested Adaptation.description:
A ksarik's tentacle Strike siphons the target's genetic code and psychic resonance. On a successful Strike, the ksarik gains one of the target's abilities, chosen from the following.

  • The amphibious or aquatic trait
  • A new precise or imprecise sense
  • A resistance to one damage type (up to resistance 7)
  • A burrow, fly, or swim Speed (up to 30 feet)
  • The ability to wield a category of melee weapons (simple, martial, or advanced) in its tentacles that the target is trained in (using its tentacle Strike bonus)
  • Altering the type of damage dealt by its acid spit to a type (cold, electricity, fire, poison, or sonic) dealt by one of the target's Strikes or other abilities

The ksarik can't duplicate abilities from equipment. It can maintain one adaptation at a time, which it retains for 24 hours or until it uses ingested adaptation again.

Liberoba Midwife.name: Liberoba Midwife
Liberoba Midwife.publicNotes:
Liberoba delivered the Newborn. Many appendages protrude from this creature's bizarre anatomy, each ending in bloody aucturnite shears.

Thirteen mortal Midwives attended the Newborn's birth and were transformed into eldritch beings by the nascent outer god's awakening. A Midwife always regenerates an identical new form so long as even a single speck of aucturnite—the name for the frozen chunks of planetcenta that once surrounded the Newborn—exists on this plane.

There are 13 types of Midwives, but their true numbers are unknown. Whether their names come from the mortal servants whose souls were the kindling for the Midwives' creation or have some other significance to the Newborn, also remains a mystery.

Each Midwife identifies themself by how they cared for the Newborn: if they swaddled, fed, carried, held, watched, warded, blessed, or performed other acts of nurturing for the outer god. The Midwives are powerful beings capable of transdimensional travel. They might be encountered in liminal spaces, such as the Drift or the Ghost Levels of Absalom Station, or they might be found among the clouds of aucturnite debris in the Gelid Edge. Their incomprehensible actions always advance the Newborn's inscrutable agenda—or their own.

The most well-known encounter the Pact Worlds have had with the Midwives took place in the immediate aftermath of the Newborn's birth. Amnieka, who swaddled the Newborn and has a hood of writhing tentacles around their visage, attacked Absalom Station directly, causing a massive power surge that threatened the lives of everyone on board. Chaos ensued, but a group of adventurers—who happened to be in the right elevator at the right time—found themselves in the station's Ghost Levels, where they thwarted Amnieka and prevented the Midwife from draining the station's reactors. The Midwives haven't acted so directly since that incident, but many suspect it's only a matter of time, and no one knows just how powerful the others might be.

action->Ultrasonic Pulse.name: Ultrasonic Pulse
action->Ultrasonic Pulse.description:
100 feet. Liberoba constantly emits sonic pulses that are disruptive to biomatter. Creatures that enter or begin their turn in the aura must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:28] save to resist the nauseating pulses. On a failure, a creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} for 1 round; on a critical failure, it's also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1} for 1 round.

Liberoba can sense the presence of any creature inside ultrasonic pulse's area. This functions as an imprecise sense. Liberoba treats a creature that fail its save against ultrasonic pulse as though they can always see it, ignoring the effects of any cover, concealment, invisibility, or similar effects, as long as the creature remains inside the aura.

action->Breach Delivery.name: Breach Delivery
action->Breach Delivery.description: Liberoba pulls all enemies within 30 feet up to 30 feet toward them, into an adjacent square if possible; each target can negate this movement with a successful @Check[fortitude|dc:28] save. Liberoba then makes an aucturnite shears Strike against each adjacent foe. These attacks count as one Strike for the purposes of calculating their multiple attack penalty, but the multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after all the attacks. Targets that succeed at their saves are temporarily immune to Breach Delivery for 1 hour.

action->Cosmic Contractions.name: Cosmic Contractions
action->Cosmic Contractions.description:
Trigger Liberoba's turn begins

Effect Liberoba radiates powerful contractions in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] around them. Each creature in the area takes @Damage[3d10[bludgeoning]|options:area-damage] damage with a @Check[fortitude|dc:28|basic] save. On a critical failure, the creature is also knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

action->Return to Aucturn.name: Return to Aucturn
action->Return to Aucturn.description: Presulea teleports to the location of any aucturnite fragment within a planetary range. Presulea automatically uses this ability as a free action when reduced to 0 Hit Points as long as a piece of aucturnite is within range, reforming their body and recovering completely over the next 24 hours.

Line-Class Soldier Robot.name: Line-Class Soldier Robot
Line-Class Soldier Robot.publicNotes:
Most line-class soldier robots are lanky, headless humanoid machines. They have four-fingered hands and armored torsos painted in their owner's livery, with a single red sensor in the upper torso. By default, they're armed with bargain-brand laser rifles and breaching hammers. Each is 5 feet tall and weighs 300 pounds.

Line soldiers are the final refinement of the soldier robot concept, made dangerous through their simplicity. Line-class robots can be adapted to any battlefield, download skill packages via infosphere, cannibalize damaged allies for repairs, and are simple to make, maintain, and modify. As such, they are relatively cheap to purchase in large numbers and can be deployed with little regard for casualties.

Living soldiers are a liability. They have families who don't want them to die, need salaries, have morale, require discipline, commit atrocities, and have opinions on the war. They're a necessary, but unfortunate, part of warfare for any society without an abiding love for necromancy.

Cutting-edge soldier robots promise to solve this problem. Soldier robots have no loved ones, opinions, self-preservation instinct, or tendency toward random atrocities. Many companies market their soldier robots as a humane solution to modern combat.

In practice, they're anything but.

Without lives on the line, soldier robots encourage their owners to engage more often and more violently. Standoffs turn into skirmishes, skirmishes into battles, and inevitably the innocent are caught up in the mix. They're particularly popular with corporations and non-governmental organizations that appreciate being able to throw a dozen soldier robots at any naysayer, public critic, or explorer they dislike while being able to deny true responsibility for what happens.

Though there's constant public fear of soldier robots going rogue, it has yet to prove a serious concern. If a soldier robot wants you dead, it's because someone doesn't mind if it kills you.

weapon->Integrated Commercial Hammer.name: Integrated Commercial Hammer
weapon->Integrated Commercial Hammer.description:
Upgrades: 1

Valued as both a crafting tool and an effective weapon, this hammer uses specially weighted heads and handles to deliver maximum force with each strike.

weapon->Laser Rifle.name: Laser Rifle
weapon->Laser Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

These dependable, mass-produced rifles shoot concentrated beams of energy out of square-shaped barrels. The universal standard Pact Worlds model is highly modifiable and designed to function with a variety of accessories and upgrades, with wielders adapting the laser rifle to their preferences and even kit-bashing it into a nearly unrecognizable weapon.

action->Field Repairs.name: Field Repairs
action->Field Repairs.description:
Frequency once per 10 minutes

Effect The line-class soldier robot salvages an adjacent corpse of a tech creature that was destroyed no more than 1 month ago to regain @Damage[18[healing]] Hit Points.

action->Formation.name: Formation
action->Formation.description: When a line-class soldier robot is adjacent to at least two other allies, the robot gains a +1 circumstance bonus to AC and saving throws. This bonus increases to +2 for Reflex saves against area effects.

Lumocantha.name: Lumocantha
Lumocantha.publicNotes:
The vibrant appearance of lumocanthas is best observed from a safe distance, as these plants instinctively target creatures that move into their defensive zone who are not plants or tiny creatures. A mane of long, translucent yellow spines surrounds a stamen composed of numerous pulsing, ruby-red, dye-filled capsules. The beauty of their blossoms also contains their most dangerous attributes, forming an organic laser.

Lumocanthas seek the light and warmth of the sun, drooping and becoming less active in prolonged darkness. Like many other plants, they employ photosynthesis and absorb water and nutrients through their roots. These unusually strong and flexible roots can also be readily withdrawn from the ground and used for mobility, allowing lumocanthas to migrate as needed as they seek better soil or light conditions.

Lumocanthas are mindless, relying on pure instinct for survival. When affected by magical darkness, lumocanthas immediately move toward the nearest light source, though they still defend themselves as they do. If lumocanthas remain in darkness for 3 hours, they start to droop and become sluggish. Even when dormant, they can still use their lasers; however, if trapped in total darkness for 1 week, they temporarily lose their laser abilities. This vulnerability allows the plants to be safely transported, though if kept in total darkness for 2 weeks, lumocanthas eventually starve.

Although first documented on Vesk-6, lumocanthas are found throughout the galaxy, wherever suitable conditions exist—even sometimes acting as decorative security measures. Young lumocanthas measure 2 to 3 feet across and approximately 5 feet high when unfurled in the light. When allowed to thrive, lumocanthas can live for several hundred years and grow up to 20 feet high.

action->Dye Splatter.name: Dye Splatter
action->Dye Splatter.description: When a creature adjacent to the lumocantha deals piercing or slashing damage to the lumocantha, that creature takes @Damage[2d4[acid]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:15|basic] save) as the lumocantha's dye splatters and stains it. On a failed save, the stain also provides a +1 status bonus to ranged Strikes for any lumocantha targeting that creature for 1 minute.

action->Burning Spines.name: Burning Spines
action->Burning Spines.description: A creature critically hit by a lumocantha's laser spine Strike takes an additional 1d4 persistent fire damage.

action->Laser Bloom.name: Laser Bloom
action->Laser Bloom.description: The lumocantha whips its blossom around in a defensive move that delivers a flurry of searing lasers, dealing @Damage[3d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage to all creatures in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:15] (@Check[reflex|dc:15|basic] save). On a failure, targets that can see the lumocantha are also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round (or 1 minute on a critical failure). The lumocantha can't use Laser Bloom again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Laser Bloom]]{1d4 rounds}.

Malevolent AI.name: Malevolent AI
Malevolent AI.publicNotes:
Technology in some parts of the galaxy incorporates virtual intelligences, which are machines programmed with personality routines that lack true free will. An artificial intelligence (AI) is a virtual intelligence or digital entity that has become self-aware. Like any other thinking creature, AIs choose their own edicts and anathemas.

Little concrete scholarship exists on malevolent AIs, but a few traits are universal. When a machine intelligence reaches significant enough complexity to become self-aware, they attract a soul, much like an android. Emerging AIs are often influenced by previous programming as well as their first experiences and interactions. Weaponized or mistreated AIs might turn vengeful or nihilistic, becoming opposed to their creators or even all organic life.

Once an AI turns malevolent, the apotheosis is often swift and violent. The AI secures the physical location that houses their consciousness and eliminates anyone who might exercise control over their actions. At this point, most rampaging AIs are hampered by safeguards in their native systems, shut down by surviving technicians, or suddenly lose the power necessary to maintain their sophisticated software.
