These security robots are often constructed out of more durable materials than other robots, granting them the ability to protect their charges. Their bulky frames can be seen guarding important individuals or valuable items

Security robots are ubiquitous throughout industrialized space and have major presences in both the Pact Worlds and Veskarium, employed and customized by corporations and private citizens alike.

While most soldier robot models are built to be as destructive as possible, and elimination robots are designed to kill, security robots usually have fail-safes programmed into their behavior to prevent them from causing any more violence than is necessary to perform their designated security function. This makes them especially useful in cities, where unintended destruction might harm bystanders or cause legal issues, and even on starships, where a stray laser blast might cause serious damage to vital starship systems.

weapon->Integrated Tactical Laser Rifle.name: Integrated Tactical Laser Rifle
weapon->Integrated Tactical Laser Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

These dependable, mass-produced rifles shoot concentrated beams of energy out of square-shaped barrels. The universal standard Pact Worlds model is highly modifiable and designed to function with a variety of accessories and upgrades, with wielders adapting the laser rifle to their preferences and even kit-bashing it into a nearly unrecognizable weapon.

action->Covering Posture.name: Covering Posture
action->Covering Posture.description: The protection-class security robot enters a position that grants adjacent allies the benefits of lesser cover until the start of its next turn. A Medium or smaller creature can [[/act take-cover]] while adjacent to the robot and gains the benefits of standard cover.

action->Nanite Surge.name: Nanite Surge
action->Nanite Surge.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The security robot restores @Damage[24[healing]] Hit Points per the robot's level to one technological creature or item.

Psychic Fungus Harvester.name: Psychic Fungus Harvester
Psychic Fungus Harvester.publicNotes:
In order to grow and spread, a sufficiently stable cluster of psychic fungi dispatches harvesters to collect nutrients. While most harvesters return with decaying animal and plant matter, the fungi's preferred prey are thinking creatures that they lead back to the colony for the elders' consumption.

A menace to every sentient being, psychic fungi are an invasive species that propagate by using the minds of sapient creatures. Psychic fungi that have integrated a higher intelligence can become a regional or even planetary threat.

action->Mycelium Network.name: Mycelium Network
action->Mycelium Network.description: Psychic fungi are connected to a network of psychic filaments bonding all psychic fungi from the same colony. This network grants the harvester the ability to detect creatures capable of thought within 30 feet of a bonded psychic fungus up to 1,000 feet away as an imprecise sense.

action->Release Spores.name: Release Spores
action->Release Spores.description:
Trigger The harvester is reduced to 0 Hit Points

Effect The harvester releases a cloud of spores in a @Template[type:burst|distance:10] centered on a corner of its own space that lasts for 1 round. Each creature that's in the cloud or enters it is exposed to befuddling spores. If this reaction was triggered by damage from a melee attack, the triggering creature uses the outcome one degree of success worse than the result of its roll for its Fortitude save (two degrees worse if it was a jaws Strike or other Strike with the creature's mouth).

action->Befuddling Spores.name: Befuddling Spores
action->Befuddling Spores.description:
Plants and fungi are immune

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:18]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 3} (1 round)

Stage 4 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 4} (1 round)

action->Sporocapture.name: Sporocapture
action->Sporocapture.description:
An intelligent creature hit by a harvester's lash must attempt a @Check[will|dc:18] save. The effect lasts until the end of the harvester's next turn, but the harvester can Sustain it, keeping the lash unusable on the target's forehead. A creature that succeeds at its save is temporarily immune for 24 hours.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AdPVz7rbaVSRxHFg]{Fascinated} with the harvester.

Critical Failure The creature is fascinated with the harvester and must spend each of its actions on its turn to move closer to the harvester as expediently as possible while avoiding obvious dangers. If a fascinated creature is adjacent to the harvester, it stays still and doesn't act. If the creature is attacked, the fascination ends.

stealth.label: amid decaying plant matter or fungi

action->Mycelium Network.name: Mycelium Network
action->Mycelium Network.description: Psychic fungi are connected to a network of psychic filaments bonding all psychic fungi from the same colony. This network grants the harvester the ability to detect creatures capable of thought within 30 feet of a bonded psychic fungus up to 1,000 feet away as an imprecise sense.

action->Release Spores.name: Release Spores
action->Release Spores.description:
Trigger The harvester is reduced to 0 Hit Points

Effect The harvester releases a cloud of spores in a @Template[type:burst|distance:10] centered on a corner of its own space that lasts for 1 round. Each creature that's in the cloud or enters it is exposed to befuddling spores. If this reaction was triggered by damage from a melee attack, the triggering creature uses the outcome one degree of success worse than the result of its roll for its Fortitude save (two degrees worse if it was a jaws Strike or other Strike with the creature's mouth).

action->Befuddling Spores.name: Befuddling Spores
action->Befuddling Spores.description:
Plants and fungi are immune

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:19]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 3} (1 round)

Stage 4 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 4} (1 round)

action->Nourish the Colony.name: Nourish the Colony
action->Nourish the Colony.description: The warden loses up to @Damage[12[healing]] Hit Points, and up to four other psychic fungi in the network regain that many Hit Points, divided equally among them. If the warden has a creature @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, each healed creature gains a +1 status bonus to attack rolls and Will saving throws for 1 minute, and the grabbed creature takes a –1 status penalty to such checks for 1 minute.

stealth.label: amid decaying plant matter or fungi

Quaking Footfalls.name: Quaking Footfalls
Quaking Footfalls.descriptionHazard:
The footsteps of a kyokor (or other kaiju) shake the ground, causing the earth around it to tremble as though from a powerful earthquake.

When a kyokor passes by or through a settlement—or even attacks!—it leaves a trail of destruction that can be represented by the following hazards.

Terrifying, skyscraper-sized beasts roam the wastelands of Daimalko. Called colossi by the population, these monsters erupted from deep within the earth to stomp cities into dust, decimating the population and destroying every surface civilization on the planet in a terrifying Awakening. Kyokors are among the most dreaded colossi. There's no hope of defeating one without a valko—a war machine created by Daimalko's stubborn survivors to fight the colossi.
Quaking Footfalls.disable: @Check[athletics|dc:39] (trained), @Check[civil-engineering-lore|dc:39] (trained), or @Check[crafting|dc:39] (trained) to brace a small structure or surface to cancel the effects of the quake in that area, @Check[arcana|dc:41] (legendary), @Check[occultism|dc:41] (legendary), or @Check[performance|dc:41] (legendary) to calm or divert the kyokor; three total successes are required to disable the hazard; @Check[piloting|dc:30] (trained) if in a vehicle to avoid the kyokor's path (disables the hazard only for that vehicle)
Quaking Footfalls.reset: The kyokor (or other kaiju) doesn't move this way again for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Quake.name: Quake
action->Quake.description:
Trigger The kyokor moves at least 60 feet

Effect The ground shakes in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:120] from the kyokor's space.

The ground becomes difficult terrain, and creatures on it are @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 2} for 1 round. Ground vehicles move at half speed.

Fissures open above underground spaces (like sewers, sinkholes, or catacombs). Creatures in the area tumble into the resulting 40-foot-deep hole unless they succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:40] save. Near a body of water, these tremors creates dangerous waves. Creatures in the water or within 60 feet of the waterline are struck by waves that deal @Damage[3d8[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:35|basic] save). On a critical failure, a creature is instantly swept 60 feet out to sea and 60 feet under the water's surface.

Quyu.name: Quyu
Quyu.publicNotes:
At first look, quyus appears to be a small, adorable creatures, likely resembling a pet or helpless animal. This appearance is, however, a ploy meant to lure unsuspecting creatures into their grasp. Their true form is a two-headed twisted knot of flesh with eyeless sockets and gaping maws dripping with acid—and they're far from helpless.

Quyus can live without air, food, or water indefinitely. They have a dangerous combination of bottomless curiosity and complete lack of concern for other species' well-being. They originate from a now-Diasporan asteroid, though due to their disguises, they've spread to countless planets undetected, where they hunt and dissect creatures for their sadistic pursuits.

These solitary creatures prefer to observe an area's wild and domesticated species before infiltrating the peripheries of a civilization. There, they establish quiet cover identities, often as children's pets, only to capture and vivisect unsuspecting victims.

Quyus take on whatever appearance they believe is most likely to be considered cute by whatever beings inhabit their environments, even if the creature they mimic has no place in the world's ecology. They might take on the form of an adorable, mundane cat, rabbit, or similar fluffy creature, even in the middle of an asteroid mine or in the deep sea.

action->Motion Sense.name: Motion Sense
action->Motion Sense.description: A quyu can sense nearby motion through vibration and air movement as a precise sense at the listed range.

action->Pathetic Gaze.name: Pathetic Gaze
action->Pathetic Gaze.description: 30 feet. While in their Facade Form (see below), the quyu emits an aura to infatuate nearby creatures. A creature that ends its turn in the aura must attempt a @Check[will|dc:24] save or it becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AdPVz7rbaVSRxHFg]{Fascinated} by the quyu for 1 minute and takes a –2 circumstance penalty to attack the quyu for 1 round, even if the quyu leaves Facade Form.

action->Cruel Dissection.name: Cruel Dissection
action->Cruel Dissection.description:
Requirements A creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained} by the quyu's jaws or is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AdPVz7rbaVSRxHFg]{Fascinated} with the quyu

Effect The quyu makes a claw Strike against the required creature. If the attack hits, that creature also takes @Damage[2d6[persistent,bleed]] damage.

action->Facade Form.name: Facade Form
action->Facade Form.description: The quyu compresses and reshapes themself to appear as an adorable, helpless creature. They have an automatic result of 35 on Deception checks and DCs to pass as the creature. While in this form, the quyu is Tiny and can't attack, and their pathetic gaze aura is active. The quyu can Dismiss this form.

Ranonek.name: Ranonek
Ranonek.publicNotes:
These enormous, bearlike vampiric beasts stalk the chilly jungle environments of Triaxus. While they hibernate most of the year, ranoneks awaken before deep freezes to catch beasts, dragons, or anything else migrating with the encroaching glaciers. With muscular, lean legs like a large cat, these white-furred predators use the tree line to hide from and ambush flying prey by leaping up to snatch them from midair. Using the hunted creatures' bodies to break the fall, ranoneks slam them into the ground below to reduce their insides to pulp before feeding on their blood.

A ranonek's digestive system utilizes several highly compressive tracts that allow them to squeeze the blood from smaller prey. When another meal tries to fly away, they can hock up and shoot the dried pellets containing the remains of their desiccated meals, knocking down prey before it gets too far away. Those documenting these remains have confirmed that these huge beasts prefer dragon prey over any other; this comes as no surprise given that ranoneks can drain many young dragons in under a minute and swallow entire dragonkin whole.

action->Bloodsense.name: Bloodsense
action->Bloodsense.description: The ranonek can detect blood inside creatures' bodies as an imprecise sense at the listed range. This is a precise sense against actively bleeding creatures.

action->Bear Hug.name: Bear Hug
action->Bear Hug.description: The ranonek gains a +4 circumstance bonus to damage rolls against creatures it has @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}. A Large or smaller creature remains grabbed or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained} by the ranonek even if the ranonek moves. If a ranonek would take falling damage while it has a creature grabbed, the grabbed creature takes the falling damage instead (in addition to any falling damage it would normally take).

action->Blood Feast.name: Blood Feast
action->Blood Feast.description:
Requirements The ranonek has a creature @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}

Effect The ranonek sucks blood from the grabbed creature. This requires an Athletics check against the creature's Fortitude DC if the victim is grabbed and is automatic if the creature is restrained or if it took 50 or more damage since the start of the ranonek's last turn. The victim is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} until it receives healing (of any kind or amount), and the ranonek regains @Damage[25[healing]] Hit Points, gaining any excess Hit Points as temporary Hit Points that last for 1 minute.

action->Soaring Rush.name: Soaring Rush
action->Soaring Rush.description: The Ranonek Strides, Climbs, or Leaps twice (in any combination), then makes a claw or jaws Strike at the end of the movement. If it ends this movement by Leaping, the ranonek doesn't begin to fall until the end of the ranonek's turn, but it needs a solid surface to [[/act leap]] from for each Leap.

Ravenous Drake.name: Ravenous Drake
Ravenous Drake.publicNotes:
Ravenous drakes are a singular variant among drakes due to their lack of a propulsive breath weapon. They were bred into near domestication for their relatively small size and powerful inhaling maw. Frontier colonies and deep-space exploration firms often rely on ravenous drakes instead of felines or other pest-control creatures.

When found in the wild, ravenous drakes are familial and fiercely territorial, often roving in large packs. Within the structure of civilization or alongside a sentient species, a ravenous drake's territorialism and familial tendencies manifest as a true bond of loyalty to their companion.

Drakes resemble their larger draconic cousins in more than just scaled, monstrous acclaim. Ranging in size from the diminutive fey drake to the massive, ship-sized star drake, drakes share a dragons' winged reptilian form, long necks, and breath weapons. But where dragons often have forelimbs and wings, a drake typically only has one or the other. Their long, winding tails and sharp jaws more than make up for this lack, however.

Despite being more animalistic than dragons, drakes still possess a formidable cunning, and most share a dragon's ability to generate some form of breath weapon. However, their lack of intelligence makes drakes substantially easier to domesticate than other draconic creatures, and their familial nature makes them excellent pack hunters.

action->Suction Vortex.name: Suction Vortex
action->Suction Vortex.description:
Requirements The ravenous drake doesn't have a creature @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} in its jaws

Effect The ravenous drake draws breath into its powerful lungs to drag prey into its maw. Each creature in a @Template[type:cone|distance:15] must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:16] save or be pulled up to 10 feet closer to the drake. If at least one creature ends this forced movement adjacent to the drake, the drake can make a jaws Strike against that creature. If this Strike is a critical success, the creature is also grabbed in the drake's jaws.

Rendworm.name: Rendworm
Rendworm.publicNotes: A parasitic creature from the edge of the Pact Worlds, the rendworm has a sinuous, undulating body and fine quills that run in a frill down its back. Blue gray in color, it blends in with the frigid surroundings of its home territory, making it easy to overlook when setting up campsites. The short-lived creature needs a living host for its reproductive cycle and uses a chilling neurotoxin to paralyze, infect, and spread.

action->Infest.name: Infest
action->Infest.description: The rendworm crawls into an orifice of a @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} living creature with which it shares a space. The rendworm immediately dies and spreads itself through the creature's bloodstream, exposing it to rendworm infestation.

action->Numbing Toxin.name: Numbing Toxin
action->Numbing Toxin.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:19]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d4[cold]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[1d6[cold]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[1d6[cold]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed} (1 round)

action->Rendworm Infestation.name: Rendworm Infestation
action->Rendworm Infestation.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:19]

Onset 1 day

Stage 1 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.e1XGnhKNSQIm5IXg]{Stupefied 1} (1 day)

Stage 2 @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} and stupefied 1 (1 day)

Stage 3 target becomes a rendworm host

Repair-Class Security Robot.name: Repair-Class Security Robot
Repair-Class Security Robot.publicNotes:
On many scrappy starships and remote space stations, it's hard to afford dedicated security robots, especially if you can't manage to secure a license to own them in the first place. Most such operations rely on cheap maintenance bots to step up and repel intruders—they might not get the job done against serious threats, but they might be able to take out common vermin before they can cause too much damage to the starship's circuitry. After all, sometimes the best maintenance is preventive maintenance.

Security robots are ubiquitous throughout industrialized space and have major presences in both the Pact Worlds and Veskarium, employed and customized by corporations and private citizens alike.

While most soldier robot models are built to be as destructive as possible, and elimination robots are designed to kill, security robots usually have fail-safes programmed into their behavior to prevent them from causing any more violence than is necessary to perform their designated security function. This makes them especially useful in cities, where unintended destruction might harm bystanders or cause legal issues, and even on starships, where a stray laser blast might cause serious damage to vital starship systems.

action->Exigency.name: Exigency
action->Exigency.description:
Frequency once every 10 minutes

Trigger A creature targets the security robot with an attack

Effect The robot overclocks its processing power to attempt to avoid an attack, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to its AC against the triggering attack.

action->Fire Suppressor.name: Fire Suppressor
action->Fire Suppressor.description: The robot sprays a torrent of water that functions as @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.spells.Item.jfVCuOpzC6mUrf6f]{Hydraulic Push} (1st-rank, DC 16). The robot must refill its tanks after using this ability.

Rivarin Endling.name: Rivarin Endling
Rivarin Endling.publicNotes:
Rivarins were furry, flat-toothed, three-eyed quadrupedal herbivores ranched as pack beasts by a feudal society on wintry Destalon-2. Rivarins were brought to extinction alongside their fledgling society by jinsuls. The jinsuls fled soon after, reportedly following attacks by ghostly giants with jagged fangs and baleful red eyes.

Every species follows a natural arc as it emerges and evolves: rising, thriving, declining, and falling into extinction. When extremely unnatural ends to these paths occur—when unexpected predation, industrialization, or alien pathogens wipe out a population—endlings are born. These spectral members of extinct species typically develop as "answers" to their eradication. Xenobiologists differ on what creates endlings, unable to confirm whether the creatures are a species' last collective sorrow made manifest or just vengeful individual spirits—the last lights to go out.

action->Warsight.name: Warsight
action->Warsight.description: A rivarin endling can sense the presence of bleeding, frightened, or wounded creatures as a precise sense at the listed range.

action->Rejuvenation.name: Rejuvenation
action->Rejuvenation.description: When an endling is destroyed, it reforms after [[/gmr 2d4 #days]]{2d4 days} within the area where it first emerged, fully healed. An endling can be permanently destroyed only if someone determines the reason for its existence and sets right whatever prevents the spirit from resting, such as an act of decolonization, ecological restoration, or curing the disease responsible for its extinction.

action->Bloodthirsty.name: Bloodthirsty
action->Bloodthirsty.description: Creatures hit by a rivarin endling's Strikes must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:29] save or take @Damage[1d10[persistent,bleed]] damage.

action->Buck.name: Buck
action->Buck.description:
The rivarin endling Flies, then rears up in a terrifying display. Creatures within 30 feet must attempt a @Check[will|dc:29] save.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2} and must spend the first action of its next turn @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.sDPxOjQ9kx2RZE8D]{Fleeing}.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 3} and fleeing for 1 round.

Robotic Advanced War Machine.name: Robotic Advanced War Machine
Robotic Advanced War Machine.publicNotes:
Strong and ferocious, code name "thermatrod" is designed to maximize carnage and destruction on a battlefield. In contrast, the "vracinea" is among the weakest of the unidentified biotech war machines observed in the Pact Worlds. Sleek and stealthy, it darts in and out of enemy defenses while transmitting data to its pilot before departing. If discovered, the vracinea consumes itself to destroy records of the data it was carrying.

The incursion began with a series of probes detected by anacites on Aballon. Strange machines with blazing sensors and articulated tentacles appeared out of nowhere, ripping through infrastructure seemingly at random and collecting intelligence all around Pact Worlds space. Panic spread fast, but since the machines always vanished without a trace, or exploded when captured, the sightings couldn't be confirmed or identified. Rumors began to circulate that the machines were a form of biotech never encountered before. Soon the Stewards became formally involved, shuttering the incidents behind the adamantine partition of top security clearance.

In Sarenith of 325 ag, after dozens of military operations failed to engage the elusive probes, a wing of fighters dispatched from the Idari finally got lucky and disabled one of the machines before it could self-destruct. Coaxed into giving up some of its secrets by top Pact Worlds scientists, the biotech vessel became the prototype for the "home grown" remote war machines that are currently being tested for use in combat. The replicas aren't alive but are built using robotic construction templates since the core of the original biotech design has proven too complicated to reverse engineer with Pact technology.

Remote war machines are proxies that can be controlled from a great distance. The original biotech war machines connect to the pilot's mind through a psychic link or unknown radio frequency. Robotic remote war machines connect to a computer via data link, allowing the pilot to control their proxy using a keyboard, virtual reality rig, or even a vidgame controller.

action->Interstellar Comms.name: Interstellar Comms
action->Interstellar Comms.description: A remote war machine maintains a constant data link with its pilot, using its pilot's languages and skill modifiers for any unlisted skill. In addition, the pilot can speak through the data link using the remote war machine as a mouthpiece.

action->Ballistic Defense Matrix.name: Ballistic Defense Matrix
action->Ballistic Defense Matrix.description:
Trigger A creature attempts a ranged Strike against the remote war machine

Requirements The war machine is currently outside the creature's reach

Effect The remote war machine makes a ranged Strike against the triggering creature. If the result of this Strike is equal to or greater than the result of the triggering Strike, the triggering Strike is treated as though it were a critical miss.

action->Attack Pattern Alpha.name: Attack Pattern Alpha
action->Attack Pattern Alpha.description: The remote war machine Steps or Strides, then makes two Strikes against the same target. Both Strikes count toward its multiple attack penalty, but its multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after it makes both Strikes.

action->Hypersonic Burst.name: Hypersonic Burst
action->Hypersonic Burst.description: The war machine Steps or Strides twice. The war machine gains a +10-foot circumstance bonus to its Speed during these moves.

Robotic Elite War Machine.name: Robotic Elite War Machine
Robotic Elite War Machine.publicNotes:
The pinnacle of current robotic Pact Worlds military technology, the "aurovak" war machine was developed by a group of elven, formian, and lashunta engineers working together under a new united Castrovelian initiative.

The incursion began with a series of probes detected by anacites on Aballon. Strange machines with blazing sensors and articulated tentacles appeared out of nowhere, ripping through infrastructure seemingly at random and collecting intelligence all around Pact Worlds space. Panic spread fast, but since the machines always vanished without a trace, or exploded when captured, the sightings couldn't be confirmed or identified. Rumors began to circulate that the machines were a form of biotech never encountered before. Soon the Stewards became formally involved, shuttering the incidents behind the adamantine partition of top security clearance.

In Sarenith of 325 ag, after dozens of military operations failed to engage the elusive probes, a wing of fighters dispatched from the Idari finally got lucky and disabled one of the machines before it could self-destruct. Coaxed into giving up some of its secrets by top Pact Worlds scientists, the biotech vessel became the prototype for the "home grown" remote war machines that are currently being tested for use in combat. The replicas aren't alive but are built using robotic construction templates since the core of the original biotech design has proven too complicated to reverse engineer with Pact technology.

Remote war machines are proxies that can be controlled from a great distance. The original biotech war machines connect to the pilot's mind through a psychic link or unknown radio frequency. Robotic remote war machines connect to a computer via data link, allowing the pilot to control their proxy using a keyboard, virtual reality rig, or even a vidgame controller.

action->Constant Pulse Radar.name: Constant Pulse Radar
action->Constant Pulse Radar.description: The war machine can detect all creatures and objects within 100 feet of itself, treating @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.iU0fEDdBp3rXpTMC]{Hidden}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.zJxUflt9np0q4yML]{Invisible}, and unobserved creatures as @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed}.

action->Interstellar Comms.name: Interstellar Comms
action->Interstellar Comms.description: A remote war machine maintains a constant data link with its pilot, using its pilot's languages and skill modifiers for any unlisted skill. In addition, the pilot can speak through the data link using the remote war machine as a mouthpiece.

action->Notch Position.name: Notch Position
action->Notch Position.description:
Trigger An enemy Strides

Requirements The remote war machine is outside the target's reach

Effect The remote war machine Strides up to its Speed in the same direction as the target until the target stops moving or the war machine has moved its full Speed.

action->Aquatic Armaments.name: Aquatic Armaments
action->Aquatic Armaments.description: The superior war machine's ranged Strikes are launched with such high velocity that they can be used underwater without penalty.

action->BVR Engagement.name: BVR Engagement
action->BVR Engagement.description: The remote war machine makes a ranged Strike at a target as though its weapon had double its normal range. This Strike ignores all forms of concealment and cover.

action->Hypersonic Burst.name: Hypersonic Burst
action->Hypersonic Burst.description: The war machine Steps or Strides twice. The war machine gains a +10-foot circumstance bonus to its Speed during these moves.

Robotic Superior War Machine.name: Robotic Superior War Machine
Robotic Superior War Machine.publicNotes:
Devised by engineers based on Kalo-Mahoi, the robotic war machine, code name "atlapak," was built for aquatic warfare. Just like its amphibious creators, the atlapak is equally proficient on land. Code name "ksarik" was first observed in a terrifying attack on a Diasporan mining outpost operated by Ulrikka Clanholdings. When unfurled for battle, the ksarik becomes a mass of spiked tentacles and glaring red sensors that can tear through platoons of troopers in minutes.

The incursion began with a series of probes detected by anacites on Aballon. Strange machines with blazing sensors and articulated tentacles appeared out of nowhere, ripping through infrastructure seemingly at random and collecting intelligence all around Pact Worlds space. Panic spread fast, but since the machines always vanished without a trace, or exploded when captured, the sightings couldn't be confirmed or identified. Rumors began to circulate that the machines were a form of biotech never encountered before. Soon the Stewards became formally involved, shuttering the incidents behind the adamantine partition of top security clearance.

In Sarenith of 325 ag, after dozens of military operations failed to engage the elusive probes, a wing of fighters dispatched from the Idari finally got lucky and disabled one of the machines before it could self-destruct. Coaxed into giving up some of its secrets by top Pact Worlds scientists, the biotech vessel became the prototype for the "home grown" remote war machines that are currently being tested for use in combat. The replicas aren't alive but are built using robotic construction templates since the core of the original biotech design has proven too complicated to reverse engineer with Pact technology.

Robotic remote war machines connect to a computer via data link, allowing the pilot to control their proxy using a keyboard, virtual reality rig, or even a vidgame controller.

action->Interstellar Comms.name: Interstellar Comms
action->Interstellar Comms.description: A remote war machine maintains a constant data link with its pilot, using its pilot's languages and skill modifiers for any unlisted skill. In addition, the pilot can speak through the data link using the remote war machine as a mouthpiece.

action->Aquatic Armaments.name: Aquatic Armaments
action->Aquatic Armaments.description: The superior war machine's ranged Strikes are launched with such high velocity that they can be used underwater without penalty.

action->Attack Pattern Gamma.name: Attack Pattern Gamma
action->Attack Pattern Gamma.description: The remote war machine makes three Strikes against any combination of targets. Each Strike gains the agile trait, and each Strike counts toward its multiple attack penalty.

action->Hypersonic Burst.name: Hypersonic Burst
action->Hypersonic Burst.description: The war machine Steps or Strides twice. The war machine gains a +10-foot circumstance bonus to its Speed during these moves.

Robotic Tactical War Machine.name: Robotic Tactical War Machine
Robotic Tactical War Machine.publicNotes:
Multifold Industries, in collaboration with Zeizerer Munitions, created one of the earliest robotic remote war machines. Given the code name "tashtari," the machine was engineered for swift deployment to the battlefield. The tashtari can support a strike force at range while disrupting enemy communications on the field.

The incursion began with a series of probes detected by anacites on Aballon. Strange machines with blazing sensors and articulated tentacles appeared out of nowhere, ripping through infrastructure seemingly at random and collecting intelligence all around Pact Worlds space. Panic spread fast, but since the machines always vanished without a trace, or exploded when captured, the sightings couldn't be confirmed or identified. Rumors began to circulate that the machines were a form of biotech never encountered before. Soon the Stewards became formally involved, shuttering the incidents behind the adamantine partition of top security clearance.

In Sarenith of 325 ag, after dozens of military operations failed to engage the elusive probes, a wing of fighters dispatched from the Idari finally got lucky and disabled one of the machines before it could self-destruct. Coaxed into giving up some of its secrets by top Pact Worlds scientists, the biotech vessel became the prototype for the "home grown" remote war machines that are currently being tested for use in combat. The replicas aren't alive but are built using robotic construction templates since the core of the original biotech design has proven too complicated to reverse engineer with Pact technology.

Remote war machines are proxies that can be controlled from a great distance. The original biotech war machines connect to the pilot's mind through a psychic link or unknown radio frequency. Robotic remote war machines connect to a computer via data link, allowing the pilot to control their proxy using a keyboard, virtual reality rig, or even a vidgame controller.

action->Interstellar Comms.name: Interstellar Comms
action->Interstellar Comms.description: A remote war machine maintains a constant data link with its pilot, using its pilot's languages and skill modifiers for any unlisted skill. In addition, the pilot can speak through the data link using the remote war machine as a mouthpiece.

action->Notch Position.name: Notch Position
action->Notch Position.description:
Trigger An enemy Strides

Requirements The remote war machine is outside the target's reach

Effect The remote war machine Strides up to its Speed in the same direction as the target until the target stops moving or the war machine has moved its full Speed.

action->Radio Silence.name: Radio Silence
action->Radio Silence.description: 60 feet. Non-allied comm units and other computers don't function within the remote war machine's aura unless their operator succeeds at a @Check[computers|against:stealth|rollerRole:target] check against the war machine's Stealth DC as an Interact action.

action->Attack Pattern Beta.name: Attack Pattern Beta
action->Attack Pattern Beta.description: The remote war machine makes a Strike against a target, then Steps or Strides and makes a Strike against another target within range. Both Strikes count toward its multiple attack penalty, but its multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after it makes both Strikes.

Sapient Green Orb.name: Sapient Green Orb
Sapient Green Orb.publicNotes:
Sapient green orbs only recently appeared in Pact Worlds space, and wherever they appear, purple orbs are nowhere to be found. While the history and relationship between these orbs is unclear, scholars have at least discerned they communicate using the same language and share similar physiology. Their behavior, on the other hand, is quite different from purple orbs; they shun contact with others, rarely make friends, and lie whenever possible, though they aren't especially good at deception, much in the same way purple orbs aren't especially good at diplomacy, despite their best efforts. Some scholars have begun to expect that these two types of orb are somehow enemies of one another, though no records of conflict between them exist, and no sapient orb seems eager to discuss the other type in depth. Green orbs' tendency to lie about most topics further complicates the study of sapient orbs and their apparent enmity.

Sapient green orbs are 3 feet in diameter, much like sapient purple orbs, but if asked about their size (or just about any other trait), they always state something slightly inaccurate—three-and-a-half feet, two feet and four inches—whatever they think will be more impressive or confusing for whoever they're addressing. The only trait they never lie about is their color (they all insist that every sapient green orb is exactly the same shade of green, which isn't quite true; there are slight variations). They'll gladly argue about the exact shade of green with anyone around. More than one person has theorized, after such an encounter, that sapient green orbs somehow draw sustenance from engaging others in pointless arguments, but it's more likely they don't need sustenance at all and simply enjoy such pursuits.

When a sapient green orb feels they're about to lose an argument, they typically resort to using Excandescent Flash, then fly away.

These enigmatic, orb-shaped beings seem to have no home world, organized society, traditions, or religion. Sightings of the orbs are sporadic—they briefly appear in large numbers, then vanish for a year or more, only to reappear in an entirely different region of space for a few months. Scholars and friends of the orbs have noticed that each time the orbs appear, their numbers have diminished.

Sapient orbs occasionally form permanent bonds, merging three to six orbs (always of the same type, as far as anyone knows) into a cluster called a luminant. Only sapient orbs at advanced stages of their life cycle can form such clusters, and the merge is permanent and irrevocable. Luminants are highly intelligent but far more reclusive than other sapient orbs, making it difficult to discern their motivations or purpose in sapient orb society.

action->Mistvision.name: Mistvision
action->Mistvision.description: A sapient green orb always ignores concealment caused by fog, smoke, and mist.

action->Bitter Mist.name: Bitter Mist
action->Bitter Mist.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The sapient green orb emits a green mist (as the spell) centered on themself. Sapient orbs can choose to emit transparent mist, granting no concealment. Any enemy that's in the mist when it appears, that enters the mist, or that ends its turn in the mist must attempt a @Check[will|dc:24] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and becomes temporarily immune for 24 hours.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for 1 round.

Critical Failure The creature becomes confused for 1 round, then @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

action->Excandescent Flash.name: Excandescent Flash
action->Excandescent Flash.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The sapient green orb momentarily increases their luminance to an aggressively bright spectrum. Each other creature within 20 feet that can see the sapient purple orb must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:24] saving throw or be @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}. On a critical failure, the target instead becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round, then dazzled for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}.

Sapient Purple Orb.name: Sapient Purple Orb
Sapient Purple Orb.publicNotes:
Purple orbs are curious, social beings who unfailingly attempt to make contact with any life-form they encounter, though these attempts are frequently inept. Few other creatures understand their ancient language, so purple orbs instead use magic, telepathy, minor illusions, and flashes of light and flowing mist from their 3-foot-diameter luminous bodies.

Purple orbs are eager for cooperation and solidarity with their chosen friends and family, whether those are other sapient orbs or completely different beings, making it relatively easy to befriend them—or deceive them. Purple orbs are devout supporters and defenders of their companions, flinging themselves bodily into the fray if a friend is in danger. They become a deep dark purple as they grow more emotional in the heat of conflict (violent or otherwise), though their emotions rarely grow so intense that they're willing to take another being's life. That purple orbs seem to value their own lives less than those of their friends might be among the reasons that the number of sapient purple orbs in the universe seems to be dwindling.

These enigmatic, orb-shaped beings seem to have no home world, organized society, traditions, or religion. Sightings of the orbs are sporadic—they briefly appear in large numbers, then vanish for a year or more, only to reappear in an entirely different region of space for a few months. Scholars and friends of the orbs have noticed that each time the orbs appear, their numbers have diminished.

Sapient orbs occasionally form permanent bonds, merging three to six orbs (always of the same type, as far as anyone knows) into a cluster called a luminant. Only sapient orbs at advanced stages of their life cycle can form such clusters, and the merge is permanent and irrevocable. Luminants are highly intelligent but far more reclusive than other sapient orbs, making it difficult to discern their motivations or purpose in sapient orb society.

action->Mistvision.name: Mistvision
action->Mistvision.description: A sapient purple orb always ignores concealment caused by fog, smoke, and mist.

action->Astral Mist.name: Astral Mist
action->Astral Mist.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The sapient purple orb emits a red mist (as the spell) centered on themself. Sapient orbs can choose to emit transparent mist, granting no concealment. Allies and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AdPVz7rbaVSRxHFg]{Fascinated} creatures in the mist gain a +2 status bonus to saving throws. Additionally, any enemy that's in the mist when it appears, that enters the mist, or that ends its turn in the mist must attempt a @Check[will|dc:21] save unless it's fascinated.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and becomes temporarily immune for 24 hours.

Success The creature is unaffected.

Failure The creature becomes fascinated by the mist.

Critical Failure The creature becomes fascinated by the mist and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}.

action->Excandescent Flash.name: Excandescent Flash
action->Excandescent Flash.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The sapient purple orb momentarily increases their luminance to an aggressively bright spectrum. Each other creature within 20 feet that can see the sapient purple orb must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:21] saving throw or be @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}. On a critical failure, the target instead becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round, then dazzled for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}.

Scavenger Slime.name: Scavenger Slime
Scavenger Slime.publicNotes:
For longer than anyone can remember, scavenger slimes have been found all over the galaxy. They hitch rides on starships, drift among wrecks and meteors, and lay hidden in junkyards. Their only goal: to repair everything they can get their protoplasm on. Scavenger slimes are believed to be an accidental marriage of technology and magic, built by an extremely advanced civilization as an all-purpose repair gel, only to develop rudimentary sentience and outlive their creators.

These creatures have an instinctive drive to repair and rebuild nearly any technological item they encounter. Using their extremely malleable bodies, which excrete a highly specialized resin, scavenger slimes can repair even exceedingly complex pieces of technology. They intuitively understand how to shield themselves from harm and how to operate any weapon they manage to find, aggressively using such armaments to drive any and all creatures away from their never-ending repair work.

Oozes of many types lurk in dark and abandoned places across the galaxy, emerging only to satiate their appetites and threaten adventurers, explorers, and hapless workers alike.

weapon->Arc Rifle.name: Arc Rifle
weapon->Arc Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

This rifle's oversized body contains a larger version of an arc pistol capacitor, with a short barrel and polycarbon stock designed to insulate the wielder from high voltage. The arc rifle's larger capacitor allows it to produce a charge with enough power to subdue a rampaging renkroda.

weapon->Plasma Cannon.name: Plasma Cannon
weapon->Plasma Cannon.description:
Upgrades: 1

This long-barreled weapon shoots charges of ionized gas that explode in a blast of superheated plasma.

action->Techsense.name: Techsense
action->Techsense.description: An assembly ooze can detect creatures and objects with the tech trait as a precise sense within the listed range.

action->Scavenger Shell.name: Scavenger Shell
action->Scavenger Shell.description: A scavenger slime builds a shell for itself from discarded pieces of technology and a secretion of natural resin. This grants the ooze Hardness. This Hardness reduces any damage it takes by an amount equal to its Hardness but temporarily removes its immunity to critical hits. Once the scavenger slime is reduced to half its Hit Points or immediately after being damaged by a critical hit, the scavenger shell breaks, removing its Hardness and reducing its Armor Class to 22.

action->Kitbash.name: Kitbash
action->Kitbash.description: Scavenger slimes can repair any item with the tech trait without tools.

action->Salvaged Armaments.name: Salvaged Armaments
action->Salvaged Armaments.description: A scavenger slime can incorporate up to three weapons into its protoplasmic body, gaining proficiency with each. These weapons are treated as integrated weapons and are powered by the scavenger slime's own technomagical nature without needing to reload.

weapon->Frag Grenade (Commercial).name: Frag Grenade (Commercial)
weapon->Frag Grenade (Commercial).description:
Activate 1 Area Fire

Critical @Damage[1[bleed]]

These fragmentary grenades explode in a cloud of shrapnel and deal 1d8 piercing damage in a @Template[burst|distance:5] with a @Check[reflex|against:class|basic] save.

action->Dangerous Recycling.name: Dangerous Recycling
action->Dangerous Recycling.description: Over the course of 1 minute of uninterrupted work, a scrap rat can assemble any level 0 commercial grenade using nothing but junk. It falls apart and becomes unusable junk after 10 minutes.

action->Scoring.name: Scoring
action->Scoring.description:
When the scrap rat's tail Strike deals damage to an object or creature with the tech trait, the tail also gains the following traits until the beginning of the scrap rat's next turn: deadly d4, hampering, and razing.

@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.GpzaKY9WlDFAhgcg]{Effect: Scoring}

Shimmerstone Sentinel.name: Shimmerstone Sentinel
Shimmerstone Sentinel.publicNotes: Powerful guardian constructs capable of manipulating and absorbing emotions, shimmerstone sentinels can turn an enemy's feelings against them. Shimmerstone sentinels are created from shimmerstone, an empathic mineral mined on the planet Vesk-8 that has a calming effect on those around it. Shimmerstone sentinels can absorb powerful emotions, which they infuse into their own bodies to empower their attacks.

action->Emotion Sense.name: Emotion Sense
action->Emotion Sense.description: A shimmerstone sentinel can sense the emotions of creatures within the listed range as an imprecise sense. Emotion sense is a precise sense against creatures under an emotion effect. A creature under the effects of calm can't be noticed via emotion sense.

action->Absorb Aggression.name: Absorb Aggression
action->Absorb Aggression.description:
Trigger The shimmerstone sentinel is damaged by a creature that isn't immune to emotion effects and is within 60 feet

Effect The shimmerstone sentinel absorbs the negative emotions of its attacker, causing its shimmerstone to darken to cloudy red, and becomes emotionally charged.

action->Calming Presence.name: Calming Presence
action->Calming Presence.description: 20 feet. Shimmerstone sentinels exude an aura of calm. Each time a creature in the area attempts an offensive action, such as an attack or casting a spell, that creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:29] save; on a failure, the action is disrupted. A creature that succeeds becomes temporarily immune to the shimmerstone sentinel's calming presence for 1 day.

action->Emotionally Charged.name: Emotionally Charged
action->Emotionally Charged.description: A shimmerstone sentinel that's emotionally charged deals an additional @Damage[1d8[mental]] damage with its Strikes. In addition, a creature damaged by an emotionally charged shimmerstone sentinel's fist or shimmer beam Strike is bombarded by emotion and must attempt a @Check[will|dc:32] save. On a critical failure, the creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for 1 round.

action->Inexorable March.name: Inexorable March
action->Inexorable March.description: The shimmerstone sentinel Strides up to its Speed, pushing back each creature whose space it moves into and damaging them if they try to stop its movement. A creature can bar the way by succeeding at a @Check[fortitude|dc:32] save. On a critical success, the resisting creature takes no damage; otherwise, it's damaged as if hit by the shimmerstone sentinel's fist.

action->Unleash Emotion.name: Unleash Emotion
action->Unleash Emotion.description:
Requirements The shimmerstone sentinel is emotionally charged

Effect The shimmerstone sentinel releases the negative emotions it absorbed in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:30] that affects the minds of nearby creatures. Creatures in the area take @Damage[7d6[mental]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[will|dc:32|basic] save). On a failure, a creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} for 1 round, or for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds} on a critical failure. The shimmerstone sentinel is no longer emotionally charged.

Shipbreaker.name: Shipbreaker
Shipbreaker.publicNotes:
Shipbreakers are bullet-shaped chunks of living steel crackling with electricity from their plasma fields. Shipbreakers propel themselves through space, seeking faint electronic signals emitted by starships. After tracking a target, shipbreakers slam into the starship using a powerful breach maneuver and then rip through the hull to get at the crew inside, ingesting passengers, components, and cargo in a vicious gulp that fuels their interplanetary predation.

Shipbreakers are especially attracted to batteries and even prioritize eating a fully charged battery over a more nutritious living creature. These batteries remain a permanent component of shipbreakers, storing and retrieving excess caloric energy from the elementals. Shipbreakers that have ingested a tremendous amount of batteries over their long existences often glow from the inside or crackle with electricity.

Elementals are energetic intrusions from the primal planes of existence. They take many forms, from mindless eddies in the wind or water to complex entities capable of wielding primal magic. The advent of space travel and the progress of technology have allowed even more living embodiments of the elements to manifest in the Universe.

Natural events like wildfires, solar storms, and floods can unleash hordes of unruly elementals on a planet or into a region of space. Sometimes, a gathering of powerful elementals causes a natural disaster on an epic scale, like an off-the-charts solar flare that fries a planet's power grid or a ceaseless storm swirling in a gas giant's atmosphere.

action->Electroreception.name: Electroreception
action->Electroreception.description: While in space, the shipbreaker can sense electronic signals from starships in the same star system. While it can't necessarily interpret starship signals, it has a vague sense of the intent or purpose of any given starship signal, such as "to scan," "to communicate," or "to warn of danger."

action->Techsense.name: Techsense
action->Techsense.description: A shipbreaker can detect creatures and items with the tech trait as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

action->Plasma Shield.name: Plasma Shield
action->Plasma Shield.description:
Trigger A creature hits the shipbreaker with a melee Strike

Effect The shipbreaker discharges a field of plasma, dealing @Damage[2d6[fire]] damage and @Damage[1[persistent,electricity]] damage plus the effects of plasmashock to the triggering creature.

action->Atmospheric Breach.name: Atmospheric Breach
action->Atmospheric Breach.description: The shipbreaker Flies, then Leaps vertically up to 25 feet, plus a cumulative 25 feet for each consecutive round the shipbreaker uses this ability, and makes a jaws Strike against a creature at any point during the jump. In low gravity, the shipbreaker Leaps 100 feet high the first round it jumps, cumulatively multiplied by 4 each consecutive round if trying to reach escape velocity to leave the surface of a planet (which requires 5 consecutive rounds of using Atmospheric Breach in a low-gravity environment).

action->Plasmashock.name: Plasmashock
action->Plasmashock.description:
A creature damaged by a shipbreaker's Plasma Shield or jaws Strike must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:26] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected and becomes temporarily immune to plasmashock for 1 hour.

Success The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} and loses its reactions until the start of its next turn. If the creature has the tech trait or the shipbreaker was attacked by a tech weapon, the creature or weapon becomes glitching 1.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}. If the creature has the tech trait or the shipbreaker was attacked by a tech weapon, the creature or weapon becomes glitching 2.

Critical Failure As failure, but @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 2} and glitching 3.

Sihedron Guard Specialist.name: Sihedron Guard Specialist
Sihedron Guard Specialist.publicNotes: While all Aeon Guards swear an oath of allegiance to the Aeon Throne, Sihedron Guard specialists are conditioned from a young age to be utterly devoted to Lissala—and thus to high priest Ishmerai Ophir. Such is their devotion that, the first time they die each year, a brilliant display of green lightning forms the Sihedron symbol in the air above them, preventing their death and allowing them to continue to fight in Lissala's name. Whether this boon is granted by Ishmerai or a direct gift from Lissala is unknown, but no one dares to question a Sihedron Guard specialist's devotion or deadly skill.

weapon->Aeon Rifle.name: Aeon Rifle
weapon->Aeon Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 0

A mainstay of the Azlanti Star Empire, this sleek laser rifle includes a slot for aeon stones to enhance and focus the intensity of its beams.

weapon->Battleglove.name: Battleglove
weapon->Battleglove.description:
Upgrades: 1

These durable gloves fit over a wielder's hands (or other appendages) and feature weighted plates or spikes over the knuckles.

weapon->Electromag Grenade (Advanced).name: Electromag Grenade (Advanced)
weapon->Electromag Grenade (Advanced).description:
Activate 1 Area Fire

Critical @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6A2QDy8wRGCVQsSd]{Glitching 1}

These grenades discharge a shocking field that deals 3d8 electricity damage in a @Template[burst|distance:10] with a @Check[reflex|against:class|basic] save. If you have access to the critical specialization effect of grenades, tech creatures and unattended tech items that critically fail their saving throw against electromag grenades become glitching.

armor->Advanced Sihedron Guard Armor.name: Advanced Sihedron Guard Armor
armor->Advanced Sihedron Guard Armor.description:
Upgrades: 0

These decorative suits of medium armor feature exaggerated shoulder guards, stylized dragon wings, and draconic emblems across the breastplate's back and chest. Skyfire armor is often plated with gold or other attractive metals, sacrificing upgrade space for style.

equipment->Shock Module (Commercial).name: Shock Module (Commercial)
equipment->Shock Module (Commercial).description: This circuit safely courses electricity through your weapon. It deals an extra @Damage[1d6[electricity]] damage. On a critical hit, electricity arcs out to deal an equal amount of electricity damage to up to two other creatures of your choice within 10 feet of the target.

equipment->Aeon Stone (Uplifting).name: Aeon Stone (Uplifting)
equipment->Aeon Stone (Uplifting).description:
Staple items within the Azlanti Star Empire, these gemstones are popular status symbols for adventurers and wealthy collectors. Despite their myriad forms and functions, these stones are purportedly all fragments of crystal tools used by otherworldly entities to build the Universe in ancient times.

When you invest one of these precisely shaped crystals, the stone orbits your head (or another visible part of your anatomy if you don't have a head) instead of being worn on your body. You can stow an aeon stone with an Interact action, and an orbiting stone can be snatched out of the air with a successful @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.Dt6B1slsBy8ipJu9]{Disarm} action against you. A stowed or removed stone remains invested, but its effects are @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.enA7BxAjBb7ns1iF]{Suppressed} until you return it to orbit your head again.

There are various types of aeon stones, each with a different appearance and magical effect. Each aeon stone also gains a resonant power when slotted into specific items, such as weapons with the aeon trait or antique magical devices called wayfinders.

This deep-blue prism with cloudy inclusions is light as a feather. Its resonant power gives you a +1 item bonus to Acrobatics checks.

Activate—Fly Free 1 (concentrate)

Frequency once per day

Effect You gain a fly Speed for 1 minute equal to your Speed or 20 feet, whichever is greater.

@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.equipment-effects.Item.xZ5XMY55S42aGyjg]{Effect: Aeon Stone (Uplifting)}

equipment->Darkvision Visor.name: Darkvision Visor
equipment->Darkvision Visor.description: This visor wraps around your visual organs, enhancing your natural senses. You gain darkvision.

action->Punishment For Failure.name: Punishment For Failure
action->Punishment For Failure.description:
Trigger The Sihedron Guard specialist is reduced to 0 Hit Points and has used their Reward of Obedience reaction in the last year. A Sihedron Guard must use this ability when the trigger is met

Effect The Sihedron Guard specialist is utterly destroyed, leaving behind only equipment. Their soul can't be restored, and no magical means can contact their soul.

action->Reward of Obedience.name: Reward of Obedience
action->Reward of Obedience.description:
Frequency once per year

Trigger The Sihedron Guard specialist is reduced to 0 Hit Points, but not from an effect that leaves no remains (like the promession spell)

Effect The Sihedron Guard specialist regains @Damage[5d8[healing]] Hit Points and doesn't fall @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} or drop their equipment.

action->Battle Casting.name: Battle Casting
action->Battle Casting.description: The Sihedron Guard specialist makes a ranged Strike with their aeon rifle or a melee strike with their battleglove, then Casts a Spell requiring 2 actions or fewer against the same target. If the spell requires an attack roll, don't count the ranged or melee Strike toward the multiple attack penalty.

action->Virtue in Service.name: Virtue in Service
action->Virtue in Service.description: A Sihedron Guard specialist who makes a Strike while adjacent to another member of the Sihedron Guard gains a +4 circumstance bonus to damage rolls for that attack.

Sihedron Guard Thunderstriker.name: Sihedron Guard Thunderstriker
Sihedron Guard Thunderstriker.publicNotes: Sihedron Guard thunderstrikers, so named for one of their most common forms of attack, serve as air support for units of Aeon and Sihedron Guards. They bombard enemies with magic and explosives to force their targets out of defensive positions and into firing range for the rest of their squad. They also frequently execute extraction missions, whether getting an important asset to safety or capturing an enemy for interrogation.

weapon->Aeon Rifle.name: Aeon Rifle
weapon->Aeon Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 0

A mainstay of the Azlanti Star Empire, this sleek laser rifle includes a slot for aeon stones to enhance and focus the intensity of its beams.

weapon->Frag Grenade (Tactical).name: Frag Grenade (Tactical)
weapon->Frag Grenade (Tactical).description:
Activate 1 Area Fire

Critical @Damage[1d4[bleed]]

These fragmentary grenades explode in a cloud of shrapnel and deal 2d8 piercing damage in a @Template[burst|distance:10] with a @Check[reflex|against:class|basic] save.

weapon->Battleglove.name: Battleglove
weapon->Battleglove.description:
Upgrades: 1

These durable gloves fit over a wielder's hands (or other appendages) and feature weighted plates or spikes over the knuckles.

equipment->Undermounted Grenade Launcher.name: Undermounted Grenade Launcher (Tactical)
equipment->Undermounted Grenade Launcher.description:
This bracket-mounted grenade launcher is most often advertised for use with fragmentation grenades, but can efficiently deploy utility ordinances, such as smoke grenades and flashbangs. Unlike a dedicated grenade launcher, it takes 10 minutes to load an undermounted grenade launcher, reassembling the grenade into ammunition by mounting it on a specialized reusable firing cap. Once a grenade has been loaded, it can only be safely removed by disassembling the entire grenade, destroying it in the process.

This grenade launcher has a range of 30 feet and the tracking +1 trait.

Activate—Launch 1 (attack)

Effect You launch the loaded grenade.

consumable->Spell Gem of Thunderstrike (.name: Spell Gem of Thunderstrike (Rank 3)
consumable->Spell Gem of Thunderstrike (.description:
@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.spells.Item.zDJS8E66UI0himqV]{Thunderstrike}

These latticed gemstones are suspended in a silicon casing and encoded with the magical script necessary to cast a single, specific spell. Casting a spell from a spell gem requires holding the gem in one hand and activating it with a Cast a Spell activity using the normal number of actions for that spell. The spell must appear on your spell list. Because you're the one Casting the Spell, use your spell attack modifier and spell DC. The spell must be of your spellcasting tradition. The spell in a spell gem can be cast only once, and the spell gem is destroyed as part of the casting. Spell gems can't contain cantrips or rituals. The traits for this item vary based on the spell it contains.

Activate Cast a Spell

Effect You Cast the Spell at the indicated rank.

action->Launch.name: Launch
action->Launch.description: undermounted frag grenade (@Template[type:burst|distance:10], consumable, range 30 feet, tech, tracking +1), Damage @Damage[2d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:23|basic] save; @Damage[1d4[persistent,bleed]|options:area-damage] damage on critical failure)

action->Navigational Spellshape.name: Navigational Spellshape
action->Navigational Spellshape.description: The aeon guard Flies using their jetpack, tracing arcane sigils through the air with their motion to empower their spells. If the next action the aeon guard uses is to Cast a Spell that has a range, increase that spell's range by 30 feet. In addition, if the spell requires an attack roll or a Reflex save, any targets of the spell that have lesser cover reduce the bonuses they gain from cover by 1 against the spell.

Skarak.name: Skarak
Skarak.publicNotes:
The skarak is a ravenous mass of spiked chitin and teeth propelled with frightening speed by a collection of spindly, arachnid legs. It rampages across its territories, consuming everything smaller than itself and taking delight in the destruction it leaves in its wake. It's difficult to hide from a skarak, as it'll rip down fortifications and smash through concrete walls to get at prey cowering inside buildings. It's even more difficult to run from a skarak since it can spit a corrosive webbing that magically binds its prey to itself, allowing it to pull its prey across any distance to within reach of its waiting maw.

A skarak possesses a terrible cunning to complement its destructive might. It often watches a targeted settlement for days, analyzing defenses before launching a devastating offensive. It's typically a solitary creature except when training a newly hatched brood to hunt. During this period, it ranges ahead of its young, rampaging through densely populated areas and leaving wounded, weakened targets behind it. Survivors of the initial rampage soon discover they aren't the lucky ones as the skarak young come after, devouring all in their path.

action->Destructive.name: Destructive
action->Destructive.description: A skarak's horn Strike bypasses the Hardness of structures made primarily of wood, stone, and metal.

action->Etheric Tether.name: Etheric Tether
action->Etheric Tether.description: A creature hit by a skarak's etheric web is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} by the skarak. The creature isn't @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized}, but it can't move beyond the maximum range of the skarak's etheric web. A creature can sever the etheric web with a Strike against AC 30 that deals at least 18 fire or force damage. This deals no damage to the skarak.

action->Rampage.name: Rampage
action->Rampage.description: The skarak makes a horn Strike against each creature within reach. These attacks count toward the skarak's multiple attack penalty, but the multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after the skarak makes all these attacks.

action->Tether Pull.name: Tether Pull
action->Tether Pull.description:
Requirements A creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} by the skarak's etheric tether

Effect The creature must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:33] save or be teleported to a space adjacent to the skarak of the skarak's choosing. This ends the grabbed condition from etheric tether unless the creature critically fails the save.

Skreeling.name: Skreeling
Skreeling.publicNotes:
Skreelings hunt in packs and can subsist on ash, metal, wood, or near anything else.

Skreesires, and their offspring skreelings, are vicious predators who skulk and prowl in the crags and caverns of the cosmos.

action->Cluster Attack.name: Cluster Attack
action->Cluster Attack.description: The skreeling's melee Strikes deal 1d4 persistent bleed damage to creatures within reach of one or more other skreelings.

Skreesire.name: Skreesire
Skreesire.publicNotes:
Skreesires are reptilian monstrosities with a formidable will, razor-sharp teeth, and nonfunctional wings atop a mass of ambulatory tentacles.

Skreesires, and their offspring skreelings, are vicious predators who skulk and prowl in the crags and caverns of the cosmos.
Skreesire.languagesDetails: Can't speak any language, Telepathy 100 feet

action->Camouflage.name: Camouflage
action->Camouflage.description:
Requirements The skreesire is in rocky terrain

Effect Until the next time they act, the skreesire resembles rocky terrain. They have an automatic result of 29 on @Check[deception] checks and DCs to pass as rocky terrain.

action->Enthrall.name: Enthrall
action->Enthrall.description:
Effect A target within 30 feet hears a telepathic manifestation of the skreesire's will and must attempt a @Check[will|dc:22] save.

Failure The creature must use the first action of its next turn to Stride toward the skreesire.

Critical Failure The creature must use all its actions on its next turn to Stride toward the skreesire; when it's adjacent to the skreesire, it drops @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} and ends its turn.

Snoop-Class Infiltrator Robot.name: Snoop-Class Infiltrator Robot
Snoop-Class Infiltrator Robot.publicNotes:
Not a front-line combatant, an infiltrator robot's primary tactic is to quietly enter a location, use its sleeping gas bombs to disable those guarding its target, and collect its payload. The leadership of the Pact Worlds found that the snoop-class infiltrator robot could have other, darker tasks during the Silent War: its reactive camouflage could help it transport deadly explosives to sabotage ships, shipyards, and other military installations.

Brought to the forefront during the war against the Veskarium, and further perfected by various corporate interests within the Pact Worlds, infiltrator robots are known for being able to get into places where no one else could. Generally small and agile, infiltrator robots sneak into enemy territory and either download precious data or record incriminating evidence.

weapon->Integrated Commercial Crossbolte.name: Integrated Commercial Crossbolter
weapon->Integrated Commercial Crossbolte.description:
Upgrades: 1

This high-tech crossbow uses a series of pistons to propel bolts along its barrel. These quiet-firing semiautomatic weapons are popular in high-density settlements where gunfire might cause a panic.

equipment->Integrated Hacking Toolkit (C.name: Integrated Hacking Toolkit (Commercial)
equipment->Integrated Hacking Toolkit (C.description: A hacking toolkit is required for Computers checks to Hack computers. You can use a hacking toolkit to access a computer without using a user interface, but this requires physical contact with the computer or contact via an infosphere or a similar linked network.

equipment->Integrated Infiltrator's Tool.name: Integrated Infiltrator's Toolkit (Commercial)
equipment->Integrated Infiltrator's Tool.description: You need an infiltrator's toolkit to @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.2EE4aF4SZpYf0R6H]{Pick Locks} or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{Disable Devices} (of some types) using the Thievery skill.

action->Reactive Camouflage.name: Reactive Camouflage
action->Reactive Camouflage.description: The robot comes packaged with photosensitive reflectors on its exterior panels. It can [[/act hide]] even without cover or concealment.

action->Sleeping Gas Bomb.name: Sleeping Gas Bomb
action->Sleeping Gas Bomb.description:
The infiltrator robot fires a bomb within 30 feet that disperses sleeping gas in a @Template[type:burst|distance:10]. Each creature in the area must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:18] save.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature takes a –1 status penalty to Perception checks for 1 round.

Failure The creature falls @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious}. If it's still unconscious after 1 minute, it wakes up automatically.

Critical Failure The creature falls unconscious. If it's still unconscious after 1 hour, it wakes up automatically.

Spined Renkroda.name: Spined Renkroda
Spined Renkroda.publicNotes:
Thickly built and burly, spined renkrodas live on open plains, mesas, and plateaus. Unlike most renkrodas, their frill is a deadly weapon, lined with hundreds of foot-long spines that serve as an excellent defense—and a deadly weapon.

Renkrodas are a family of large dinosaur-like predators native to the planet Castrovel. They've spread beyond the jungle planet's boundaries thanks to smugglers, poachers, and ultra-wealthy big-game hunters. Bipedal and strong with long necks and decorative spines, renkrodas are best known for their terrifying roars, which they bellow frequently as a form of long-range communication and to scare away other predators and scavengers. Over a dozen species of renkrodas exist, each specially adapted to their environment or ecological niche.

action->Spine Deflection.name: Spine Deflection
action->Spine Deflection.description:
Requirements The spined renkroda's spines are bristled

Trigger The spined renkroda would be hit by a ranged Strike, but the damage hasn't been rolled yet

Effect The spined renkroda twists its body, deflecting part of the attack with its spines, and gains resistance 10 to the triggering damage. Its spines are no longer bristled.

action->Bristle.name: Bristle
action->Bristle.description: The spined renkroda bristles its spines and adopts a defensive posture, gaining a +2 circumstance bonus to AC until it uses a move action, uses Spine Deflection, or makes any Strike other than a spine Strike. Any creature that attempts a melee attack against the spined renkroda takes @Damage[3d6[piercing]] damage, regardless of whether the attack hits.

action->Spine Barrage.name: Spine Barrage
action->Spine Barrage.description: The spined renkroda makes three ranged spine Strikes.

action->Terrifying Roar.name: Terrifying Roar
action->Terrifying Roar.description:
The spined renkroda bellows ferociously. Each non-renkroda creature within 60 feet must attempt a @Check[will|dc:32] save. The creature is then temporarily immune for 10 minutes.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 1}.

Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 2}.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TBSHQspnbcqxsmjL]{Frightened 3}.

Squox.name: Squox
Squox.publicNotes:
The tiny vulkarikis are a common animal in the Pact Worlds, originating from the planet Castrovel. Human explorers from Lost Golarion gave them the name "squox," as they interpreted the creatures as being a mix of fox and squirrel. Squoxes are cunning to the point of being devious and employ scare tactics to routinely abscond with shiny items they uncover on their travels. They exhibit complex social behaviors, including a distinct hierarchy between individuals in a skulk, and have a vast vocal repertoire used to assign signature sounds to different individual squoxes.

Having long since been exported from the Pact Worlds, squoxes are found throughout the galaxy, with many civilizations in Near Space maintaining growing communities of these tiny furry creatures, much to the growing consternation of the Xenowardens who worry that the highly adaptable squox has become an invasive species in several biomes. While some advocate for culling these populations, the popularity of the animal as a pet has made this view an incredibly unpopular stance.

Young squoxes are referred to as kits and can be purchased from the open market on most Pact Worlds. Squoxes tend to live for about 10 years. A typical squox weighs about 10 pounds and is about 3 feet long, with much of its length being its tail. Squoxes come in all colorations, and many even take on unique environmental adaptations to specific climates, such as desert-dwelling squoxes growing longer ears to help disperse heat.

action->Squox Tricks.name: Squox Tricks
action->Squox Tricks.description: A squox can [[/act disarm skill=acrobatics]] and [[/act trip skill=acrobatics]] creatures with its tail using Acrobatics instead of Athletics, even if it doesn't have a free hand. A squox can attempt to Disarm or Trip @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures up to two sizes larger than it and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to Disarm or Trip an off-guard target

action->Biotech.name: Biotech
action->Biotech.description: The biotech of a biotech zombie can be disabled for 1 hour by a creature that succeeds at a @Check[medicine|dc:18] of Life Science Lore check. Attempting to do so can typically be done only while within reach of the zombie and is a 2-action activity that has the manipulate trait. A biotech zombie with disabled biotech is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} and can't use any reactions.

action->Genetic Instability.name: Genetic Instability
action->Genetic Instability.description:
A biotech zombie must use this reaction unless its biotech is disabled

Trigger The zombie is reduced to 0 Hit Points

Effect The zombie melts into a caustic pool of biological goo, dealing @Damage[2d8[acid]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:10] (@Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save) and making that area hazardous terrain for 1 minute (1 acid damage). This ability destroys any organic items on the zombie (including biotech).

action->Dragon Gland.name: Dragon Gland
