action->Dragon Gland.description: The biotech zombie breathes a blast of flame that deals @Damage[4d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:cone|distance:15] (@Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save). The zombie can't use Dragon Gland again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Dragon Gland]]{1d4 rounds}.

Sterieid.name: Sterieid
Sterieid.publicNotes:
Sterieids reside on asteroids, relishing the beauty of their rocky, icy surfaces. Due to the ubiquity of asteroids, sterieids are the most common type of space nymph. Since many asteroids exist near one another in asteroid belts, sterieids are more likely to form communities among their own kind than other nymphs. Conversely, they tend to be wary of outsiders, despite visitors being less of a novelty. Those sterieids who desire company, however, build way stations on their asteroids for passing starships, offering food, amenities, and information about the local system.

Mining is a contentious issue for sterieids, who usually react with hostility to such operations. Most mining corporations will survey an asteroid to ensure it isn't protected by a sterieid before setting up shop, though less ethical companies have been known to pay mercenaries to "relocate" sterieid guardians of asteroids that contain valuable resources.

Nymphs are beautiful fey who appear as humanoids with elven features. They generally take female forms, but nymphs of all genders and presentations exist. While many nymphs live on planets and act as protectors of natural ponds, forests, caves, and cliffsides, other nymphs—often called space nymphs—are known for their association with celestial bodies. Like their planet-bound kin, space nymphs guard their bonded territories from exploitation or harm.

As admirers of the arts, nymphs are especially friendly toward creatives, and offering to depict a nymph in story, picture, or song is a sure way to win their favor—unless the nymph doesn't like the final result and lashes out at the artist for insulting them with a mediocre product. Vidcasting and livestreaming are popular pastimes among more sociable nymphs, whether to show off their remote environments or find audiences for performances. Some nymphs entice movie crews to film in their territories, with two provisos: first, that the production not damage the environment, and second, that the nymph receive a prominent role in the film.

Unless their territories are threatened, most space nymphs are friendly or indifferent to mortals, but they have long memories. Anyone visiting a space nymph's territory would be wise to research that nymph's grudges, past encounters with mortals, or any recent events in the area that might color the nymph's perspective of those traveling near their home.

A mortal who demonstrates the right attitude and abilities, such as by protecting a stellar body from destruction or creating an especially beautiful work of art, might draw a space nymph's attention. From time to time, space nymphs will offer their services as mentors to solarians or mystics, though they seldom seek pupils on their own. Space nymphs rarely enter into more than one such arrangement at a time and typically only make commitments that promise to last decades or centuries, so they're extremely selective in their choice of mentee.

action->Sense Transponder.name: Sense Transponder
action->Sense Transponder.description: While on their bonded celestial body, a nymph can sense approaching starships within a day's travel from the celestial body. This doesn't give them any information about the ship, its occupants, or its exact position. The nymph can send a message to the ship as if using a personal comm unit.

action->Asteroid-Dependent.name: Asteroid-Dependent
action->Asteroid-Dependent.description: A sterieid is mystically bonded to a small asteroid, no more than 1 mile across. If they're away from their bonded asteroid for more than 24 hours, they become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1} and must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:21] save each additional 24 hours or increase their drained value by 1. A sterieid can perform a 24-hour ritual to bond themself to a new asteroid.

action->Debris Field.name: Debris Field
action->Debris Field.description:
Trigger The sterieid takes physical damage

Effect Shards of rocky debris fly off the sterieid's body, dealing @Damage[2d12[bludgeoning]] damage to all adjacent creatures (@Check[reflex|dc:21|basic] save) and giving the sterieid the @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition until the end of their next turn.

action->Icy Nimbus.name: Icy Nimbus
action->Icy Nimbus.description: 10 feet. A sterieid's body radiates an icy chill. Creatures entering or starting their turns in the aura take @Damage[2d6[cold]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:21|basic] save); a creature that critically fails its save is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} until the start of its next turn as it grows sluggish from the cold.

Sterieid Queen.name: Sterieid Queen
Sterieid Queen.publicNotes:
The largest asteroids, some many miles across, are home to sterieid queens. As these asteroids more likely have a semblance of atmosphere, sterieid queens are accustomed to sharing their territory with other inhabitants and generally don't mind so long as they and the environment are treated with respect.

Nymphs are beautiful fey who appear as humanoids with elven features. They generally take female forms, but nymphs of all genders and presentations exist. While many nymphs live on planets and act as protectors of natural ponds, forests, caves, and cliffsides, other nymphs—often called space nymphs—are known for their association with celestial bodies. Like their planet-bound kin, space nymphs guard their bonded territories from exploitation or harm.

As admirers of the arts, nymphs are especially friendly toward creatives, and offering to depict a nymph in story, picture, or song is a sure way to win their favor—unless the nymph doesn't like the final result and lashes out at the artist for insulting them with a mediocre product. Vidcasting and livestreaming are popular pastimes among more sociable nymphs, whether to show off their remote environments or find audiences for performances. Some nymphs entice movie crews to film in their territories, with two provisos: first, that the production not damage the environment, and second, that the nymph receive a prominent role in the film.

Unless their territories are threatened, most space nymphs are friendly or indifferent to mortals, but they have long memories. Anyone visiting a space nymph's territory would be wise to research that nymph's grudges, past encounters with mortals, or any recent events in the area that might color the nymph's perspective of those traveling near their home.

A mortal who demonstrates the right attitude and abilities, such as by protecting a stellar body from destruction or creating an especially beautiful work of art, might draw a space nymph's attention. From time to time, space nymphs will offer their services as mentors to solarians or mystics, though they seldom seek pupils on their own. Space nymphs rarely enter into more than one such arrangement at a time and typically only make commitments that promise to last decades or centuries, so they're extremely selective in their choice of mentee.

action->Astronomical Ties.name: Astronomical Ties
action->Astronomical Ties.description:
A nymph queen is intrinsically tied to a specific celestial body, such as a supergiant star for a heliad queen.

As long as the queen is healthy, her territory thrives, and she can attempt to [[/r 1d20+21 #Counteract]] counteract spells and rituals that alter its physical properties with a counteract rank of 5.

If a nymph queen is injured or unhealthy, however, her celestial body also weakens: asteroids wobble out of orbit, stars dim, and the gravity of black holes diminishes. Restoring the nymph queen returns her celestial body to its equilibrium.

action->Debris Field.name: Debris Field
action->Debris Field.description:
Trigger The sterieid takes physical damage

Effect Shards of rocky debris fly off the sterieid's body, dealing @Damage[3d12[bludgeoning]] damage to all adjacent creatures (@Check[reflex|dc:29|basic] save) and giving the sterieid the @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.DmAIPqOBomZ7H95W]{Concealed} condition until the end of their next turn.

action->Icy Nimbus.name: Icy Nimbus
action->Icy Nimbus.description: 20 feet. A sterieid's body radiates an icy chill. Creatures entering or starting their turns in the aura take @Damage[3d6[cold]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:29|basic] save); a creature that critically fails its save is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} until the start of its next turn as it grows sluggish from the cold.

action->Broadcast Allure.name: Broadcast Allure
action->Broadcast Allure.description:
The nymph queen magically superimposes her image on all technological items capable of displaying it, such as datapads or comm units, within planetary range. Alternatively, she can send this image to any comm address or addresses that she knows.

Each creature that can see the image must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:29] or have their attitude toward her improve by one step (two steps on a critical failure).

Affected creatures' attitudes revert to their previous level if the nymph queen uses a hostile action against them or their allies.

action->Celestial Step.name: Celestial Step
action->Celestial Step.description: A nymph queen can traverse her celestial body near-instantaneously. A nymph queen can use Celestial Step to teleport to any area on or within her territory, vanishing into its surface and reemerging at her intended destination.

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description: Nymph queens can transform between their original form, which looks much like a typical nymph of their kind, and any Small or Medium humanoid form, typically choosing a version of their natural form with the appearance of the chosen species.

action->Fan Mail.name: Fan Mail
action->Fan Mail.description:
A nymph queen can inspire a single intelligent creature by sending them a motivational video or text message. As long as the creature keeps the message saved and remains in good standing with the nymph queen, they gain a +1 status bonus to all Crafting, Performance, and Lore checks related to art or performance.

As a 1-action Interact action, the creature can play or view the message to bolster their spirits. Doing so allows the creature to attempt a [[/r 1d20+21 #Counteract]] counteract check against a single emotion effect affecting them.

When the nymph queen's message is used in this way, it becomes a mundane video or text afterward.

Supenga Pup.name: Supenga Pup
Supenga Pup.publicNotes:
Supengas reproduce by fruiting, a process that can take months in a harsh desert environment. Pups often spend years learning to survive before they are ready to strike out on their own—or are kicked out.

When rains grow sparse in this succulent's native habitat, it turns to another source for liquid: blood. The supenga has adapted to a world of scarcity and takes advantage of any chance to hunt using its sharp leaves and paralyzing toxin.

action->Slowing Enzyme.name: Slowing Enzyme
action->Slowing Enzyme.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:20]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 –10-foot status penalty to all Speeds (1 round)

Stage 2 –10-foot status penalty to all Speeds and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} (2 rounds)

Stage 3 –20-foot status penalty to all Speeds and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2} (1 round)

action->Spinning Charge.name: Spinning Charge
action->Spinning Charge.description: The supenga pup curls into a ball and launches itself forward. It Strides up to twice its Speed in a straight line. If it ends this movement adjacent to an enemy, it bashes into that enemy, dealing @Damage[(3d8+3)[bludgeoning]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:22|basic] save). A creature that critically fails this save is knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

Supenga Titan.name: Supenga Titan
Supenga Titan.publicNotes:
These toxic titans can drain a living creature's blood in moments.

When rains grow sparse in this succulent's native habitat, it turns to another source for liquid: blood. The supenga has adapted to a world of scarcity and takes advantage of any chance to hunt using its sharp leaves and paralyzing toxin.

action->Siphon Blood.name: Siphon Blood
action->Siphon Blood.description:
Requirements A @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6uEgoh53GbXuHpTF]{Paralyzed}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.VcDeM8A5oI6VqhbM]{Restrained}, or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fBnFDH2MTzgFijKf]{Unconscious} living creature is within the supenga titan's reach

Effect The supenga titan absorbs the creature's blood with its spines. This requires an @Check[athletics|against:fortitude] check against the creature's Fortitude DC if the creature is grabbed but is otherwise automatic. The creature becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}, and the supenga titan regains @Damage[21[healing]] Hit Points.

action->Slowing Enzyme.name: Slowing Enzyme
action->Slowing Enzyme.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:36]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 –10-foot status penalty to all Speeds (1 round)

Stage 2 –10-foot status penalty to all Speeds and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} (2 rounds)

Stage 3 –20-foot status penalty to all Speeds and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 2} (1 round)

action->Spine Volley.name: Spine Volley
action->Spine Volley.description: The supenga titan makes up to four spine Strikes, each against a different target. The supenga titan's multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after it makes all the attacks.

Surnoch.name: Surnoch
Surnoch.publicNotes:
Surnochs inhabit lifeless asteroids and small moons throughout the cosmos. A surnoch's mouth is deep, funnel-like, and lined with numerous rows of sharp, pointed teeth, which allow it to grind matter down as it chews and melts its way through rock and stone. Surnochs have an innate sense of which minerals their bodies require most and can find these minerals even through miles of rocks. Surnochs excrete condensed forms of these minerals, leaving tunnels full of strange alloys and gem-quality materials in their wake.

When multiple surnochs gather together, their appetites synchronize, causing them to hunt for specific minerals en masse. The worms rain destruction on whole regions until their need is sated, then suddenly turn on each other in a show of dominance.

"Space worm" is a nonscientific term for a xenobiologically complex clade of invertebrate animals and beasts that make their home in the vastness of space. Some, like the diaspora and dust worms, show signs of intelligence and are directly related to each other. Others, like the surnoch, evolved separately, with their origins completely unknown to science.

action->Corrosive Spines.name: Corrosive Spines
action->Corrosive Spines.description: With impressive control, the surnoch can launch its spines in a tight grouping over a great distance. All creatures in a @Template[type:line|distance:30] take @Damage[8d8[piercing]|options:area-damage] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:25|basic] save. On a failure, the creature also takes @Damage[1d8[persistent,acid]|options:area-damage] damage (or @Damage[2d8[persistent,acid]|options:area-damage] damage on a critical failure). The surnoch can't use Corrosive Spines again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Corrosive Spines]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Surnoch's Kiss.name: Surnoch's Kiss
action->Surnoch's Kiss.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:25]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 3} (1 round)

action->Tail Smash.name: Tail Smash
action->Tail Smash.description: The surnoch's tail smash has a burst centered on a corner of its space. It's excluded from the burst.

action->Tunneling Expert.name: Tunneling Expert
action->Tunneling Expert.description: Surnochs have adapted to move swiftly underground. When burrowing, a surnoch worm leaves a tunnel behind itself. When moving through a previously created surnoch tunnel, it gains a +10-foot status bonus to its Speed.

Szynegator Swarm.name: Szynegator Swarm
Szynegator Swarm.publicNotes:
A single szynegator vibrating causes slight vertigo, but when these tiny beetle-like components harmonize, the atmospheric disruption they generate renders most forms of communication inoperable. Szynegators can usually be found in isolated or desolate areas of planets so their number can grow unimpeded. Their presence harbingers a full Swarm invasion.

Developing far out in the Vast from an insectile species known as kucharns, the Swarm is considered the greatest threat in existence for several cultures. Composed of countless subcolonies, each consisting of myriad component subspecies, the Swarm is a vast host that acts in psychic union for the purpose of consuming all matter across the cosmos. Most frightening of all is the Swarm's ability to assimilate the knowledge and DNA of those they consume. Thanks to its pre-Gap development of star travel, the Swarm had already consumed innumerable systems before history short-circuited, and the Swarm's pace only accelerated once it received access to the Signal and the hyperspace dimension known as the Drift.

Worlds touched by the Swarm are drained of their natural resources and rendered barren places known as huskworlds. What outsiders consider to be "Swarm space" is little more than a swathe of lifeless worlds that the Swarm have consumed in its reckless advance. The Swarm so thoroughly strips these worlds that surveyors struggle to find even trace amounts of inorganic resources, such as rare minerals and water. Few of these huskworlds have been thoroughly explored, as oftentimes exploration awakens inert drones, theorized to have been left behind in case the devoured system was ever colonized and repopulated. Pockets of Swarm activity exist well beyond this region of space, as the Swarm sent out countless subcolonies in the ages before the Gap, and even now, only some of them have reached their intended destinations.

The Swarm is perhaps most known in the current era for two important facts. First, its assault on the Pact Worlds and the Veskarium led to the cessation of hostilities and tenuous alliance between the two powers. Second, the Swarm is the direct ancestor of the shirren species. Having broken away sometime during the Gap, shirrens found succor with the deity Hylax, who was believed to have evolved from a pre-Swarm kucharn and who turned her back on the ravenous entity the Swarm has evolved into.

In recent years, the Swarm had been seen as little more than a distant boogeyman with no activities save for classified actions in the Suskillon system in the Vast. However, the recent discovery of the missing Szandite world of Krethiskar inadvertently awoke a dormant subcolony that had been responsible for the world's consumption. Since then, the newly dubbed Krethiskar subcolony has become a scourge of Near Space, engaged in an active invasion of Szandite Collective worlds and poised to spill over into other powers like the Veskarium and Pact Worlds. This rediscovered subcolony has begun rapid evolution of its components and remains cut off from the wider Swarm, but it still represents a clear danger to Near Space.

action->Motion Sense.name: Motion Sense
action->Motion Sense.description: An szynegator swarm can sense nearby creatures through vibrations in air or water caused by movement as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

action->Colony Mind.name: Colony Mind
action->Colony Mind.description: 30 feet. All allies with colony mind within the listed range of each other are in constant telepathic communication and are aware of all threats any individual knows about. While within range of at least one ally with colony mind, when a creature rolls a success on a save against a mental effect, it gets a critical success instead.

action->Comm Occlusion.name: Comm Occlusion
action->Comm Occlusion.description: 40 feet. All electronic and telepathic communication, except for that with the colony mind ability, ceases to function, and affected creatures take a –2 circumstance penalty to Perception checks. When three or more szynegator swarms are aware of each other using colony mind, the range of comm occlusion increases to 100 feet. This range increases to planetary when 10 or more szynegator swarms are aware of each other using colony mind.

action->Sonic Distortion.name: Sonic Distortion
action->Sonic Distortion.description: Each enemy in the szynegator swarm's space takes @Damage[1d8[sonic]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:18|basic] save).

Tashtari.name: Tashtari
Tashtari.publicNotes: Native to the green world of Castrovel, the tashtari has become known throughout the wider galaxy as the laser wolf. Wolflike pack hunters, tashtaris have a layer of flexible filaments that emit phosphorescent lights and allow them to silently communicate through a bespoke visual language. Each tashtari possesses a node within their throat that allows them to channel their stored solar energy and unleash a beam of focused light, giving them their moniker of laser wolves. A mating pair, consisting of one or two alphas, leads packs of tashtaris, who generally become the apex predators of large areas with one or more forested regions. The presence of trees is important for the nocturnal tashtaris, who sleep on the treetops during the day to bask in sunlight and recharge their solar energies.

action->Bristle Flash.name: Bristle Flash
action->Bristle Flash.description:
The tashtari causes their filaments to glow with intense light. Non-tashtari creatures within a @Template[type:emanation|distance:40] must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:19] save. A creature that attempts this save is immune to all Bristle Flashes for 1 minute. The tashtari's fur then dims, and they can't use this ability until they bask in sunlight for at least 10 minutes.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round.

Failure The creature is dazzled for 1 minute.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round and dazzled for 1 minute.

Tashtari Alpha.name: Tashtari Alpha
Tashtari Alpha.publicNotes: Native to the green world of Castrovel, the tashtari has become known throughout the wider galaxy as the laser wolf. Wolflike pack hunters, tashtaris have a layer of flexible filaments that emit phosphorescent lights and allow them to silently communicate through a bespoke visual language. Each tashtari possesses a node within their throat that allows them to channel their stored solar energy and unleash a beam of focused light, giving them their moniker of laser wolves. A mating pair, consisting of one or two alphas, leads packs of tashtaris, who generally become the apex predators of large areas with one or more forested regions. The presence of trees is important for the nocturnal tashtaris, who sleep on the treetops during the day to bask in sunlight and recharge their solar energies.

action->Bristle Flash.name: Bristle Flash
action->Bristle Flash.description:
The tashtari causes their filaments to glow with intense light. Non-tashtari creatures within a @Template[type:emanation|distance:40] must attempt a @Check[fortitude|dc:21] save. A creature that attempts this save is immune to all Bristle Flashes for 1 minute. The tashtari's fur then dims, and they can't use this ability until they bask in sunlight for at least 10 minutes.

Critical Success The creature is unaffected.

Success The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 round.

Failure The creature is dazzled for 1 minute.

Critical Failure The creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} for 1 round and dazzled for 1 minute.

action->Solar Cry.name: Solar Cry
action->Solar Cry.description: The tashtari alpha unleashes a searing, rainbow muzzle beam that soars into the sky before splitting into countless rays of multicolored light that crash down in every direction. Each non-tashtari creature in a @Template[type:emanation|distance:20] takes @Damage[4d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:19|basic] save). On a critical failure, a creature that can see the tashtari alpha is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} for 1 minute. Other tashtaris in the area recharge their Bristle Flash. The tashtari alpha's glowing heart dims, and they can't use this ability until they bask in sunlight for at least 1 hour.

Tax-Class Civil Robot.name: Tax-Class Civil Robot
Tax-Class Civil Robot.publicNotes:
Robotic tax collectors are used to track down debtors with outstanding payments and harass them into paying what they owe. AbadarCorp was the first such entity to utilize the technology and owns, operates, and rents a majority of the tax-class civil robots in the Pact Worlds to this day. AbadarCorp takes a portion of the payment and monitors their robots to make sure the transaction is legal, adding to the perceived legitimacy of these devices and shame of being followed by one in public. The robots will usually leave once given a small portion of the payment, often enough to pay any late fees, fines, and the cost of using the robot just to remind the debtor of their obligations; they're often treated as a minor but embarrassing nuisance and paid to leave without any trouble. Robots repurposed by loan sharks are often accompanied by other agents and programmed to collect payment in full.

Civil robots can be found in almost any large settlement, employed by the local government. They aren't meant to function as keepers of the peace, but instead perform minor functions, such as collecting refuse, aiding citizens with information, or collecting taxes. However, they can still defend themselves against vandals if necessary.

weapon->Integrated Pulsecaster Pistol (C.name: Integrated Pulsecaster Pistol (Commercial)
weapon->Integrated Pulsecaster Pistol (C.description:
Upgrades: 1

This imposing pistol fires a jolt of paralyzing electricity from its barrel. Its remaining charges are visible as glowing lines of energy radiating down its body. Pulsecaster pistols are often used by bounty hunters and law enforcement who need to keep their targets alive.

equipment->Integrated Infiltrator's Tool.name: Integrated Infiltrator's Toolkit (Commercial)
equipment->Integrated Infiltrator's Tool.description: You need an infiltrator's toolkit to @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.2EE4aF4SZpYf0R6H]{Pick Locks} or @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.actions.Item.cYdz2grcOcRt4jk6]{Disable Devices} (of some types) using the Thievery skill.

equipment->Integrated Datapad (Commercia.name: Integrated Datapad (Commercial)
equipment->Integrated Datapad (Commercia.description: These ubiquitous handheld computers incorporate a comm unit, microphone, speaker, camera, infosphere browser, and data storage. They can store thousands of hours of recordings, play games, and perform simple computing functions, such as time tracking and notifications, word processing, calculations, data processing, streaming media, and broadcasting emergency alerts from local governments. In most societies, commercial datapads are relatively flimsy, designed to rapidly wear out or fall behind on the latest features and updates to encourage the consumer to replace it with a newer model. In contrast, higher-end datapads are made to last and often include a sturdier chassis and extra functions.

equipment->Integrated Hacking Toolkit (C.name: Integrated Hacking Toolkit (Commercial)
equipment->Integrated Hacking Toolkit (C.description: A hacking toolkit is required for Computers checks to Hack computers. You can use a hacking toolkit to access a computer without using a user interface, but this requires physical contact with the computer or contact via an infosphere or a similar linked network.

action->Reactive Disarm.name: Reactive Disarm
action->Reactive Disarm.description:
Trigger A creature within the robot's reach attempts a melee or ranged Strike against the tax-class civil robot with a held weapon

Effect The robot uses its gasping hook to attempt to [[/act disarm]] the triggering creature's weapon with a +1 circumstance bonus to its check.

action->Tax Collector.name: Tax Collector
action->Tax Collector.description: A tax-class civil robot can be placated by paying the fees, fines, or taxes it seeks to collect by offering the robot a credstick with an Interact action. If the robot takes a target's equipment (see repossession), it will count half the equipment's value toward the total tax owed. A creature can attempt a 3-action activity to fool the robot by Hacking it using a hacking toolkit and succeeding at a @Check[computers|dc:18] or Accounting Lore check. Programmed to accept many forms of payment, the robot takes a –2 penalty to AC and saving throws against actions that use a Computers check, such as the Combat Hack skill feat.

action->Repossession.name: Repossession
action->Repossession.description: When a tax-class civil robot succeeds at a check to [[/act steal]] or critically succeeds at a check to [[/act disarm]] an item, it immediately picks up the item (if necessary) and stows it in a lockbox in the robot's frame. The robot can open the lockbox with a single Interact action without difficulty, but others must Pick the Lock (DC 18); a creature that attempts to do so while the tax-class civil robot is aware takes a –4 circumstance penalty to the check.

weapon->Cryopike.name: Cryopike
weapon->Cryopike.description:
Upgrades: 1

This polearm's shaft houses rapidly circulating supercooled gas that condenses and channels endothermic energy into a cryogenic blade.

weapon->Laser Rifle.name: Laser Rifle
weapon->Laser Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

These dependable, mass-produced rifles shoot concentrated beams of energy out of square-shaped barrels. The universal standard Pact Worlds model is highly modifiable and designed to function with a variety of accessories and upgrades, with wielders adapting the laser rifle to their preferences and even kit-bashing it into a nearly unrecognizable weapon.

weapon->Nano-edge Rapier.name: Nano-edge Rapier
weapon->Nano-edge Rapier.description:
Upgrades: 1

The edge of this precision-crafted foil is sharpened to the thickness of a single atom, using regenerating nanites to maintain itself after countless strikes.

armor->Second Skin.name: Second Skin
armor->Second Skin.description:
Upgrades: 0

Soft but resilient fabric contours perfectly to the wearer's body, offering basic protection without sacrificing comfort. Second skin is commonly worn underneath casual clothing.

action->Change Shape.name: Change Shape
action->Change Shape.description: A temporai can take the appearance of any Small, Medium, or Large humanoid. This doesn't change their Speed or their attack and damage modifiers with their Strikes, but it might change the damage type their Strikes deal.

action->Multidexterous.name: Multidexterous
action->Multidexterous.description: A temporai can Switch Hands as a free action.

action->Out of Time.name: Out of Time
action->Out of Time.description:
The temporai turns their gaze to a single target within 120 feet, forcing upon it all the fragments of time it has shed. The target takes @Damage[12d8[mental]] damage and must attempt a @Check[will|dc:34] save. Regardless of the result, the target then becomes temporarily immune to Out of Time for 1 day.

Critical Success The target takes no damage.

Success The target takes half damage and becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1}, @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.4D2KBtexWXa6oUMR]{Drained 1}, and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1}, or increases these conditions by 1.

Failure As success, but full damage and the conditions' value is 2.

Critical Failure As success, but double damage and the conditions' value is 3.

action->Sands of Time.name: Sands of Time
action->Sands of Time.description: With a flick of their wrist, the temporai disperses a wave of time-altering sand, dealing @Damage[15d6[spirit]|options:area-damage] damage to all creatures in a @Template[type:cone|distance:60] (@Check[fortitude|dc:34|basic] save). Creatures that fail their save are additionally slowed for [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds}. The temporai can't use Sands of Time again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Sands of Time]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Sense Fate.name: Sense Fate
action->Sense Fate.description: A temporai always rolls a 20 for initiative

action->Shepherd's Touch.name: Shepherd's Touch
action->Shepherd's Touch.description: An erabryth's Strikes have the benefit of a ghost killer upgrade and deal an extra 5d6 void damage to living creatures or 5d6 vitality damage to undead.

Tergaiator.name: Tergaiator
Tergaiator.publicNotes:
Amid space's asteroid belts and atop their rocky exteriors rest the homes of these massive, competition-loving elementals. Tergaiators augment their bodies with pieces of asteroid as they wrestle and jump around. They thrive off the nutrients within asteroids and fight to protect their homes from being excessively farmed by greedy mining ventures.

Elementals are energetic intrusions from the primal planes of existence. They take many forms, from mindless eddies in the wind or water to complex entities capable of wielding primal magic. The advent of space travel and the progress of technology have allowed even more living embodiments of the elements to manifest in the Universe.

Natural events like wildfires, solar storms, and floods can unleash hordes of unruly elementals on a planet or into a region of space. Sometimes, a gathering of powerful elementals causes a natural disaster on an epic scale, like an off-the-charts solar flare that fries a planet's power grid or a ceaseless storm swirling in a gas giant's atmosphere.

action->Meteoric Death Drop.name: Meteoric Death Drop
action->Meteoric Death Drop.description:
Frequency once per day

Requirements The tergaiator has a creature @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed}

Effect The tergaiator launches themself and their victim high up in the air before crashing down. The creature takes @Damage[5d8[bludgeoning]] damage and @Damage[1d6[fire]] damage with a @Check[fortitude|dc:30|basic] save. On a failure, the creature also falls @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone} in an unoccupied adjacent square of the tergaiator's choice; on a critical failure, the creature is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.dfCMdR4wnpbYNTix]{Stunned 1}. After using Meteoric Death Drop, reduce the tergaiator's size by one category, their reach by 5 feet, and their Strike damage by 2 for 1 day.

action->Orbital Lariat.name: Orbital Lariat
action->Orbital Lariat.description:
Frequency once per minute

Effect The tergaiator hurtles toward their foes, using the momentum to launch a spinning flurry of attacks with outstretched arms. They Stride and make a melee Strike against any number of creatures within reach at the end of their movement. Each Strike applies to the tergaiator's multiple attack penalty, but the multiple attack penalty doesn't increase until after they make all of their attacks. After making these attacks, the tergaiator is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} until the start of their next turn.

Terrible Roar.name: Terrible Roar
Terrible Roar.descriptionHazard:
The kyokor unleashes a terrible roar.

When a kyokor passes by or through a settlement—or even attacks!—it leaves a trail of destruction that can be represented by the following hazards.

Terrifying, skyscraper-sized beasts roam the wastelands of Daimalko. Called colossi by the population, these monsters erupted from deep within the earth to stomp cities into dust, decimating the population and destroying every surface civilization on the planet in a terrifying Awakening. Kyokors are among the most dreaded colossi. There's no hope of defeating one without a valko—a war machine created by Daimalko's stubborn survivors to fight the colossi.
Terrible Roar.reset: The kyokor must wait [[/gmr 1d4 #rounds]]{1d4 rounds} before roaring again.

action->Thundering Roar.name: Thundering Roar
action->Thundering Roar.description:
Trigger A creature takes a hostile action against the kyokor, produces a visible area effect, or flies within 120 feet of the kyokor

Effect The kyokor roars, producing a @Template[type:cone|distance:120] of sound in the direction of the triggering creature. Unattended objects of 5 or less Hardness immediately gain the broken condition, and concrete and metal surfaces warp into difficult terrain. Creatures in the area take @Damage[20d6[sonic]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:44|basic] save). On a failure, a creature also takes @Damage[3d6[persistent,mental]|options:area-damage] damage and is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2}.

Terror of Ukulam.name: Terror of Ukulam
Terror of Ukulam.publicNotes:
When a massive ooze-like being emerged from the polluted caverns of Castrovel's industrial moon, Elindrae, the planet's leaders made the mistake of assuming the ooze posed no threat to Castrovel itself. When the ooze destroyed several of the moon's shipyards, then launched itself through space to the remote reaches of Ukulam, they made the mistake of assuming they had time to quarantine the threat in that continent's remote wilderness. When its radiation began to spread, and long-dead elindrian cultists rose from their nest-necropolises beneath the Singing Range to worship the ooze, the planet's leaders finally understood they couldn't ignore it. They called it the Terror of Ukulam. They still don't understand quite what it is, why it exists, or what it wants.

The Terror is an enormous ooze-like thing, somewhat resembling layered flaps of oily dark green flesh. It conceals its only anatomical feature—a large purple eye—beneath its undulating surface. The creature spends most of its time floating in deep subterranean caverns or ocean trenches, remaining immobile for days at a time, then suddenly traversing a great distance, almost always in a straight line, before stopping again. These stops are seemingly random, but they've displaced settlements with increasing regularity. The vengeful worshippers who follow the Terror's path are almost as dangerous as the radiation it spreads, though their reasons for following it are as inscrutable as the Terror itself.

Thanks to the nature of atomic energy and especially atomic weapons, Castrovel's scientists have deduced that the radioactive Terror is likely to cause as much destruction in death as it has caused in life—or perhaps more. Even if the combined military might of Castrovel and its allies was sufficient to defeat the Terror, these scientists have warned that they need more time to study the Terror and assess the risks of destroying it outright. Of course, every day that passes is another day that more elindrians flock to the Terror, and yet more victims cross its destructive path.

action->Voice of Linked Minds.name: Voice of Linked Minds
action->Voice of Linked Minds.description: The Terror doesn't speak, but it can psychically communicate complex concepts with any creature within 200 feet that is part of a hive mind, husk mind, or similar shared mind. Other creatures that can communicate telepathically can somewhat understand the Terror, but their understanding is vague.

action->Ancient Bond.name: Ancient Bond
action->Ancient Bond.description: The Terror commands obedience from creatures on Castrovel, suggesting an ancient connection to the planet. Wild creatures native to Castrovel or its moon must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:45] saving throw when they first come within 200 feet of it on a given day; on a failure, they improve their attitude toward the Terror to friendly. Creatures that become friendly typically approach the Terror, resulting in a painful death by radiation sickness.

action->Radioactive Death.name: Radioactive Death
action->Radioactive Death.description: When the Terror of Ukulam dies, it explodes in a radioactive blast that instantly vaporizes all creatures and objects within 30 miles and deals @Damage[45d12[fire]] damage to all creatures, objects, and structures in a 150-mile-radius emanation with a @Check[fortitude|dc:45|basic] save. Creatures in the area are also exposed to terrible radiation sickness. The terrain and any bodies of water (or suitable portions of larger bodies, such as oceans, at the GM's discretion) become terribly radioactive for a minimum of 50 years, after which time they slowly become less radioactive, using less severe degrees of radiation from GM Core at the GM's discretion.

action->Terribly Radioactive.name: Terribly Radioactive
action->Terribly Radioactive.description: 120 feet. The Terror spreads radiation everywhere it goes. Non-creature plants near the Terror quickly wither and die. Any creature that begins its turn within the aura is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 3} and is exposed to terrible radiation sickness each round.

action->Induce Frenzy.name: Induce Frenzy
action->Induce Frenzy.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The Terror stirs creatures in hive minds into a frenzy. Each creature within 200 feet that's part of a hive mind gains the @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.nlCjDvLMf2EkV2dl]{Quickened} condition for 1 minute, and it can use the extra action each round only to Stride or Strike.

action->Terrible Radiation Sickness.name: Terrible Radiation Sickness
action->Terrible Radiation Sickness.description:
This radiation causes unimaginably painful burns, unrelenting nausea, and death

Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:45]

Onset 1 hour

Stage 1 @Damage[13d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (1 hour)

Stage 2 @Damage[14d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} (1 hour)

Stage 3 @Damage[15d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 3} (1 hour)

Stage 4 death

action->Toxic Touch.name: Toxic Touch
action->Toxic Touch.description: Creatures struck by the Terror's sludge tendril gain weakness 10 to poison and take a –2 status penalty to Fortitude saves for 1 round.

action->Undulating Wrath.name: Undulating Wrath
action->Undulating Wrath.description: The Terror Strikes with its sludge tendrils six times.

action->Vorpal Eye Beam.name: Vorpal Eye Beam
action->Vorpal Eye Beam.description: The Terror pulls back a lid of oozy "skin" to reveal its only anatomical feature—an enormous dark purple eye—firing an invisible particle beam along the path of its gaze. The beam is 10 feet wide and 120 feet long. Creatures in the area take @Damage[18d8[slashing]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:45|basic] save). Creatures that critically fail their save are instantly decapitated. This kills any creature except ones that don't require a head to live. For creatures with multiple heads, this usually kills the creature only if its last head is severed. The Terror can't use Vorpal Eye Beam again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Vorpal Eye Beam]]{1d4 rounds}. During this time, it loses immunity to critical hits and precision damage.

Thasteron Khefak.name: Thasteron Khefak
Thasteron Khefak.publicNotes:
When khefaks consume thasteron, they take on a crystalline appearance and grow into territorial, ravenous threats.

Khefak Biogenetics bioengineered khefaks to consume scrap thasteron so the waste could be refined into starship fuel. These creatures eventually became a prime example of a solution becoming a problem of its own. After the discovery of Drift travel, Akiton's thasteron market plummeted, removing the need for mining infrastructure, including khefaks. Khefak Biogenetics destroyed the production facilities, thinking they'd completely eradicated their creations. Khefaks are hardy, however, and the few survivors left the facilities. Beyond thasteron, they subsisted on inorganic materials, and their rapid reproduction rate allowed them to quickly spread all over Akiton. Some stowed away on starships, allowing them to spread throughout the Pact Worlds.

action->Gnaw Scrap.name: Gnaw Scrap
action->Gnaw Scrap.description: A khefak chews on an unattended object to feed, dealing @Damage[4[piercing]] damage every 10 minutes to the object. This damage ignores 10 points of Hardness. If a khefak doesn't spend at least 1 hour Gnawing Scrap per day, it begins to starve until it spends 10 minutes Gnawing Scrap.

action->Thasteron Radiation.name: Thasteron Radiation
action->Thasteron Radiation.description: 10 feet. A thasteron khefak gives off an aura of mild radiation. A creature who starts its turn in the aura must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:20] save or take @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage and become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}.

Thermatrod.name: Thermatrod
Thermatrod.publicNotes:
A standard thermatrod dwells near volcanic vents and other sources of intense heat.

Originally thought to be exiles from the Plane of Fire, thermatrods actually developed independently in multiple star systems in the Universe. A thermatrod resembles a molten bipedal creature, though they often walk on their front knuckles to support their heavy frames. Thermatrods sport distinctive raised dorsal plates that resemble hexagonal basalt columns, which researchers use to estimate an individual's age. A thermatrod's hardened exterior varies greatly based on local mineral deposits that make up a thermatrod's diet.

action->Temperature Sense.name: Temperature Sense
action->Temperature Sense.description: A thermatrod can detect nearby changes in temperature as a precise sense to detect living creatures and other heat sources.

action->Melting Aura.name: Melting Aura
action->Melting Aura.description: 10 feet. A creature that begins its turn within this aura takes @Damage[1d6[fire]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:17|basic] save).

action->Slag Barrage.name: Slag Barrage
action->Slag Barrage.description: The thermatrod sprays part of its molten core in a @Template[type:cone|distance:15] that hardens moments later. Each creature in the area takes @Damage[4d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:20|basic] save). A creature that fails the save is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} ([[/act escape dc=20]]). The thermatrod can't use Slag Barrage again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Slag Barrage]]{1d4 rounds}.

Thermatrod Caldera.name: Thermatrod Caldera
Thermatrod Caldera.publicNotes:
Under certain electromagnetic conditions, two or more thermatrods might eject their molten cores into a shared magma chamber. The conjoined material forms a caldera, a mighty beast with starmetal veins running through its plates.

Originally thought to be exiles from the Plane of Fire, thermatrods actually developed independently in multiple star systems in the Universe. A thermatrod resembles a molten bipedal creature, though they often walk on their front knuckles to support their heavy frames. Thermatrods sport distinctive raised dorsal plates that resemble hexagonal basalt columns, which researchers use to estimate an individual's age. A thermatrod's hardened exterior varies greatly based on local mineral deposits that make up a thermatrod's diet.

action->Temperature Sense.name: Temperature Sense
action->Temperature Sense.description: A thermatrod caldera can detect nearby changes in temperature as a precise sense to detect living creatures and other heat sources.

action->Melting Aura.name: Melting Aura
action->Melting Aura.description: 15 feet. A creature that begins its turn within this aura takes @Damage[4d6[fire]] damage (@Check[fortitude|dc:26|basic] save).

action->Slag Barrage.name: Slag Barrage
action->Slag Barrage.description: The thermatrod sprays part of its molten core in a @Template[type:cone|distance:15] that hardens moments later. Each creature in the area takes @Damage[11d6[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:29|basic] save). A creature that fails the save is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized} ([[/act escape dc=29]]). The thermatrod can't use Slag Barrage again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Slag Barrage]]{1d4 rounds}.

Thresher Lord.name: Thresher Lord
Thresher Lord.publicNotes:
Engineered to be heavy assault forces, thresher lords break enemy formations and cut paths through fortifications to make way for masses of infantry components. The enormous blades protruding from their forearms have evolved not just as weapons, but to provide both aerodynamic support and a modicum of protection while thresher lords close into melee range.

Developing far out in the Vast from an insectile species known as kucharns, the Swarm is considered the greatest threat in existence for several cultures. Composed of countless subcolonies, each consisting of myriad component subspecies, the Swarm is a vast host that acts in psychic union for the purpose of consuming all matter across the cosmos. Most frightening of all is the Swarm's ability to assimilate the knowledge and DNA of those they consume. Thanks to its pre-Gap development of star travel, the Swarm had already consumed innumerable systems before history short-circuited, and the Swarm's pace only accelerated once it received access to the Signal and the hyperspace dimension known as the Drift.

Worlds touched by the Swarm are drained of their natural resources and rendered barren places known as huskworlds. What outsiders consider to be "Swarm space" is little more than a swathe of lifeless worlds that the Swarm have consumed in its reckless advance. The Swarm so thoroughly strips these worlds that surveyors struggle to find even trace amounts of inorganic resources, such as rare minerals and water. Few of these huskworlds have been thoroughly explored, as oftentimes exploration awakens inert drones, theorized to have been left behind in case the devoured system was ever colonized and repopulated. Pockets of Swarm activity exist well beyond this region of space, as the Swarm sent out countless subcolonies in the ages before the Gap, and even now, only some of them have reached their intended destinations.

The Swarm is perhaps most known in the current era for two important facts. First, its assault on the Pact Worlds and the Veskarium led to the cessation of hostilities and tenuous alliance between the two powers. Second, the Swarm is the direct ancestor of the shirren species. Having broken away sometime during the Gap, shirrens found succor with the deity Hylax, who was believed to have evolved from a pre-Swarm kucharn and who turned her back on the ravenous entity the Swarm has evolved into.

In recent years, the Swarm had been seen as little more than a distant boogeyman with no activities save for classified actions in the Suskillon system in the Vast. However, the recent discovery of the missing Szandite world of Krethiskar inadvertently awoke a dormant subcolony that had been responsible for the world's consumption. Since then, the newly dubbed Krethiskar subcolony has become a scourge of Near Space, engaged in an active invasion of Szandite Collective worlds and poised to spill over into other powers like the Veskarium and Pact Worlds. This rediscovered subcolony has begun rapid evolution of its components and remains cut off from the wider Swarm, but it still represents a clear danger to Near Space.

action->Motion Sense.name: Motion Sense
action->Motion Sense.description: A thresher lord can sense nearby creatures through vibrations in air or water caused by movement as an imprecise sense at the listed range.

action->Colony Mind.name: Colony Mind
action->Colony Mind.description: 30 feet. All allies with colony mind within the listed range of each other are in constant telepathic communication and are aware of all threats any individual knows about. While within range of at least one ally with colony mind, when a creature rolls a success on a save against a mental effect, it gets a critical success instead.

action->Deflecting Blades.name: Deflecting Blades
action->Deflecting Blades.description:
Trigger A creature adjacent to the thresher lord targets the thresher lord with a melee attack

Effect The thresher lord gains a +2 circumstance bonus to AC against the triggering attack.

action->Blade Storm.name: Blade Storm
action->Blade Storm.description: The thresher lord makes three arm blade Strikes. Each Strike uses the thresher lord's current multiple attack penalty, but each Strike takes a –2 penalty. This counts as three attacks when calculating its multiple attack penalty.

action->Hurtle.name: Hurtle
action->Hurtle.description:
Frequency three times per day

Effect The thresher lord Strides up to three times its Speed in a straight line.

action->Serrated Blades.name: Serrated Blades
action->Serrated Blades.description: On a critical hit with an arm blade Strike, the thresher lord inflicts @Damage[1d8[persistent,bleed]] damage to its target.

Tool Rat.name: Tool Rat
Tool Rat.publicNotes:
The tool rat resembles an infant of their kind, but closer study reveals coppery whiskers akin to a dwarven beard and eyebrows. Intuitive spellcraft helps them turn junkyards into minefields for the unwary

When pileups of metal garbage begin to conquer the wilderness, rodents conquer the garbage. Scrap rats adapt to every civilization that disposes their ruined gadgets and industrial debris, all of which the rats recycle and reuse to potentially deadly effect. While not especially intelligent, they have an innate knack for crafting.

weapon->Arc Rifle.name: Arc Rifle
weapon->Arc Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

This rifle's oversized body contains a larger version of an arc pistol capacitor, with a short barrel and polycarbon stock designed to insulate the wielder from high voltage. The arc rifle's larger capacitor allows it to produce a charge with enough power to subdue a rampaging renkroda.

action->Scoring.name: Scoring
action->Scoring.description:
When the tool rat's tail Strike deals damage to an object or creature with the tech trait, the tail also gains the following traits until the beginning of the scrap rat's next turn: deadly d4, hampering, and razing.

@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.bestiary-effects.Item.GpzaKY9WlDFAhgcg]{Effect: Scoring}

action->Upscaled Recycling.name: Upscaled Recycling
action->Upscaled Recycling.description: Over the course of 1 hour of uninterrupted work, a tool rat can assemble a simple tactical weapon of any type, up to 2nd level, including a single @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.equipment.Item.0jSc8zqUPnAByMf9]{commercial battery} or a full magazine of projectile ammunition. using nothing but junk. It falls apart and becomes unusable junk after 10 minutes.

Trained Squox.name: Trained Squox
Trained Squox.publicNotes:
The tiny vulkarikis are a common animal in the Pact Worlds, originating from the planet Castrovel. Human explorers from Lost Golarion gave them the name "squox," as they interpreted the creatures as being a mix of fox and squirrel. Squoxes are cunning to the point of being devious and employ scare tactics to routinely abscond with shiny items they uncover on their travels. They exhibit complex social behaviors, including a distinct hierarchy between individuals in a skulk, and have a vast vocal repertoire used to assign signature sounds to different individual squoxes.

Having long since been exported from the Pact Worlds, squoxes are found throughout the galaxy, with many civilizations in Near Space maintaining growing communities of these tiny furry creatures, much to the growing consternation of the Xenowardens who worry that the highly adaptable squox has become an invasive species in several biomes. While some advocate for culling these populations, the popularity of the animal as a pet has made this view an incredibly unpopular stance.

Young squoxes are referred to as kits and can be purchased from the open market on most Pact Worlds. Squoxes tend to live for about 10 years. A typical squox weighs about 10 pounds and is about 3 feet long, with much of its length being its tail. Squoxes come in all colorations, and many even take on unique environmental adaptations to specific climates, such as desert-dwelling squoxes growing longer ears to help disperse heat.

action->Go for the Eyes!.name: Go for the Eyes!
action->Go for the Eyes!.description:
The squox Strides, attempts an @Check[acrobatics|against:perception] check against an adjacent creature's Perception DC, and then makes a jaws Strike.

Critical Success Thrown by the squox's sudden leap, the target is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the end of the squox's next turn.

Success The target is only momentarily startled and is off-guard until the end of the squox's current turn.

Critical Failure The squox misjudges the distance to its target's face and falls @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}.

action->Squox Tricks.name: Squox Tricks
action->Squox Tricks.description: A squox can [[/act disarm skill=acrobatics]] and [[/act trip skill=acrobatics]] creatures with its tail using Acrobatics instead of Athletics, even if it doesn't have a free hand. A squox can attempt to Disarm or Trip @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} creatures up to two sizes larger than it and gains a +2 circumstance bonus to Disarm or Trip an off-guard target

Trawler.name: Trawler
Trawler.publicNotes:
Experienced explorers of Castrovel know to monitor the sky, lest they be caught unaware by a diaphanous trawler. A trawler can spin a filament with sticky coating that has a mild anesthetic effect, allowing them to stalk at a distance and then pull their prey in close, all while comfortably airborne.

It's extremely rare for an adult trawler to land or alight on anything voluntarily. Usually, they maintain at least a minimal air gap between themself and any object. If forced to be on the ground, a trawler can use their tentacles to clumsily ambulate, though more often than not, they'll launch themself into the air given the first opportunity.

action->Transparency.name: Transparency
action->Transparency.description: Unless they've fed recently, the trawler is naturally fully transparent, allowing them to [[/act hide]] without concealment or cover and granting them a +4 circumstance bonus to Stealth checks to Hide. A trawler loses this transparency if they take a hostile action of any kind.

action->Reel In.name: Reel In
action->Reel In.description:
Requirements The trawler has a Medium or smaller creature @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} with its lasso filament

Effect The trawler pulls the creature toward themself. They attempt an Athletics check against the target's Fortitude DC. A trawler can lift a creature off the ground in this way.

Critical Success The target is moved 20 feet closer to the trawler.

Success The target is moved 10 feet closer to the trawler.

Critical Failure The trawler releases the target.

action->Sticky Filaments.name: Sticky Filaments
action->Sticky Filaments.description: A creature hit by the trawler's lasso filament becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} by the trawler. The creature isn't @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.eIcWbB5o3pP6OIMe]{Immobilized}, but it can't move beyond the range of the lasso filament. A creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.i3OJZU2nk64Df3xm]{Clumsy 1} for as long as it's grabbed by a lasso filament. A creature can sever the filament with a Strike against AC 19 that deals at least 6 fire or slashing damage. This deals no damage to the trawler but destroys the filament. A trawler has three lasso filaments, and they can't use their lasso filament Strike if all three are destroyed. It takes a week for the trawler to regrow all three of their filaments.

action->Trawler Venom.name: Trawler Venom
action->Trawler Venom.description:
Saving Throw @Check[fortitude|dc:20]

Maximum Duration 6 rounds

Stage 1 @Damage[1d4[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 1} (1 round)

Stage 2 @Damage[1d6[poison]] damage and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.MIRkyAjyBeXivMa7]{Enfeebled 2} (1 round)

Stage 3 @Damage[2d4[poison]] damage, enfeebled 2, and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} (1 round)

Stage 4 @Damage[2d6[poison]] damage, enfeebled 2, and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 2} (1 round)

Tregalxi.name: Tregalxi
Tregalxi.publicNotes:
Tregalxis generally look like a knotted bundle of electrical wiring. Their true form is a shifting ball of radioactive energy safely nestled within their wired shell. Tregalxis need a near-constant source of power to safely maintain their radiation. They're most often found parasitically integrated into a ship's wiring, secretly siphoning power or wedged into a reactor. They leech power from the chosen source until they become either satiated or bored enough to seek out a new power source.

Theoretically, a wayward tregalxi could find their way into a large ship's power core, a city power grid, or the control center for a satellite, where they would most certainly cause power outages and malfunctions, all while becoming incrementally more powerful and destructive.

Elementals are energetic intrusions from the primal planes of existence. They take many forms, from mindless eddies in the wind or water to complex entities capable of wielding primal magic. The advent of space travel and the progress of technology have allowed even more living embodiments of the elements to manifest in the Universe.

Natural events like wildfires, solar storms, and floods can unleash hordes of unruly elementals on a planet or into a region of space. Sometimes, a gathering of powerful elementals causes a natural disaster on an epic scale, like an off-the-charts solar flare that fries a planet's power grid or a ceaseless storm swirling in a gas giant's atmosphere.

action->Wire Sense.name: Wire Sense
action->Wire Sense.description: A tregalxi can sense the presence of electrical wires within 30 feet as an imprecise sense.

action->Insulated Shell.name: Insulated Shell
action->Insulated Shell.description: When a tregalxi is reduced to less than half their Hit Points, their insulated wire shell breaks, freeing their contained radiation. All electricity damage dealt by the tregalxi instead becomes poison damage. When a creature takes poison damage from a tregalxi, it becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1} for 1 minute with no way to reduce the condition.

action->Circuit Splice.name: Circuit Splice
action->Circuit Splice.description: The tregalxi extends their wire frame to all enemies within 30 feet. Each creature takes @Damage[2d6[piercing]] and @Damage[2d6[electricity]] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:20|basic] save). The tregalxi can't use Circuit Splice again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Circuit Splice]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Short Circuit.name: Short Circuit
action->Short Circuit.description: When a creature makes direct contact with a tregalxi's wires, the creature takes @Damage[1d6[electricity]] damage with a @Check[reflex|dc:20|basic] save.

Typodaemon.name: Typodaemon
Typodaemon.publicNotes:
These child-sized daemons represent the horrors of death through dictation errors, transcription woes, or incorrect copying and pasting of text. Typodaemons make discreet adjustments to text, changing a word, adding a taunting emote, or adjusting punctuation to create entirely new meanings for written words. These changes lead to conflicts, and the typodaemon thrives on the strife and potential for death because of these simple errors.

Hailing from the plane of Abaddon, daemons are utterly devoted to the destruction of all life. Their existence is based around specific means of death, and they seek the death of all things in service to their lords: the Apocalypse Riders. Each daemon represents a different way to die, and they use their specific powers to further that means of death.

Advents in technology have only created new means of death and torment, so new types of daemons enter existence with regularity, each created once a sufficient mass of new deaths occurs to spawn them. These new advent daemons often prefer to spend their time in the galaxy rather than Abaddon, as they can better spread their torments to the mortals of creation.

action->Input Overload Aura.name: Input Overload Aura
action->Input Overload Aura.description: 20 feet. Enemies in the aura take a –1 status penalty to AC and all saves against sonic effects or effects that alter written or stored data. A creature within this aura attempting to read a document must succeed at a @Check[flat|dc:5] or cannot read the document for the next [[/gmr 1d4+1]]{1d4+1 rounds}.

action->Pedant Annoyance.name: Pedant Annoyance
action->Pedant Annoyance.description: Typodaemons paradoxically despise having their errors pointed out. If a creature Interacts to correct the grammar or syntax of something the typodaemon has written or is writing, including with a spell such as implant data, the typodaemon becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.fesd1n5eVhpCSS18]{Sickened 1}. While sickened this way, the daemon must spend an action to justify its actions instead of retching, attempting a @Check[will] save instead to remove the condition.

action->Error Injection.name: Error Injection
action->Error Injection.description: The typodaemon remotely accesses the code of a visible item with the tech trait within 60 feet and injects erroneous data. The item becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.6A2QDy8wRGCVQsSd]{Glitching 2}; if the item is in possession of a creature, the creature must attempt a @Check[will|dc:18|options:inflicts:glitching] save, negating the effect on a success. The item is then immune to Error Injection for 1 hour.

Ulgaazan Nyssholora.name: Ulgaazan Nyssholora
Ulgaazan Nyssholora.publicNotes:
The largest nyssholora ever recorded was Ulgaaza the Ageless, a mythical creature so old and so massive it was said to dwarf mountains. Today, any nyssholora that reaches epic proportions is called "Ulgaazan," though even these mighty beasts pale in comparison to their namesake.

Incredibly ferocious, nyssholoras are dinosaur-like creatures that number among the most dangerous and feared apex predators on the planet of Castrovel. These walking weapons brandish lethal biology: a massive maw lined with twin rows of razor-sharp teeth, scythe-shaped phasic blade forearms that vibrate at ultrasonic speeds, and a scourge-like tail capable of absorbing electricity from the surrounding atmosphere. Yet, nyssholoras are also cunning and perceptive—a frill of tentacles that crowns their head detect telepathic signals, making it impossible for the local formians and lashuntas to escape their notice. Their phasic blades can cut through walls and vehicles as easily as underbrush, ensuring prey have nowhere safe to hide.

action->Telepathy Sense.name: Telepathy Sense
action->Telepathy Sense.description: A nyssholora senses all creatures that have telepathy, limited telepathy, or a similar ability, such as a mystic's bond, as an imprecise sense at the listed range. This sense works through walls and other obstacles.

action->Sonic Snarl.name: Sonic Snarl
action->Sonic Snarl.description:
Trigger A creature fails or critically fails a melee Strike against the nyssholora

Effect The nyssholora snarls at the triggering creature, dealing @Damage[(3d6+6)[sonic]] damage.

action->Crunch.name: Crunch
action->Crunch.description:
Frequency once per round

Requirements A creature is @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.kWc1fhmv9LBiTuei]{Grabbed} in the nyssholora's jaws

Effect The nyssholora chomps down on the creature, dealing @Damage[(2d12+16)[piercing]] damage.

action->Discordant Bellow.name: Discordant Bellow
action->Discordant Bellow.description: The nyssholora unleashes a blast of discordant sound that deal @Damage[18d6[sonic]|options:area-damage] damage in a @Template[type:cone|distance:60] (@Check[reflex|dc:38|basic] save). Objects and constructs in the area are treated as if they had half as much Hardness as usual. Creatures that critically fail their saving throw are also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.xYTAsEpcJE1Ccni3]{Slowed 1} for 1 round. The nyssholora can't use Discordant Bellow again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Discordant Bellow]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Phasic Flurry.name: Phasic Flurry
action->Phasic Flurry.description: The nyssholora Strides up to its Speed then makes a phasic blade Strike against each creature within reach. Each attack counts toward the nyssholora's multiple attack penalty, but the penalty doesn't increase until after all the attacks.

action->Phasic Strike.name: Phasic Strike
action->Phasic Strike.description: A nyssholora's phasic blade Strike treats any object or construct it hits as if the target had half as much Hardness as usual.

Vanguard-Class Soldier Robot.name: Vanguard-Class Soldier Robot
Vanguard-Class Soldier Robot.publicNotes:
Vanguard-class soldier robots are hulking machines of battle. They often have four clawed hands, digitigrade legs, a long tail, and a featureless, diamond-shaped head. Their back-mounted plasma launcher and burst-duration jump jets give them a hunched, predatory appearance, augmented by top-of-the-line weapons. Each is 8 feet tall and weighs 700 pounds.

Though their striking image has captured media attention, the vanguard-class soldier robot is too expensive to mass-produce on the scale of an army, and so they are used as special forces, vanguards, bodyguards, and even field commanders for all-robotic forces. A lack of large-scale feasibility is, admittedly, poor comfort to any soul within seeker warhead range.

Living soldiers are a liability. They have families who don't want them to die, need salaries, have morale, require discipline, commit atrocities, and have opinions on the war. They're a necessary, but unfortunate, part of warfare for any society without an abiding love for necromancy.

Cutting-edge soldier robots promise to solve this problem. Soldier robots have no loved ones, opinions, self-preservation instinct, or tendency toward random atrocities. Many companies market their soldier robots as a humane solution to modern combat.

In practice, they're anything but.

Without lives on the line, soldier robots encourage their owners to engage more often and more violently. Standoffs turn into skirmishes, skirmishes into battles, and inevitably the innocent are caught up in the mix. They're particularly popular with corporations and non-governmental organizations that appreciate being able to throw a dozen soldier robots at any naysayer, public critic, or explorer they dislike while being able to deny true responsibility for what happens.

Though there's constant public fear of soldier robots going rogue, it has yet to prove a serious concern. If a soldier robot wants you dead, it's because someone doesn't mind if it kills you.
Vanguard-Class Soldier Robot.sensesDetails: linked senses 60 feet, x-ray vision (precise) 60 feet

weapon->Integrated Advanced Painglaive.name: Integrated Advanced Painglaive
weapon->Integrated Advanced Painglaive.description:
Upgrades: 1

This fierce but deceptively elegant polearm rips apart enemies with a motor-powered fangblade. An adjustable pulse trigger allows the wielder to channel extra pain through the weapon.

weapon->Integrated Advanced Seeker Rifle.name: Integrated Advanced Seeker Rifle
weapon->Integrated Advanced Seeker Rifle.description:
Upgrades: 1

This single-shot sniper rifle is one of the most popular weapons in the Vast thanks to its stability and reliability with minimal upkeep.

action->Assault Jump.name: Assault Jump
action->Assault Jump.description: The vanguard-class soldier robot Leaps to a space it can see within 60 feet. All creatures within 5 feet of where the robot lands must succeed at a @Check[reflex|dc:33] save or be knocked @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.j91X7x0XSomq8d60]{Prone}. The robot then makes a painglaive Strike against one creature within reach. The robot can't use Assault Jump again for [[/gmr 1d4 #Recharge Assault Jump]]{1d4 rounds}.

action->Linked Senses (60 feet).name: Linked Senses (60 feet)
action->Linked Senses (60 feet).description: The vanguard-class soldier robot shares senses with other allied vanguard-class soldier robots within 60 feet.

action->Seeker Warhead.name: Seeker Warhead
action->Seeker Warhead.description:
Frequency once per day

Effect The vanguard-class soldier robot fires a plasma warhead at an intersection within 200 feet it can see. All creatures in a @Template[type:burst|distance:15] take @Damage[8d12[fire]|options:area-damage] damage (@Check[reflex|dc:33|basic] save). On a failure, a creature is also @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.9PR9y0bi4JPKnHPR]{Deafened} for 1 minute. The area in which the warhead exploded becomes difficult terrain.

action->X-Ray Vision (60 feet).name: X-Ray Vision (60 feet)
action->X-Ray Vision (60 feet).description: The vanguard-class soldier robot can see through most materials and walls within 60 feet. Its sight is blocked by 2 feet of wood or plastic, 1 foot of stone, 2 inches of metal, or any amount of lead or starmetal, and it can see only in black and white.

Veolisk.name: Veolisk
Veolisk.publicNotes:
Veolisks, formidable creatures from remote planets within the Vast, are reminiscent of prehistoric megafauna, despite their relatively smaller size. These lumbering quadrupeds, characterized by their reptilian features and bony exoskeletons, evoke the mystery and fear often associated with ancient colossal creatures. The reason for their seclusion becomes apparent as most xenobiologists posit that the creature's gaze, capable of inducing mental distress in other species, renders habitation near veolisk territory a daunting challenge. Encounters with veolisks near established communities lead to ruthless hunts.

The creatures, with their signature Void Gaze ability, have sparked speculation about their lineage. Some theories propose that veolisks descended from ancestors with more potent gaze attacks, earning them the moniker "void basilisks" among those versed in Lost Golarion's ancient folklore. An intriguing hypothesis suggests that millennia ago, destruction-loving cultists of the Devourer might have selectively bred the first veolisks, a narrative predating the Gap

Despite their fearsome reputation, veolisks find utility as guardians for Devourer cult bases and even as pets to individuals embracing the chaos of the universe. Interestingly, veolisks are docile and harmless when equipped with blinders, veils, or other means to nullify their gaze—a quirk rarely explored in cross-cultural attempts at domestication.

Surviving on minimal sustenance, veolisks consume a single meal daily, feeding on flesh, fruits, fungus, or any available plant life. The physiological systems of veolisks remain a subject of study among scientists. Theories range from hyperefficient metabolisms to feeding on cosmic radiation, akin to trees photosynthesizing sunlight. A fringe notion suggests veolisks might subsist solely on background arcane energies pervasive throughout the galaxy, challenging the boundaries of scientific understanding.

action->Void Glance.name: Void Glance
action->Void Glance.description:
Trigger A creature within 30 feet that the veolisk can see starts its turn

Effect The target must attempt a @Check[will|dc:24] save. If it fails, it's @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the end of the veolisk's next turn from distracting thoughts of the emptiness of space.

action->Null Bite.name: Null Bite
action->Null Bite.description: The veolisk makes a jaws Strike against a @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} creature, which gains the deadly d10 trait. If the target attempts the flat check to recover from its confusion when it takes damage from this Strike, it rolls twice and takes the lower result.

action->Void Gaze.name: Void Gaze
action->Void Gaze.description: The veolisk's eyes exude the dark, claustrophobic aspects of deep space. A creature the veolisk can see within 30 feet must attempt a @Check[will|dc:24] save. If it fails, it becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.AJh5ex99aV6VTggg]{Off-Guard} until the end of the veolisk's next turn. On a critical failure, or on a failure if the creature was already off-guard from this ability or Void Glance, the creature instead becomes @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.yblD8fOR1J8rDwEQ]{Confused} until the end of the veolisk's next turn.

Void Ooze.name: Void Ooze
Void Ooze.publicNotes:
A scourge to spacefarers across the galaxy and beyond, void oozes slip into the Universe from the Netherworld. These creatures float through space in eternal hibernation until they land on a planetoid or spaceship, awoken by the subtle signs of life. Entire colonies can form overnight from a single ooze lucky enough to find a battlefield, consuming the deceased and wounded in no man's land before spreading to consume the camps of war-weary soldiers.

Oozes of many types lurk in dark and abandoned places across the galaxy, emerging only to satiate their appetites and threaten adventurers, explorers, and hapless workers alike.

action->Vitality Siphon.name: Vitality Siphon
action->Vitality Siphon.description: 20 feet. A creature attempting to restore Hit Points with a magical effect to one or more creatures inside the aura must succeed at a @Check[will|dc:25] save for each target or else the magic heals the void ooze instead. If a creature gains the dying condition while inside the aura, the ooze regains @Damage[10[healing]] Hit Points.

action->Numb Senses.name: Numb Senses
action->Numb Senses.description:
A living creature hit by a void ooze's pseudopod Strike must succeed at a @Check[fortitude|dc:25] save or become @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.TkIyaNPgTZFBCCuh]{Dazzled} and @UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.9PR9y0bi4JPKnHPR]{Deafened} until the end of the creature's next turn (@UUID[Compendium.sf2e.conditions.Item.XgEqL1kFApUbl5Z2]{Blinded} and deafened on a critical failure).

This numbs all of the creature's perceptive senses (such as smell, taste, and touch), applying the dazzled and blinded conditions' effects to other precise senses the creature might have.

action->Shades Linger.name: Shades Linger
